Grimhaven MUD Game Design

Revision 1.0 draft: 2000.01.31

(This document is a work in progress. I am anticipating a second pass at the Game Design question and as such am drawing this document to explore the changes before committing myself to actual code. - Batopr 10/22/1999)

Table of Contents

Grimhaven MUD Game Design

Introduction

For any system as complex as a MUD to both maintain long term stability of existing systems, and allow for the addition of new and modification of old systems, it is imperative that the game design be well thought out in a quantitative manner. It is only by devising a systematic approach that details what is expected, and then implementing such a plan that the game maintainers can ever hope to achieve a macroscopic understanding of their game, or properly diagnose problems that occur.

Unfortunately, in the real world, game design tends to fall by the wayside by most implementers. Too often new imps opt to dive into the programming, adding in those neat bells & whistles they've always wanted in a mud, while game design (assuming it existed in the base code they started with) is ignored or willfully disregarded.

There is a misconception amongst such implementers that they can “stay in touch” with the game and will be able to head off any problems that new code introduces. In a simple system, this might well be possible. But as a mud becomes larger and larger, and as code elements become increasingly intertwined, it becomes both more likely that a given change will cause problems in other subsystems, and that problems will go unnoticed because the implementers insist that nothing they touched recently should have had any effect.

To further complicate the life of implementers, players of the game often “misreport” problems. That is to say, a player may report that X is broken. A detailed analysis would reveal that indeed X is out of specification, but it is in fact due to a small discrepancy in the intertwined system Y. This is not a criticism of well-meaning players that report problems that are observed. I use this hypothetical example to illustrate that without a thorough understanding of both what the X and Y systems are expected to do, but also how they interact with each other, implementers are lulled into tweaking X rather than fixing the root cause in Y. The result is that Y is left broken (unknowingly), while X is now corrupted to account for this problem.

What problems will changing X now cause? Are the problems in the broken Y limited to those noted in X? Implementers lacking a solid game design simply cannot evaluate these questions, and are forced to firefight as things crop up. The high degree of complexity associated with a MUD environment, and the fact that a player's life span covers many months means that a mud in such a state will inevitably be forced to make vast, and profound changes in the course of this fire-fighting. Players, of course, do not like it when the “rules” are changed on them, but, of course, the implementers are simply trying to keep some semblance of order to their chaotic system.

Ideally, implementers would create a solid game design at the outset, and then simply use code to implement this design. The theory can be worked out prior to players ever experiencing the new code, and problems can be caught while still in the pen, paper and calculator phase rather than the “You've destroyed my character you unfeeling bastard!” phase. Likewise, when the inevitable problem does crop up, implementers are able to check the numbers and use statistics to diagnose problems, and zero in on the proper fix.

Some History:

This realization was made by myself and the other implementers of Grimhaven some time ago, and the problems of a missing or not-adhered-to game design I speak of from first-hand experience. Ultimately, we committed ourselves to reintroducing a solid game design.

Not fully understanding the scope that such a game design would mean, we initially opted to retrofit the new game design into our existing mud. Additionally, since we had existing players, and knew how painful it is to perform a mud-wide conversion of player files, the decision was made to minimize the impact to the players by making the game design of certain elements agree with what was already in place. For instance, the number of HP a player has at a given level was pre-existing, so we simply started with that element as fixed, and ramped up from there.

This was not exactly a mistake, as the system that resulted was highly stable and was an order of magnitude improvement over what went before. However, by accepting these arbitrary constraints, we denied ourselves the ability to get the “best” possible game design. However, this “rough draft” was quite revealing, and it is doubtful that anyone could be expected to get game design right the first time.

This document forms the basis of a second pass at answering the Game Design question. The lessons learned in the first pass will be taken to heart, and we hope to build upon the successes that that first pass resulted in. However, this time around we will not impose arbitrary constraints, and are basically assuming a clean slate. For practical purposes, this means either an equally fresh slate in terms of players (PWipe, yuck!) or at the very least the acceptance of some conversion of players as the migration to the new game design occurs.

Prerequisites and Caveats

Readers of this document are presumed to be relatively familiar with the basic concepts associated with a MUD as well as basic RPG terminology. For the most part, familiarity with other gaming systems is a boon. I am making no effort to provide a glossary of terms as I presume that anyone reading this document has the necessary background knowledge.

Furthermore, Game Design is inherently quantitative. Those with a fear of numbers should be wary when perusing this document. The math will at times get intense, if I lose someone in the numbers, my apology in advance.

For the most part however, if you have an understanding of algebra (solving equations for the unknowns), basic calculus (how simple functions are shaped) and are not lost when presented with a term like “2d6+6” is mentioned, then this document ought to be understandable.

Thesis Justification

The casual reader of this paper is likely to question the need for this level of in-depth analysis. In places, this paper will go into extraordinary depth, often into areas of the Game Dynamics that seldom see much exposure. It is right to question whether spending the amount of time to push as deep as we do into the nitty-gritty details. Can't we just “wing it”?

The dangers of winging it were explored in the opening few paragraphs. While I personally feel that the rationale there is compelling enough, I will offer one additional argument for a high degree of understanding of the nitty-gritty details. By doing so, any Game system devised can be defended on logical grounds.

Please note that I use the term “logical” as opposed to “instinctual”. Players that feel that the system works against them are going to respond poorly to the “instinctual” arguments. A mathematical rationale for why a player has the HP that they do will be much more widely accepted than one that goes “I just felt that that class should have X HP”. Players that see that things are the way they are because the system has been heavily thought through will complain less often and less loudly, (especially when they can follow the logic and see the assumptions) than those that feel that the “game design” was developed by the implementers after drinking too many beers one night.

Furthermore, I use the term “logical” as opposed to “realistic”. Frequent debates break out over changes that are made on “realistic” grounds. As the Game Designers, we must keep in mind that what is being created is a gaming simulation and not a virtual reality. It's nice to use reality as a framework, but we must avoid compromising the gaming system. In the final analysis, a game that has a good logical system behind it will be more enjoyable than one that strictly models reality in all its unpleasant and mundane detail.

Thus, we go to this much trouble to delve into the gaming system in order to avoid making seemingly arbitrary decisions that must face constant scrutiny. At the same time, we isolate the critical systems upon which “enjoyability” will be measured from the well-meaning features thrown on top of the Gaming System that may or may not have a beneficial effect on the game. Such thoroughness insures that the core system is stable and defensible (thus letting developers concentrate on creating the features that are desired).

Some Basics of Game Design

It is appropriate to begin a discussion of game design by first establishing what we are attempting to accomplish. There will be some tough decisions along the path ahead, and it is useful to have a yardstick with which we can measure the options to aid in sorting through the confusion.

A Quantitative Model

Game Design is first and foremost establishing quantitative numbers that model how we desire our game system to behave. The root decisions, as seen in the above calculations, often come down to gut instincts and arbitrary decisions. Often, these decisions are simply based on experience as a game implementer.

It is important to understand that while we often start with arbitrary decisions, we also establish how we want systems to behave. These rules of behavior serve to constrain our choices. As systems intermingle, the constraints become tighter and tighter. We cease to be able to make arbitrary decisions. At a certain point, we become tightly bound to the math and must cease to do as we please.

Establishing and Maintaining Equilibrium

Secondly, Game Design deals strongly in establishing the relationships between systems. We must have an understanding of how our systems are setup, as well as how they interrelate or chaos will surely ensue.

The process of establishing equilibrium between a MUD's systems is generally referred to as balancing. This term has often gotten a bad reputation amongst mud players, primarily due to most MUDs lacking an overall game design, and hence implementers misuse the “balance” phrase to mean stripping away powers from players of a game gone haywire. This is of course unfortunate, for if the true sense of the word is applied, the gaming system is both more stable over the long haul, and more readily understandable by implementers and players alike.

A Basic Definition of Balance

In one sense, balancing a MUD is about insuring that the relative advantages and disadvantages in a given decision are equalized. A decision that leads to more advantage is said to be "over powered" while one that has more disadvantages is thought to be "under powered". However, realize that when evaluating advantages and disadvantages, it is important to maintain perspective. It is entirely possible to devise a balanced decision where one choice leads to immediate rewards, but long-term hardships, and the other is a more even-keeled choice. It's useful to keep the "entire career" in mind and not simply evaluate the instantaneous effect.

In another sense, balance is a state of equilibrium where both players and NPCs are thought to be in synch, neither being evidently stronger than the other is. In this sort of balance, the outcome of any given fight heavily depends on both luck and technique. Players can't affect the random number generators, but the tactics they use will generally skew the outcome of a balanced MUD into their favor.

Furthermore, balance is also an intra-player concept in terms of analyzing whether choices the individual player has to make are even. At the simplest level, this can mean looking at racial and class choices, but translates down into equipment choice, learning paths, and a whole slew of other minor decisions. In a nutshell, balance in this sense, is about evaluating all possible choices, and striving to make all the choices evenly weighted.

Why Balance?

As a game designer, we seek to have all aspects of the game utilized. No coder wishes to develop a new aspect of the game that no one wishes to play with. Where is the reward in that?

However, it also behooves coders to respect what went before. If they add a new aspect of the game that is better than the alternatives, players will shift to that (which is not fair to the developer(s) of the original alternatives). Balance, in a sense, is about not adding things that are better or worse, but about simply extending the number of choices available.

It is a rare game that adds elements that are weaker than the alternatives. Typically, new choices are over-powered because either the coder has not contemplated balance concerns, or has opted to ignore balance-concerns in favor of kudos and praise from a grateful player-base. It is the game designer's duty to avoid such situations, as it leads to one of three bad consequences.

Consequence 1: Realize an element is overpowered, and go in after the fact to tame down the power to the "balanced state". This of course leads to wide- spread complaints from the players that chose that element (because it was better).

Consequence 2: Do nothing. Typically this is not a decision that is made consciously, usually being the result of not being informed, or of not having enough time to address the problem. The obvious pitfall is that the longer such a state occurs, the more folks will take the stronger option and the harder it will be to change it at a later date.

Consequence 3: Redefine "balance" to take the strength of the new element into account. Balance is simply an equilibrium state where all things are equal. To some degree, nothing prevents a game designer from enhancing all elements of a decision equally to reacquire balance. However, this can only go so far in a gaming system. Coders are limited by the size of their variables, by the amount of data they can track, and by the speed of their hardware to make all the necessary calculations. Also, realize that balance is a concept with tremendous down-stream effects. In some regards, it is possible to simply redefine (upward) all other aspects, but this may not be feasible to do in a timely manner. Do this often enough and I guarantee you will run out of resources (available space, time, or processing power).

Game Design Methodology

Game Design is not a skill most people have naturally. While there are many, many, many MUDs in existence, very few of them are actually "designed". For the most part, the coders simply throw elements together, making random tweaks and adjustments as needed, and listen to feedback from the players. Some MUDs can be "successful" in doing this. But realize all they have managed to accomplish is to achieve an equilibrium state without understanding why they have the equilibrium they do, what the assumptions their game system operates under (except in very vague terms), or what the consequences of changing a given aspect will have on their equilibrium. In short, they are only capable of stumbling forward blindly, and can only safely add "bells and whistle" features without seriously risking a complete breakdown of their equilibrium.

Most multiplayer games, and MUDs in particular, are effectively chaotic systems, in that a small change in one area can propagate through the entire system and have dramatic effect in a wholly unrelated aspect of the game. The more complex the MUD, the greater is the need for understanding the ramifications of any proposed change. While the original DIKU was developed by a group of programmers, most MUDs today are small enough that a single programmer can maintain them. As time passes and MUDs get more involved, their complexity will also grow and they will exceed the capacity for one person to understand all aspects of the system. By that point, it becomes paramount that the overall game design be laid down so that new programmers can be added effectively, and that all can clearly see how given subsystems interact with each other.

In devising the gaming system, it behooves us to start simply, and add more elements as we progress. That is, while we eventually want multiple classes and multiple races and a wide-variety of skills, we are forced to start with a very basic system and get things working at the basic level before we create an overly exotic system. Trying to address too many variables at one time leads to burned out game designers, so isolate the problem, start small and don't add new elements until you are assured that the basic elements are working correctly.

A Basic Introduction to Combat:

The Power Equation:

For DIKU-based MUDs, the game centers on the combat system. Not all MUDs follow this trend (LP being an example), but for our situation, this is a fundamental fact of life. It is therefore appropriate to begin the discussion of Game Design with a basic analysis of combat.

Combat, in its simplest terms, is comprised of two combatants whacking away at each other until one of them falls. Each combatant is rated for how many whacks he can take (Hit points or HP), and how much damage (dam) he inflicts each time he whacks the other guy. (This is heavily simplified!) Furthermore, combat is generally broken down into rounds in which each combatant gets a number of hits per round. Please realize that “simplification” also means ignoring all the complex details that are a necessary part of a good combat system including chance of misses occurring, critical hits, magical effects, etc. etc. For the time being, we are just going to sweep that all under the rug…

The relevant equations for this are:

  1. SimpAvgDam/Hit

= Simplified Average Damage Per Hit

Generally rated by the combat system based on weapon-type, or racial bare-hand score. (More on this later)

  1. SimpAvgHits/Rnd

= Simplified Average Hits Per Round

Generally rated by the combat system based on racial speed. (More on this later)

  1. SimpAvgDam/Rnd

= Simplified Average Damage Per Round

= SimpAvgDam/Hit* SimpAvgHits/Rnd

Since damage is scored in terms of HP removed, we yield:

  1. SimpHP

= Hit Points

Generally rated by the gaming system based on class. (More on this later)

  1. SimpSurvRnds

= Simplified Survival Rounds

= SimpHP / (opponents SimpAvgDam/Rnd)

That is to say, the number of rounds of combat I will survive is how many HP I have, divided by how fast my opponent can remove my HP.

We note that a given fight is evenly balanced when:

  1. SimpBalancedCombat

SimpSurvRndsa = SimpSurvRndsb

SimpHPa / SimpAvgDam/Rndb = SimpHPb / SimpAvgDam/Rnda

SimpHPa * SimpAvgDam/Rnda = SimpHPb * SimpAvgDam/Rndb

This suggests that there is a simple equation for a person's “power”.

  1. SimpPower

= Simplified Power

= SimpHP * SimpAvgDam/Rnd

Of course all we have really stated here is that a person grows in power if they can raise their HP or if they can raise their damage. This is fairly elementary.

It is only a minor leap of understanding to generalize these two terms into a “defense” term and an “offense” term. So that we get:

  1. SimpPower

= Refined from (Equation 7.)

= simpOffPow * simpDefPow

SimpOffPow deals with things that contribute to offensive capability such as the amount of damage inflicted per hit, number of swings per round, chance of hitting, etc. SimpDefPow will be things that contribute to defensive capability, such as number of HP, amount of armor worn, ability to dodge and deflect blows, and the like. Thus, simpOffPow is the contribution to the power equation from the “simplified offense” (simpOff) function. And similarly, simpDefPower is the contribution to the power equation from the “simplified defense” (simpDef) function.

We will begin to derive these functions momentarily, but it helps to understand how we are breaking things down first. In short, a creature has a “power rating” as given by the power equation. This power rating is made up of that creature's simpOffPow and simpDefPow scores. SimpOffPow is derived from the creature's simpOff equation, and it is things like the amount of damage, number of swings, etc that make up simpOff. And likewise for simpDefPow and simpDef…

The Concept of Level

Most MUDs have the concept of “level”. That is, as a character advances, they rise in level. Thus, level is simply a synonym for how advanced that particular character is. The higher the level, the more advanced that person is.

While most MUDs have levels, it is not a universal constant. That is, within one MUD, you can be fairly sure that a Level 10 (abbreviated L10) is more advanced that a L5 in the same MUD. However, there is no good way to compare a L10 in one MUD to a L10 in another.

Levels essentially make discreet “steps” for advancement and serve as goals for the players. Obviously, between the beginning and ending of the game, there should be a fair number of levels, but not so many that there is little to distinguish one level from the next.

There is no correct answer to how many levels a game ought to have. It is essentially a personal preference. For our purposes, we have opted for a system of 50 levels.

Power as a Function of Level

Since we would like for a player to rise in power as they advance, it is a natural extension to think that the power formula ought to be a function of level.

What this means is that as a person advances, they rise in level. As a person gains levels, their simpOffPow and simpDefPow scores are expected to rise. As a result of this, their SimpPower goes up.

The upshot of this is that simpOffPow and/or simpDefPow functions of level. We will come back to this point momentarily, but for the time being, we must simply recognize that power is a function of level.

Let us naively assume:

  1. SimpOffPowForm

= The format of the simpOffPow equation

= Function of level

And that it takes the form

= A (level)B + C

Where A, and C are some arbitrary scaling constants, and B is some (constant) exponent.

(Side-Note: I experimented with a variety of forms for the simpOffPow formula. I am skipping the intermediate iterations and jumping to what I think is the best of the lot.)

For the most part, we can ignore A as a variable. Factoring out A simply changes the value of C, but it is still some arbitrary constant. On the LHS, factoring A out just scales SimpOffPowForm differently.

The effect of changing C is also of interest. Since we will ultimately like to compare the relative power of high-level players to the power of low-level players (this will be a prime design condition), the value of C is extremely useful in tweaking this relative number. That is to say, if C=0, then a L50 winds up with power=50B, while a L1 has power=1. It is unlikely that we would want to design the system such that high level players have vastly more power than their newbie counterparts (more on this later), we would be forced to choose very small values for B. However, if we boost C, we essentially add to what a L1 has; L1 power=1+C. While we also add this tiny amount to L50's, it is the former term that will dominate; L50 power=50B + C. The net result is that the relative number (L50 power / L1 power) shrinks; or equivalently, larger values of B can be selected. Apologies for the obtuse math; but simply regard the C factor as a “newbie gift” that is useful to tweak the relative power between high and low level characters.

Lastly, contemplate the B factor. For values of B>1, we realize that a small change in level results in a greater change in power. Small discrepancies get magnified. Conversely, for values of 0<=B<=1, small changes in level are de-emphasized.

We also note that the B value is primarily responsible for how much power a player gains at a given stage in their career. Values of B>1 result in large gains later in the career, while B<1 will cause power to go up quicker in the early levels.

We are then left to debate what sort of a system we would like to create. As we expect that players will make some missteps while adventuring and will vary somewhat from what we will come to regard as “average”, it behooves us to create a system where a minor error is not magnified into a tremendous impact on their character. That is to say, (working backwards) should a player have bad luck when gaining HP, for example, (no fault of their own), we don't want the derived “level” that results from this lower than norm HP to differ radically from what their true level is. We are thus encouraged to choose a value of B as small as possible.

Along similar lines of reasoning, we ought to devise a system that attracts players, and one of the simplest means of doing this is to make the first few levels fairly easy and rewarding. Since B<1 gives big gains in power over the first few levels, this is yet another reason to strive for low values of B.

However, as a counter-thesis, we should not ignore the effects of the two terms (B & C) acting together. While the case for B<1 has already been thoroughly made, we realize that by boosting C, we can give a generous gift in terms of power which most affects newbies. This cancels some of the arguments for B<1. The bottom line is to strive for a B as small as possible, but to realize that if we raise C, we can also raise B and still have a workable system. Furthermore, as far as the value of B debate goes, I expect there to be a reasonable argument made that “Yes, we'd like to de-emphasize mistakes (B<1), but power should grow logarithmically (growing faster and faster as level increases)”. I have no quantitative argument over which is a better system, so strike the balance that you like best.

If we assume that the damage formula follows the same form, we can make the same arguments and yield the same conclusions. We are not forced to choose the same values for the constants in the two formulas. Thus,

  1. SimpDefPowFormat

= The format of the simpDefPow equation

= Function of level

= D (level)E + F

= (level)E + F

  1. SimpPowerForm

= The format of the SimpPower equation

= Function of level

= SimpOffPowForm * SimpDefPowForm

= ((level)B + C) * ((level)E + F)

Deriving Values for B, C, E and F

It is now appropriate to start talking about some desirable qualities and discovering what these desires yield in terms of the formulas.

Firstly, we would like the simpDefPow and simpOffPow formulas to de-emphasize goof-ups. Following the above logic, 0<B<1 and 0<E<1 would be ideal. However, this concern is not paramount as we note that if we give a reasonably large value for C and F, newbies will be rewarded with a sizable bonus up front on their simpDefPow and simpOffPow. We should strive to keep B and E low, but we are free to let them exceed 1.0 if we boost C and F at the same time.

Secondly, we will strive for a relative power between L1 and L50 of 5000. That is, a L50 is 5000 times more powerful than a L1. Obviously, we want high-level players to be (much) more powerful than their newbie counterparts, but we don't want to foster an atmosphere of elitism. Likewise, if we expect players to explore, we must expect them to occasionally tread into regions for which they are not yet ready. An excessively high value for relative power results in almost assured instant death (and discourages exploration). A value of 5000 seems to be a reasonable, albeit arbitrary, compromise.

(Note: Our original opinion was to make the relative power be 500. It was not until much later in the derivation that we realized the problems with this. Choosing too low a number makes certain things later on (AC, HP, damage) too flat. That is, there is little deviation over a wide range of levels. This was viewed as problematic, hence we boosted our assumption to 5000.)

Thirdly, we do some cursory analysis of the effects of grouping. We ask ourselves how many players of level X would be required to balance the power of a L50 (or any level for that matter). For no particular reason, except gut instinct, we think that 1 L50 equate with 2 characters of roughly L40.

Similarly, we would like the system to yield no dramatic swings in power in any range of 3 levels (or so). For the most part, the intention is to keep L1 and L3 players roughly equivalent. Previous experiments have resulted in vast differences in power over the first few levels resulting in players complaining. Players do not expect there to be tremendous differences in power between small ranges in level, so our system should reflect this.

Likewise, we need to plan for those “ultimate groups”. Eventually, we should expect that enough high-level players will exist and they all team up to see what they can kill as a group. The system should extend far enough that a reasonable challenge could be offered to a group of 10 L50 players.

Many solutions exist for this problem. I have arbitrarily opted to make B=E and C=F so that both equations are equivalent just to simplify things. Some simple algebra then yields:

Power at L50 = 5000 * Power at L1

(50B + C) * (50E + F) = 5000 * (1B + C) * (1E + F)

(50B + C) * (50B + C) = 5000 * (1B + C) * (1B + C)

(50B + C) * (50B + C) = 5000 * (1 + C) * (1 + C)

(50B + C)2 = 5000 * (1 + C)2

(50B + C) = sqrt(5000) * (1 + C)

50B = sqrt(5000) * (1 + C) - C

B = log(sqrt(5000) * (1 + C) - C) / log(50)

Thus, we are left an equation with only one unknown, the value of C. As noted earlier, larger values of C help newbies the most. Since we don't want large shifts in power over the first few levels, we tweak C so that the relative power between L3 and L1 is roughly 2. By trial and error, we settled on C=13. By derivation, B=1.759815.

  1. SimpDefPow, SimpOffPow and SimpPower as a function of level

As formulas, we yield:

  1. SimpDefPow

= SimpDef Power Equation

= Represents simpDef's contribution to the Power equation

  1. (level)1.759815 + 13

  1. SimpOffPow

= SimpOff Power Equation

= Represents simpOff's contribution to the Power equation

  1. (level)1.759815 + 13

Having done this, we can also derive the power equation.

  1. Power

= Power Equation

= SimpDefPow * SimpOffPow

= ((level)1.759815 + 13) * ((level)1.759815 + 13)

  1. ((level)1.759815 + 13)2

Basic Extensions of the Simple Combat System

When we first began discussion of power, we noted that we were going to deal with a heavily simplified view of combat. Realize that what we have done up to this point essentially is to establish the shape and size of the power function. Additionally, we have identified that the power function consists of two pieces, the SimpDefPow formula and the SimpOffPow formula. This was useful for analyzing and understanding power and level and getting a rough feel for some numbers. However, it is meaningless in terms of a practical combat system. We need to start breaking up the simple terms into component pieces and assigning concepts to those components in order to yield anything worthwhile.

A Deeper Analysis of SimpDefPow and SimpOffPow

As previously noted, we have some basic relationships between our terms as follows:

(Equation 14.) Power = SimpDefPow * SimpOffPow

  1. SimpDefPow

= SimpDef's contribution to power

= (level)1.759815 + 13

= SimpDef * (constant scalar)

  1. SimpOffPow

= SimpOff's contribution to power

= (level)1.759815 + 13

= SimpOff * (constant scalar)

We can further stipulate that simpDef is comprised primarily of the character's HP (number of hits they can survive) and their “defense ability” (likelihood of avoiding being hit). We'll represent these two concepts as ActHP (the character's actual HP) and ActDef (the character's defense score). Thus:

  1. SimpDef

= Simplified defense

= ActHP * ActDef

Following similar reasoning, stipulate SimpOff as being comprised of a damage rating (ActDam) and an offensive rating (ActOff). Hence:

  1. SimpOff

= Simplified offense

= ActDam * ActOff

Combining (Equation 15.) and (Equation 17.), we realize that we can essentially take the raw scores for ActHP and ActDef, multiply them together yielding simpDef and scale it up linearly. The result is the term shown in (Equation 12.). Thus, with only a minor leap of logic, we can take the term achieved in 12, and divvy it out so that a portion is given to actHP and a portion to actDef. There are a number of ways to do this apportionment, but I have chosen one that I think works best. Equations look like:

  1. SimpDefPow

= Refined from (Equation 15.)

= (level)1.759815 + 13

= SimpDef * (constant scalar)

= ActHP * ActDef * constant

= (ActHP* constant) * (ActDef * constant)

We will presume that this takes the form

= ((level)1.759815 + 13)n * ((level)1.759815 + 13)1-n

A similar argument for offense yields:

  1. SimpOffPow

= Refined from (Equation 16.)

= (level)1.759815 + 13

= SimpOff * (constant scalar)

= ActDam * ActOff * constant

= (ActDam * constant) * (ActOff * constant)

We will presume that this takes the form

= ((level)1.759815 + 13)m * ((level)1.759815 + 13)1-m

We are left to simply choose values for n and m such that ActHP, ActOff, ActDam, ActDef scale as we desire.

Determining n, HP Concerns

As we find ourselves at the limits of what the equations are able to tell us, we must again explore what we desire in our MUD. Of the four terms, actHP, actDef, actDam, and actOff, it is with the actHP term that we will begin.

We begin by stipulating that we would like a max-level player to have roughly 1500 HP total. This number was arbitrarily chosen, but is based on the following concerns.

First, the number should be large enough that small differences in HP gained per level will be noticed. Secondly, the number should not be so great that the mud enters into the “twink” realm often characterized by MUDs that have players with tens of thousands of HP. Third, the allotment needs to provide newbies with a reasonable cushion of HP that will let them survive the learning curve. Finally, there is a gut instinct amongst the core-audience of MUD players (probably induced by expectations from playing AD&D) that a player should tend to approach about 1500 HP (or so) near max level.

(Historical Note: Around the time of SneezyMUD v2.5, max-level players were each hovering around 3500-5000 HP. Ultimate-group mobs thus were in the 30K+ HP range. There was a general feeling that the current trend was spiraling us toward becoming more and more twinkish. With the advent of v3.0, the max-level HP range was trimmed back to around 500. Over the next few years, it creeped-up slowly to perhaps 800 during v4.5. When the value of 500 was reestablished during v5.0 and v5.1, there was a general complaint about the lack of effect of various factors to significantly alter HP. This led to the push to make the value large enough to illustrate the effects of choices that players make.)

As we desire HP at L50 to be 1500, the equation that results is:

((50)1.759815 + 13)n * K = 1500

Furthermore, we want newbies to have a reasonable pad of HP, we stipulate that L1 HP = 100. Thus:

((1)1.759815 + 13)n * K = 100

(14)n * K = 100

We solve this one for K:

K = 100/14n

And plug it in to the other equation. Simple algebra follows:

((50)1.759815 + 13)n * (100 / 14n) = 1500

((50)1.759815 + 13)n / 14n) = 15

(((50)1.759815 + 13) / 14)n = 15

n log(((50)1.759815 + 13) / 14) = log(15)

n = log(15) / log(((50)1.759815 + 13) / 14)

n = 0.635902

And hence:

K = 100/140.635902

K = 18.67131

The establishment of n also determines the score for actDef.

  1. SimpDef, ActHP and ActDef as a function of level

As some simple analysis of what the ramifications of this are, consider:

Newbies start with 100 HP (by design) and gain 10-15 HP per level. The 100 HP start should theoretically satisfy new players that need a learning cushion, while the newbie HP gain rate makes newbies go up in power nicely too.

Meanwhile, a high level player is gaining 30-33 HP per gain at max level. That's sure to keep the megalomaniacs in the audience happy.

We further note that it is not until L35 that a player crosses into the realm of 1000+ HP. Since this is sure to be a milestone for players, it is good that it comes reasonably late in the player's career.

Lastly, the ultimate-group mobs characterized by L100-L120 have 3300-4000 HP. This is fairly large (bordering on the twinkish), but should serve to make those L50 groups think once or twice before rocking the mud.

The relevant equations for all this are:

  1. ActHP

= Actual Hit Points for a character

  1. 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

It is possible to further derive this equation, but doing so just makes the terms more complicated, so we'll leave it as is.

  1. ActDef

= Actual “defense” for a character

  1. ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098

Having achieved a formula for ActHP and ActDef, we can now move on and analyze the terms related to m, actDam and actOff.

Derivation of ActDam; An Analysis of SimpSurvRnds

Recall the SimpSurvRnds equation, which states that the number of HP a creature has, and the damage its opponent(s) inflict per round determines the number of rounds that creature lasts in combat.

Historically, a “round” of combat is 2-3 seconds long (real time). We desire that a “fair-fight” (more on this later) combat last about 3 minutes, which translates as roughly 60 rounds.

While this desire is mostly instinctual, we have noted problems from deviating in both directions. If combat takes a long time (150+ rounds), players grow bored and the mud suffers from tediousness. If combat is too quick (less than 30 rounds), a single round of combat can cause a tremendous shift in the outcome of the fight. Since NPCs logic during a fight is limited, we should expect that NPCs would make some flawed decisions fighting players. Thus we want combat to be long enough that a bad round or two of combat doesn't make the fight a foregone conclusion. All things considered, 60 rounds for combat seems to make the most sense as a desired target.

(Note: I briefly toyed with the idea of having combat duration increase with level, so that newbie fights were relatively fast and high level ones were drawn out. It seemed realistic, but it caused some VERY bizarre alterations to have to be introduced to the system. I removed, and am avoiding reintroducing, this concept in order to keep the system simple.)

With the 60 rounds desired for a fair fight stipulated, the following algebra results:

SimpSurvRnds = 60

ActHP / ActDam = 60

ActDam = ActHP / 60

We can then write the ActDam equation as

  1. ActDam

= Creature's actual damage

= ActHP / 60

= 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902/ 60.0

  1. 0.311189 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

  1. ActHP, ActDam and SimpSurvRnds as a function of level

Derivation of ActOff

Since we now have values for m, we can also write the equation for actOff

  1. ActOff

= actual “offense” for a character

  1. ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098

For reasons that will be made clear later, we desire ActOff and ActDef to match. We are free to multiply either equation by scalar constants, but since we want both functions to yield the same result, these constants must both be the same. With no reason to do otherwise, we set the constants in both equation to 1.0 (which we have not shown).

  1. ActOff and ActDef as a function of level

Extending the Basic Combat System

PCs and NPCs

At this stage of the discussion, it is useful to take a breather and insure that everyone is on the same page. To do this, we need to discuss terminology a bit, and to delve slightly deeper into what sort of a system we desire.

Characters in a MUD can be classified as either PCs or NPCs. This basically establishes whether a player is controlling the character's actions, or if the creature is one that the MUD code is running. NPCs are synonymous with the MUDs monsters (sometimes called mobs).

The features of an advanced MUD tend to muddy the simple terms though. For example, your basic polymorph spell can cause PCs to transform themselves into the form of a mob. Likewise, other spells allow monsters to come under the control of the player. We need to keep these ambiguities in mind as we move forward.

Equating Systems between PCs and NPCs

For any given system we create, we should strive to keep things identical between PCs and NPCs.

This would seem like common sense, and yet, in many circumstances, implementers introduce different systems for the two character types. Anytime this is done, we should sharply analyze the reasons for doing so, as almost assuredly, it means that there is some basic failure or misapplication of the game design.

We have, up to this point, introduced five systems: level, damage, offense, defense and HP. Let's analyze each in turn as they relate to PCs and NPCs.

PC and NPC level

First, there is level. We have already stated that level is to be defined as how “advanced” a given character is. Following our axiom, PC level and NPC level ought to equate. Obviously, the only equating that can be done is in terms of the combat system. So what we are essentially saying is that a PC and an NPC of the same level ought to be roughly the same difficulty.

This statement frequently raises a great number of questions. Realize that we have not yet introduced a very exotic definition of a “character”. For example, we lack important things like class, skills, race, etc. This leaves us a fairly generic definition of a character. So when we say that we are equating NPC and PC level, don't flip out trying to rationalize if a mage and a warrior of level X are the same. We will come back to this in a bit, but let's simply use our generalized definitions of “player” and “mob” for the time being.

And so, what we establish is that a player and a mob of the same level are equal. As game developers, we will analyze what this means, but we should also note that by equating level, things work out very nicely for the players of the MUD. Typically, a MUD will provide a simple “consider” command for players to evaluate NPCs strengths and weaknesses. By devising a system where equal levels equate to equal power, this greatly simplifies these sorts of considerations.

Also, the result is that by equating level, we are essentially making the declaration that we expect and desire players to be fighting like-leveled mobs in single combat.

PC and NPC HP and Damage

Proceeding onwards to the HP and Damage systems, our axiom states that mobs and players ought to have the same HP and do the same damage, at a given level.

Again, the statement is simple common sense from a simple axiom, but frequently, MUDs do not adhere to it. I must confess; Grimhaven was for a long time a violator of this axiom and so I can speak quite knowingly about the problems and the rationalizations for making this mistake.

MUDs lacking a solid game-design frequently find themselves in an unbalanced state. Players are leveling too quickly, or mobs are too easy, or any one of a number of concerns occurs. The common mistake made by implementers in this situation is that mobs need to be increased in power to accommodate. If mobs had 10% more HP, than they wouldn't get killed so quickly and we wouldn't have this problem, right? Obviously, this is false logic indicating a basic problem or lack of an overall game design. However, the logic of this sort of statement is compelling to implementers, because it is such an easy “fix” that avoids addressing the bigger questions.

And so, MUDs evolve where the relative values of HP between PCs and NPCs are slightly different. Implementers make fine-tune adjustments to HP (and possibly damage too) to restore an equilibrium state. Hopefully, they are successful, but regardless, it becomes viewed as natural that NPCs and PCs do not need the same values for HP and damage systems.

In general, this is true. Provided the SimpBalancedCombat equation is in balance, PCs and NPCs could be designed with different systems for HP and damage. However, remember what we said before about the possibility of ambiguity between PCs and NPCs. If we have one system of HP/Dam for players and another for monsters, what happens when a monster becomes a “player” and vice versa? Which system should a polymorphed player use? What system do monsters under a player's control use?

As an example, consider a system that has mobs having more HP than players (and doing less damage consequently). A charmed mob would become a very good tank for a player because of the greater number of HP it possesses. Alternatively, we could convert the mob (upon charm) to be on the player's scale for HP/damage, but now we are talking about making some very bizarre changes to accommodate such a system.

Furthermore, having separate systems of HP and damage for PCs and NPCs will result in calculations having to frequently be converted. The scale factors will have to be taken into account all over the place, and in general, our formulas will be cluttered needlessly.

Hey, I like a challenge as much as the next guy, but how about we just take the hint and keep things simple by making the HP and damage systems for PCs and NPCs the same. By factoring out any differences in the two systems, this simplifies the SimpSurvRnds and SimpBalancedCombat equations:

  1. SimpSurvRnds

= Refined from (Equation 5.)

= SimpHP / (opponents SimpAvgDam/Rnd)

= SimpHP / SimpAvgDam/Rnd

Given our more refined combat system, this should in fact be written:

  1. SurvRnds

= Survival Rounds

= ActHP / ActDam

= This could be derived further after adding level-based terms. Doing so does not add to the clarity though.

Based on the design constraints we used, SurvRnds yields 60 rounds for a fair-fight.

  1. SimpBalancedCombat

= Refined from (Equation 6.)

SimpHPa * SimpAvgDam/Rnda = SimpHPb * SimpAvgDam/Rndb

SimpHP * SimpAvgDam/Rnd = SimpHP * SimpAvgDam/Rnd

This can also be extended to our more exotic system:

  1. BalancedCombat

= Balanced Combat Equation

ActHPa * ActDama = ActHPb * ActDamb

Under our simplified definition of mobs and players, this is the rather trivial statement that says balanced combat occurs when both “a” and “b” are the same level. However, don't dismiss this equation too quickly; it will become much more important once some refinement is done about mobs and players.

Prologue to Combat Hit Percentage

We have previously determined a formula for ActDam; representing how much damage we expect to be inflicted per round of combat. Realizing that our combat system deals with both hits and misses, we should start analyzing combat in terms of the chance of a hit occurring (hit percentage, or HitPerc).

In general, we would like the HitPerc system to be somewhat dependent on level. That is to say, in an even match, both combatants will hit equally as often, but in a skewed battle, the higher-level combatant will hit more often, and conversely, the less skilled combatant hits less often.

Furthermore, we would like HitPerc, for even fights, to be as high as possible. A higher HitPerc translates into more blows landing, and consequently less damage per blow. The more damage a blow does, the more impact each blow has. Since we don't want a single event to vastly swing the outcome (players like predictability) of fights, this means we want low damage per blow, and therefore, as high a fair-fight HitPerc as we can achieve.

We also want to make sure that HitPerc is always less than 100% for any conceivable fight. Since we have conceptualized a L120 mob (ultimate-group mob), we need to insure that L120 vs. L1 fights yield a hit rate no greater than 100%

Damage Capacity

As we have defined ActDam as the damage that is actually inflicted per round, we can now discuss the DamCap equation. DamCap is simply defined as the amount of damage inflicted by a blow that hits. Algebraically:

DamCap * HitPerc = ActDam

The DamCap term is constant for a given level character. That is, a L10 character will have the same DamCap regardless of whether they are fighting a L5, a L10 or a L100.

  1. DamCap

= Damage capacity of a character

= The average damage per successful blow that hits

= ActDam / HitPerc

Combat Hit Percentage

Returning our attention to HitPerc, we should now have all the necessary information to establish a proper equation.

We rationalize that HitPerc is simply a comparison between the combatants ActOff and ActDef scores. Thus:

  1. HitPercFormab

= Format of HitPerc formula

= (constant) * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

As we want the ratio between two players powers to be the ratio between their survival rounds, the following can be said:

Powerb/Powera = ActHPb * DamCapb * ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActHPa * DamCapa * ActOffa * ActDefa)

And:

SurvRndsb/SurvRndsa = [ActHPb/(DamCapa * HitPercab)] / [ActHPa/(DamCapb * HitPercba)]

Equating the two and canceling common terms:

ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa) = HitPercba / HitPercab

Plugging in from (Equation 30.):

ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa) = (ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa))n / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

Since ActOffa = ActDefa and ActOffb = ActDefb:

ActOffb2 / ActOffa2 = (ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActOffa))n / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActOffb))n

Algebra on the RHS:

ActOffb2 / ActOffa2 = (ActOffb / ActOffa)n * ((ActOffa + ActOffb) / (ActOffb + ActOffa))n

And:

ActOffb2 / ActOffa2 = (ActOffb / ActOffa)n * 1n

Finally:

ActOffb2 / ActOffa2 = (ActOffb / ActOffa)n

Thus we prove that n=2 for the HitPerc equation.

For our worst-case scenario, a L1 vs. L120 fight, we would have ActOff=21.51171 and ActDef=2.613984. We wish the HitPerc to be 1.00 for this situation, hence:

(constant) * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))2 = 1.0

constant = 1.0 / (21.51171/(21.51171+2.613984))2

constant = 1.257795

We'll use a value of constant=1.25 just to insure that there is a slight chance for a miss even in the extreme case.

  1. HitPercab

= Chance of A hitting B

  1. 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))2

The interesting case is for a fair-fight; ActOff=ActDef for both combatants, so we realize that the two combatants are scoring hits:

HitPerc (fair-fight) = 1.25 * (1/2)2

= 1.25/4

= 31.25% of all swings

This also lets us refine DamCap, since we now know both HitPerc and ActDam for a fair-fight:

  1. DamCap

= Refined from (Equation 29.)

= ActDam / HitPercab

= [0.311189 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902]/ 0.3125

  1. 0.9958 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Unfortunately, there is no good way to show all the possible combat scenarios. I've plotted some “interesting test cases” in the forthcoming spreadsheet. Please note that the information is double-line. That is, A hitting B is on line 1; B hitting A is on line 2. The ratio of the survival rounds is plotted, as is the ratio from the power equation. The final column is simply the ratio of the two powers.

  1. Some Combat Scenarios; HitPerc, SurvRnds and the resulting Power

Examining the scenarios, we are able to note some interesting factoids.

First, the range of HitPerc in “skewed” fights is reasonable. The L1/L50 fight reveals a 3.83%/85.08% spread, meaning that at least a few shots will score.

The L10/L50 scenario is interesting as it shows the result of an exploring player wandering into the wrong zone. Such a player has 5 rounds to escape, which is hopefully adequate, albeit scary for the player. Obviously, if the level difference is not as extreme (L20/L50 for example), the player has even more rounds of survival before dying.

More traditional fights, in which the combatants are within 10 levels of each other, show a reasonable spread around 31.25%. Players tend to evaluate HitPerc by counting number of blows that hit over a relatively small number of rounds. Generally, HitPercs within 5% of each other are not discernable to players, so it is good that the HitPerc spread is as it is.

Coming Full Circle with Basic Combat

The Power ratio and SurvRnds ratio are exactly identical. This is of course good, as it is what we intended and it brings us full circle. We established the power equation initially, and from there achieved ActDam, ActHP, ActOff and ActDef. From those, we derived HitPerc, which allowed an accurate prediction of SurvRnds. The SurvRnds equation, when taken as a ratio between combatants, can be thought of as a relationship between the combatant's power values. It is good that the two ratios are the same as it validates all the work that we have performed.

Mob Difficulty and Experience Points

Having adequately modeled the basis of our game design, it is time to move onwards and start to hook other necessary pieces of the MUD into this system. The most logical extension we can make is to start a discussion of the XP system.

A Basic Definition of XP

Recall in the discussions of power, that we are representing power as how advanced a given creature is. Additionally, we have the concept of level denoting discreet milestones along the advancement path. It seems natural that we will need some mechanism for measuring advancement. The term that DIKU MUDs typically apply to this concept is XP.

That is to say, as players fight and defeat various NPCs, they are awarded XP denoting their success. After accumulating sufficient XP, they become eligible for increasingly greater levels. It's a fairly simple and straightforward system, so I won't spend too much time on the basics.

Mob XP Desires

Given the definition of power, it seems fairly reasonable to say that the XP a mob awards is directly related to the mob's power. Let us explore some of our desires for how the XP system should behave…

First, Experience has demonstrated that a mob's XP ought to exceed its HP. This is simply so that if a character does a minimal amount of damage (1HP), it will be sure to receive at least 1XP.

Additionally, XP should not be exceptionally large for any given level mob. Since players will have to kill multiple creatures per level, and that XP is additive over all levels, this translates into players needing HUGE amounts of XP at the higher levels. If we make the XP per mob too large, player's necessary XP to level will be much bigger. Assuming that XP is tracked as an integer, we have some limitations on the scale imposed by the hardware architecture. MaxInt is 232-1 = 4294967295. We can probably expect that a player, over their entire career, will kill 1000s of mobs. We also want to leave a bit of padding to let players continue to kill things after obtaining L50. So we should strive for mobs having on the order of 100000 XP (100K XP) at L50.

Also, we also seek to encourage players to group together to bring down (larger) foes, and simultaneously discourage the efforts of “plowers” (butchering large numbers of greatly inferior foes). That is to say, if two players combine forces, we assume their combined power is simply the sum of their individual power. (An overly simplified assumption! More on this much later.)

If we seek to encourage grouping, then the XP of the mob that they can kill combined should exceed the sum of the XP that they could kill separately. That is to say, if two players can each kill a mob worth 100 XP solo (total gain of 200), then together, we would like them to be able to kill a single mob worth 200+ XP. They gain more by cooperating, and we encourage grouping.

The flip-side argument is that we want to discourage players from plowing. Fighting numerous, wimpy creatures (sequentially) is inherently less risky as a player can always opt to stop the sequence short if they get into trouble. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but we should probably take this risk factor into account and make it so that the XP of a single mob will beat the XP of numerous mobs when Power is kept constant. That is to say, if we determine that 1 L3 = 2 L1 in terms of power, we want L3 XP > 2 * L1 XP. This will encourage players to take on the biggest mob that they feel they can successfully do.

Deriving Mob XP

Let us assume that Mob XP is some function of Power, and takes the form:

  1. MobXPForm

= Format of Mob XP equation

= K (Power)n

Where K is some scaling constant, and n is some exponential power.

Based on the “grouping benefit” that we desire, let us first stipulate that we want XP to be 10% larger at the point where power has doubled. That is, when power has doubled, XP has gone up by a factor of 2.2. Equations then become:

K (power1)n / K (power0)n = XP1 / XP0

(power1)n / (power0)n = XP1 / XP0

(2 * power0)n / (power0)n = (2.2 * XP0) / XP0

2n * power0n / power0n = (2.2 * XP0) / XP0

2n = 2.2

n log(2) = log(2.2)

n = log(2.2) / log(2)

n = 1.1375

Furthermore, we have a desire to keep XP > Power at all points. Since XP is an increasing function of power, we simply need to focus on the lowest power. No character can be less than L0, so the relevant equation is:

L0 power = (01.759815 + 13)2 = 169

Similarly, the lowest possible HP is for a L0, which we calculate as:

L0 HP = (01.759815 + 13)0.635902 * 18.67131

= (13)0.635902 * 18.67131

= 95.39678

Since we want L0 XP to be greater than L0 HP, the following occurs:

L0 XP >= L0 HP

K (L0 power)1.1375 = L0 HP

K ((01.759815 + 13)2)1.1375 = 18.67131 * (01.759815 + 13)0.635902

K ((13)2)1.1375 = (13)0.635902 * 18.67131

K = (13)0.635902 * 18.67131 / (13)2.2750

K = (13)0.635902 * 18.67131 / (13)2.2750

K = 0.27881

The equation becomes:

  1. MobXP

= NPC XP

= K * Powern

= 0.27881 * Power1.1375

= 0.27881 * ((level1.759815 + 13) * (level1.759815 + 13))1.1375

  1. 0.27881 * (level1.759815 + 13)2.2750

  1. Level, ActHP, Power and MobXP

As some basic analysis, we realize that XP exceeds both power and HP at all points. This means that even for the most trivial of damage, a player can always expect to get some XP.

Furthermore, XP does what it is supposed to as power doubles.

Likewise, XP for a L50 mob is 1821083. Let's take a rough guess and say that the player's career (gaining from L1-L50) will require 650 * L50 XP (we'll revisit this assumption in a little while), we get a result of about 1.2 billion XP for the player's career. Our data type can hold a value of 232-1 = 4294967295 (4.3 billion). This yields a spare capacity of roughly 3.1 billion XP, or approximately 1700 mobs of L50, or 50 mobs of L120. It is unlikely that even the most die-hard of players will play their character long enough to kill 1700 L50 creatures after they have maxed to L50. Thus we should not run into any data-overflow problems.

Discouraging Nibblers; XP Rewards for Partial Kills

As a final piece of commentary on the MobXP formula, we have discovered that having XP grow in excess of power has the potential to create a situation where “nibbling” is promoted. Recall, even in extreme combat scenarios (L1 vs. L50 for example), the low level still has a fairly decent (3.83%) chance of hitting the high level. They don't do tremendous damage, and are unlikely to survive very long. However, because the high level target has a great deal of XP, it is possible that the XP they gain from the small amount of damage they are able to do might exceed the XP they would gain fighting more evenly matched opponents. Players that seek to advance this way have become known as nibblers.

Obviously, the gaming system ought to discourage such an obviously flawed strategy.

Since we know that XP grows as Power1.1375, we conclude that XP ought to be awarded at an equivalent rate. That is to say, if I inflict 50% damage on a creature, I should only receive (0.50)1.1375 = 45% of the XP. Obviously, the remaining 55% of the mob's total XP is awarded while damaging the remaining 50% of the mob's HP. Said another way, the amount of XP earned for the first few HPs of damage are not worth as much XP as the XP earned as a mob is about to die. We are in effect back-loading the XP award toward the end of the fight, with the “back-loading” factor (nibbler exponent) being 1.1375.

We must note that 1.1375 as the nibbler-exponent makes nibbling break-even. I will get as much XP using the nibble method, as I would get if killing at my level. This is probably satisfactory, as the risk of leaving a bunch of partially injured, angry mobs around is fairly dangerous, and if there is no XP benefit from doing so, players are unlikely to pursue this method of play.

However, there is no compelling reason not to raise the nibbler-exponent above 1.1375 to further discourage this playing style. Doing so not only means that there is a greater risk from the injured mobs, but also makes the XP reward less that what would be gained by fully killing an evenly matched mob. (There is probably a practical upper limit on how high the nibbler-exponent can go given by the requirement that we want every point of damage to yield 1 XP.) In any event, we will use a value of 1.15 as the nibbler-exponent.

Prelude to the Kills to Level Equation

Having established the amount of XP each mob is worth, the next logical step is to establish how many mobs must be fought for a player to gain each successive level. Obviously, not all mobs are the same; lower level ones are easier. But we have previously stated that we have an expectation that players are fighting mobs of their own level. So what we are really trying to establish is how many mobs, of my own level, must I fight in order to advance to the next highest level. This is inherently subjective. Some generalities can be stated however.

First, the number of kills should probably increase with level. Fewer kills needed as a newbie, but more kills needed later on. This serves to make the game fairly easy for new players, sucking them into the game by tossing them a few easy levels. For the long-term player, it draws out the time commitment needed to advance, making achieving high-level more time consuming.

A problem often encountered by MUDs is that of poor distribution of player levels. Players seem to advance quickly to a given level (few players of these levels), then stall (lots of players in these levels), then finally break out and advance onwards toward max level.

Frequently, the cause of this is that the MUD has poor power management. Mobs vs. PC power is skewed toward the PC during the levels that they rise rapidly, and skewed the other way when players hit the wall. Our game design ought to alleviate problems of this sort.

However, we should be careful with how we define the kills system, as choosing a bad system can cause too rapid a change in the kills for each successive level and also create a system with a bad histogram of player levels. For this reason, we are encouraged to choose some sort of linear function.

Deriving PlayTimePerKill

Lastly, the kills to level is one of the governing equations in determining how long it takes for a player to obtain max level. Most implementers have a gut feeling for how long this ought to take, and for our part, we have settled on 35 days of play (840 hours).

We have already stated that 1 round of combat will take roughly 2.5 seconds. Additionally, we can assume (arbitrary) that every round spent fighting also requires 1.5 to 2.0 rounds of recuperation. Furthermore, players will often socialize (wasted time), and setbacks (death, XP loss, etc.) will also occur. As a rule of thumb, we have found that for every round spent fighting, 9 rounds are spent in other activity. This results in

  1. SimpPlayTimePerKill

= Simplified time spent achieving each successive kill (rule of thumb)

= SurvRnds * 10 * 2.5 secs/round

= SurvRnds * 25 secs/round

The SurvRnds formula is fairly complex, so I won't confuse the discussion by rewriting it here.

Realize that players are quite capable of gaining XP at a faster rate than what this suggests, and that what this attempts to capture is the long-term view of playtime. Players will not just monotonously kill and recuperate, but will inevitably also socialize, explore and do other activities. Similarly, they will probably die, losing XP, and be forced to recover. This leads to the 25 seconds/round rule-of-thumb for gaining insight into the long-term view of playtime per kill.

Newbies are more likely to maintain the kill/recuperate cycle exclusively rather than get sidetracked socializing. We roughly estimate that newbies only require 10 secs/round, thus we can refine (Equation 35.) and state:

  1. PlayTimePerKill

= Time spent achieving each successive kill (rule of thumb)

= Refined from (Equation 35.)

= SurvRnds * min(25, level + 9) seconds/round

Deriving Kills Per Level

Given what we stated previously about KillsPerLevel, we can model this equation as:

  1. KillsPerLevelForm

= K (level) + C

Where K and C are scaling constants.

If we restrict our view to newbie levels, we can establish the value for C. We know each fair-fight kill takes 60 rounds. Further, newbies tend to do the kill/recuperate cycle so we are fairly safe in saying a newbies PlayTimePerKill is only 10 seconds/round. We would like a newbie to be able to gain level 2 with less than an hour of playtime (40 minutes = 2400 seconds). At 10 seconds/round and 60 rounds/kill, we get a value of 600 seconds/kill. Thus, we establish that we want 4 kills for a newbie to advance. The value of C is 4.

We are then left with only one unknown (K). We combine this with the PlayTimePerKill formula, and strive to get the sum, over all 50 levels, to yield the 840 hours of playtime desired. The resulting value was K=1.53548.

(Note: Solving this equation exactly gets rather complex and does not add anything to our understanding. It was simpler for me to spreadsheet (not provided) it and use trial & error to get the final answer above.)

Hence:

  1. KillsPerLevel

= Kills per Level

= number of mobs of my own level I must kill to gain next level

  1. 1.53548 * (level) + 4

  1. PlayTime as a Function of Level and KillsPerLevel

Deriving the XP Tables

The XP required for each successive level can be gotten from summing KillsPerLevel * MobXP for all levels.

  1. XPForLevel and KillsPerLevel versus level

Since players will inevitably want nice, round numbers for the XP for level numbers, we should probably round some of these values up and present them in a reasonably acceptable format. Rounding up the XPForLevel technically alters the KillsPerLevel equation, but since KillsPerLevel was created fairly arbitrarily, we are fairly safe in doing this. We add in slight deviations from our theoretical plot, but we wind up with a nice round 1.2 billion XP to level 50.

Introducing Armor into Our System

As we continue to advance our game design, it is worthwhile to note that we remain somewhat rooted in a theoretical realm, isolated from the concepts and themes with which implementers deal with on a day to day basis. We have a number of nice, fuzzy equations, but if there are no good ways to implement them, they are fairly moot. Let us begin to worry about practical implementation.

Avoiding the Pitfalls of AD&D

Amazingly enough, the RPG that gets most people interested in MUDding in the first place is, in fact, poorly suited to running a MUD. As AD&D aficionados know, AD&D deals with things like AC, tohit modifiers, todam modifiers and the like. Obviously, these concepts were added to AD&D in order to allow the AD&D system to model things using the semi-convoluted system of dice that is its trademark.

As RPGs moved away from paper, pencil and dice toward the computer, many of these terms remained intact and implementers are loathe inventing their own system, so they piggyback on what went before. Unfortunately, many of these systems are ill suited to the realm of bits and bytes because they add needless confusion. This will become even truer as AD&D is relegated to the ash-heap of history and younger players with no concept of E. Gary Gygax, and co. come onto the scene.

For the most part, we should design our MUD to use intuitive and natural frameworks. If players think in terms of “this helm is good for a L10”, then we should be thinking in terms of level-based armor. Too often, however, MUDs continue to hold onto concepts like “AC”. This forces players to do bizarre contortions of trying to determine what AC they want on their helm for their L10 PC. This is senseless; new players to the MUD have enough things to sort out without adding additional concepts that aren't intuitive.

As we develop systems, we should strive to maintain an intuitive interface for players. Likewise, that same interface should be provided to builders to streamline the building process. If we are going to maintain “armor” or “AC” under the hood, that's OK, but it should be an implementation detail that is not exposed except in rare circumstances.

Please do not confuse this as an argument for “vague terms”. I am not insisting that raw numbers be concealed behind fuzzy phrasing (“Your helm is very buff.”) as that is a matter of personal choice not predicated on anything related to Game-Design. I am simply encouraging that the system uses something like: “The helm is good for a L10.” rather than “The helm has 65 points of armor”. The former phrasing is completely understandable to any player, while the latter forces players to perform a WTF as they try to understand what a point of armor is, how many they need, and whether this helm has the appropriate amount for their level or not. Confused players are unhappy players.

A Prelude to Armor Implementation

With all that said, it's time to do exactly what I just encouraged you not to do and devise an “armor” system. This armor system is necessary for reasonable implementation. Provided we conceal the armor system under the façade of the intuitive interface, we avoid hypocrisy. We will use an armor system behind the scenes, and display a level-based interface to players and builders. A builder will create a helm with “L10 armor”, and we will let the mud determine what that means in terms of our internal armor system.

We have previously determined an equation for ActDef=(level1.759815 + 13)0.364098. Also recall that this term encapsulates the amount of armor a character has, as well as other things (position, skill, etc.) that contribute to “defense”. Therefore, we must break ActDef into two component pieces, SimpArmor and SimpDefSkill. The two together will combine to create ActDef.

Likewise, on the offensive side we have ActOff=(level1.759815 + 13)0.364098, which is also composed of things like position, skill, etc. For the sake of symmetry, we should create two component pieces. The first, SimpOffSkill, counterbalances SimpDefSkill, while the second, SimpFinesse, will counterbalance SimpArmor.

It should not be a major leap of intuition that certain relational concepts, like position should be taken outside the actOff/actDef system. For instance, we will presume that both combatants are standing, on even-terrain with no prevailing hindrances to either party for the sake of the remainder of this discussion. If in fact, one combatant is prone, or uphill of the other, or etc., this should be modeled as a bonus/penalty above and beyond the standard ActOff/ActDef system. Hence, we take these items out of the discussion for the time being.

A Basic Overview of Combat Dynamics

To model reality, we would expect that a given combat swing might result in:

1) An outright miss.

2) The defender dodging the swing.

3) The blow being parried by the defender.

4) The blow landing, but in such a fashion that it is essentially deflected.

5) The blow landing, but the armor partially absorbs the energy.

6) The blow landing without absorption.

The ActOff and ActDef values will dictate the size of these bins, as expressed as a percentage of all swings.

Using the terms already discussed, we will utilize the SimpOffSkill and SimpDefSkill to determine if the blow lands, or if the intended victim is able to escape on skill alone.

Likewise, once we have determined that the blow has landed, it will be up to SimpFinesse and SimpArmor to determine how well the blow hits and what affect it will have on the victim.

Since we have previously made actOff and actDef come out numerically equivalent, and we have parity between a component piece in one and a component piece in the other, it seems fairly reasonable to expect numerical equivalency between SimpFinesse/SimpArmor and SimpOffSkill/SimpDefSkill. We have an arbitrary desire to weigh the importance of equipment higher than that of skill; hence we do the following:

  1. SimpFinesse

= Simplified Finesse component of ActOff

= (ActOff)0.45

= (((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098)0.45

  1. (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

  1. SimpOffSkill

= Simplified offensive skill component of ActOff

= (ActOff)0.55

= (((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098)0.55

  1. (level1.759815 + 13)0.200254

Similarly,

  1. SimpArmor

= Simplified armor component of ActDef

= (ActDef)0.45

= (((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098)0.45

  1. (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

  1. SimpDefSkill

= Simplified defensive skill component of ActDef

= (ActDef)0.55

= (((level)1.759815 + 13)0.364098)0.55

  1. (level1.759815 + 13)0.200254

Remember that, like ActOff and ActDef, these values are simply raw numbers. We are still free to throw a constant scaling multiplier into the mix, provided we do so to both sides of the equation.

  1. SimpFinesse, SimpOffSkill, SimpArmor and SimpDefSkill as Functions of Level

A Brief Dissertation on the Meaning of (Spreadsheet 9.)

Analyzing the table data is still fairly difficult because the quantities have yet to really be associated with real concepts. However, we are able to note a few things.

If we compare the L50 values to their L1 values, we can get a feel for how much of an improvement occurs over the course of the player's career.

For instance, SimpArmor goes from 1.541 up to 3.096. This is a 100% improvement and implies that high-level armor is 2X more armor than the newbie variety.

Divvying up SimpArmor

On the scale thus far, SimpArmor proceeds from 1.540942 at L1 to 3.096089 at L50. We have a desire to 1) use an integer scale, 2) have enough points to spread a chunk around to each level, and 3) have enough points per level to spread points out to each piece of armor a player might wear.

As such, we choose to multiply SimpArmor by 10000 in order to provide the fine resolution we need. Consequently, the multiplier for SimpFinesse is also 10000. We will call these newly scaled terms ActArmor and ActFinesse.

  1. ActFinesse

= Actual Finesse component of ActOff

= 10000 * SimpFinesse

= 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

  1. ActArmor

= Actual armor component of ActDef

= 10000 * SimpArmor

  1. 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

Analysis of (Spreadsheet 9.) indicates that doing this yields 402 new points of armor between L1 and L2, and 177 new points of armor between L49 and L50. Since there are 18 places for armor to be worn, this means that each new level will result in at least a few extra points of armor being accumulated on every piece.

A Suit of Armor

A complete set of armor consists of:

1.) Head piece

2.) Neck piece

3.) Body armor

4.) Shield

5.) Back armor

6.) Arm piece - left

7.) Arm piece - right

8.) Wrist piece - left

9.) Wrist piece - right

10.) Glove - left

11.) Glove - right

12.) Ring - left

13.) Ring - right

14.) Waist Piece

15.) Legging - left

16.) Legging - right

17.) Boot - left

18.) Boot - right

Each piece in the suit ought to represent some fraction of the total AC for the suit. These fractions are fairly arbitrarily assigned, but they are constrained by some realistic limits.

  1. Percent of ActArmor Found on Any Given Equipment Slot

The above numbers were chosen totally arbitrarily.

Note that we don't assign any armor to the shield. We'll come back to how a shield should be handled in a bit, but for the time being recognize that it is not a piece of equipment that possesses an “armor” rating.

  1. Equipment Armor by Level and Equipment Slot

Clothing and Other Worn Equipment

While there is a great demand in a fantasy RPG for equipment that can be classified as armor, we also have to realize that many items of clothing are not manufactured with combat in mind. In fact, from a realistic point-of-view, most items would be made of simple cloth and designed for everyday use rather than the harsh conditions that adventurers are likely to subject them to.

Furthermore, certain classes, developed further on, will clearly be viewed as not being fully decked out in gleaming metal. The archetypical magician in a fantasy setting usually wears nothing more than simple robes.

Therefore, the concept of clothing comes into being. Clothing will be defined as being another type of worn equipment, but which was built with little or no regard for a combat setting. Clothing is, by its nature, also less encumbering.

Since some classes will be required to wear clothing (partially or completely), and we recognize that player's will also want to enhance their equipment as they progress, clothing will also need to have a level associated with it. Also, while clothing is certainly no equivalent of armor, it does provide some protection over being naked.

We will arbitrarily state that clothing offers 50% the ActArmor of actual armor for a given level. That is to say, if my character were completely outfitted in clothing, I would have an armor rating half that as if I was wearing equivalent level armor. Therefore:

  1. ActArmCloth

= Armor value while wearing clothing

= 0.5 * ActArmor

= 0.5 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

  1. 5000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

The armor-value will break down in the same fashion as it does for actual armor.

  1. Clothing Armor by Level and Equipment Slot

It is an interesting side effect that L50 clothing is about equivalent to L1 armor. That is to say, the finest clothing is able to protect you as well as the shoddiest armor. This may strike some people as wrong, but realize the clothing also affords greater mobility and fewer encumbrances. Also, since players are not exposed to the internal numbers, it is unlikely that they will realize this fact.

Some Simple Refinements of Combat Blows

Recall from our overview earlier, that every given combat swing results in one of six outcomes. They are; miss, dodge, parry, deflection, absorbed hit, and full hit. It is now useful to explore how we might calculate which outcome a given blow falls into.

We have previously established the HitPercFormab equation, which in broad terms yields the percentage of hits that are either absorbed hits, or full hits. We can rewrite this equation in terms of our new symbols as:

  1. HitPercab

= Refined from (Equation 31.)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))2

  1. 1.25 * ((ActFinesse * SimpOffSkill)a / ((ActFinesse * SimpOffSkill)a + (ActArmor * SimpDefSkill)b))2

The RawMiss chance is simply the opposite of HitPercab.

  1. RawMiss

= Chance a given blow results in a miss, dodge or deflection.

  1. 1.00 - HitPercab

Parrying

While seemingly counter-intuitive, we should begin our analysis with parrying. Arguably, parrying is a special case for a combat blow. Clearly, a parried blow hasn't hit, but neither has it really missed either. Similarly, there is a “cost” to the intended-target in order to parry the blow.

Let us first define what we mean by “parry”. For the purposes of this discussion, a parry will include any blow that is stopped because of the actions of the victim to block it. This includes both shield-use, as well as the use of a second weapon used defensively.

Recalling that we have previously determined HitPercab to be 31.25% for fair fights. Instinctually, this value seems a bit low. We would clearly like a figure closer to 50%. At the same time, we theorize that in a fight, roughly one blow in three is parry-eligible.
