Clearly, I can only block a blow that I am able to get my shield in the way of, and instinct indicates that this is about 1/3 of all blows.

Fortunately, the two ideas dovetail nicely. Let us presume that HitPercab is in fact 46.875% for a fair fight. Of these blows, one in three (or 15.625%) is eligible to be parried. Assuming all ParryEligible blows are actually parried, we are left with 31.25% of blows scoring a hit.

Unfortunately, this generates a problem for us. In the above fair-fight scenario, ParryEligible blows amount to half of HitPercab. In certain extreme combat situations, HitPercab will approach 100%. Clearly, ParryEligible cannot account for an additional ␀*HitPercab in such a case, as we would need more than 100% of the blows to do so.

However, what is not immediately intuitive is that we do not want to simply scale HitPercab up, but that we want to take a percentage of the RawMiss chances, and assign them to parrying. Remembering that HitPercab, for extreme scenarios, might be 90% or more, if we were to take a naïve approach and make parrying be ␀ the value of HitPercab, we would wind up with > 100%. This is obviously not possible.

Taking the reverse approach, the fair-fight RawMiss chance is 68.75%. Since we want 15.625% to come from parrying, this is equivalent to wanting 5/22 or 22.73% of the RawMiss chances to come from parrying. We can use this fraction regardless of the actual RawMiss value.

  1. ParryEligible

= Number of all blows that are eligible to be parried

  1. 5/22 * RawMiss

And we probably want a term to describe the number of misses with parries factored out:

  1. AdjustedMiss

= Percentage of all blows that are neither hits nor parries.

= 17/22 * RawMiss

We will discuss parrying further in depth later, but for the time being, let us simply leave things as they are.

Scenarios Involving a Miss

Let us explore the “miss” outcomes. It's important to realize that for all the “miss” scenarios, it really doesn't matter (in the grand scheme of things) how a blow misses. A decent model of all the possible types of misses permits us to make combat more vibrant and dynamic, but strictly speaking, a miss is a miss. Theoretically, we are pretty much free to divvy up the misses any way we see fit. But let's try and create something reasonable nonetheless.

First and foremost, a swing has to get reasonably close to the intended victim. Inexperienced combatants (i.e. low-level) should have great difficulty getting their weapon to perform as desired, and thus we would expect that a pure miss is the vast majority of the swings that are AdjustedMiss.

Obviously, the number of TrueMiss swings is some fraction of the AdjustedMiss blows. We'll use a weighted-average, similar to that in TrueMiss, to determine the percentage. At the same time, we realize that the defender's skill level plays no part, so we leave it out, and use an arbitrary constant of 1.0 (any value less than L0 SimpDefSkill should be fine) in its place:

  1. TrueMiss

= Percentage of all swings that result in a missed blow.

= [1.00 - 1.1 * ((ActFinesse * SimpOffSkill)a / ((ActFinesse * SimpOffSkill)a + (ActArmor * 1.00)b))2] * AdjustedMiss

The next option for a swing, is that the swing gets reasonably close to the target, but that the target is able to side-step or otherwise avoid the blow. I choose to model TrueDodge, the number of all swings that can be dodged, as being a percentage of the remaining “missed” swings. I use only the SimpOffSkill and SimpDefSkill to calculate the percentage, and furthermore, I use a form that is reasonably symmetrical with that which we used in the HitPerc formula. However, I've changed the multiplier (to 2.5) simply to make the numbers come out “prettier”.

  1. TrueDodge

= Percentage of all swings that result in a blow that can be dodged

= 2.5 * (SimpOffSkilla / (SimpOffSkilla + SimpDefSkillb))2 * (AdjustedMiss - TrueMiss)

Lastly, the swing can be exceptionally well swung, but the defender is crafty or agile enough to cause the blow to deflect harmlessly. Realistically, a defender might raise an arm and cause the swing to graze along the surface, deflecting it away from hitting. Clearly, this requires high SimpDefSkill to do. Likewise, as my ActArmor rating improves, I will feel more secure about using an arm to block a shot. I won't bother to write out the fully derived form for TrueDeflect, simply because it is easier to regard it as the remainder of all “misses”. That is:

  1. TrueDeflect

= Percentage of all swings that result in a blow that can be deflected

= RawMiss-TrueMiss-TrueDodge

  1. ParryEligible, TrueMiss, TrueDodge and TrueDeflect for Fair-Fights by Level

Examining TrueMiss, as we would expect, it declines as the player advances. My accuracy improves, and I am able to get a greater percentage of blows closer to the enemy.

At the same time, greater experience permits the character to dodge and deflect more blows.

Data for fights between dissimilar fights will be presented after the next section.

Scenarios Involving a Hit

As with the “miss” scenarios, a blow that lands has numerous outcomes as well. We do, however, have an additional constraint, as we are bound by the ActDam equation.

We conceptualize three varieties of hits; a normal hit, a serious hit, and a partial hit.

The vast majority of hits should fall into the normal category. A serious hit represents the use of finesse to find a weak spot in the opponent's defense, and exploit it. Serious hits inflict 50% more damage than normal. Conversely, a partial hit represents a hit that is inferior, and does only 50% the normal damage.

Clearly, serious hits ought to be governed by ActFinesse and ActArmor. We'll simply use the same format that has worked so well up to now, and simply change the multiplier in order to scale the percentage properly:

  1. TrueSeriousHit

= Percentage of all swings that result in a serious hit

= 0.2 * (ActFinesse/(ActFinesse + ActArmor))2 * HitPercab

Further refinement is possible, but doesn't significantly simplify understanding or clarity.

Given our constraint dealing with DamCap, we can devise some simple algebra:

TrueSeriousHit * (1.5 * DamCap) + TrueNormalHit * (1.0 * DamCap) + TruePartialHit * (0.5 * DamCap) = ActDam

Rewriting ActDam in terms of DamCap, and factoring out DamCap:

TrueSeriousHit * 1.5 + TrueNormalHit * 1.0 + TruePartialHit * 0.5 = HitPercab

The three TrueXXXHit terms must sum to HitPercab, so we can rewrite things as:

TrueSeriousHit * 1.5 + TrueNormalHit * 1.0 + (HitPercab - TrueNormalHit - TrueSeriousHit) * 0.5 = HitPercab

Simplifying:

TrueSeriousHit + TrueNormalHit * 0.5 = HitPercab * 0.5

Solving for TrueNormalHit:

  1. TrueNormalHit

= Percentage of all swings that result in a normal hit

= HitPercab - 2 * TrueSeriousHit

Insert standard disclaimer about it being possible to refine this equation further, but yada yada.

And of course, we'll also state formally something we said earlier:

  1. TruePartialHit

= Percentage of all swings that result in a partial hit

= HitPercab - TrueSeriousHit - TrueNormalHit

  1. TrueSeriousHit, TrueNormalHit and TruePartialHit for Fair-Fights by Level

Clearly, for fair-fights, the “hits” breakdown is independent of level.

Blow Breakdown for Dissimilar Level Combatants

Displaying data for non-fair-fights has the traditional problems. Again, I'll simply reveal some scenarios to give a rough feel for the numbers.

  1. Some Combat Scenarios; Hit and Miss Breakdown

Analysis of the non-equal level combatant's information reveals some interesting results.

First, the higher level not only hits more often overall (HitPerc), but also achieves more hits of each type (normal, serious, and partial). Obviously, no player will complain about extra normal and serious hits, but may raise an eyebrow about getting more partial hits. However, a hit of any type is better than a miss, and even if it only does half damage, that is still some benefit to the hitter.

Secondly, even in fights between dissimilar levels, the bulk of hits are normal, with an even split between serious and partial hits. OK, so we knew that this would happen from how the math worked out, but it still gives us a warm-fuzzy all over since that seems like the way we want it to be.

Thirdly, more blows from the lower-level character are eligible to be parried. Clearly, this is what we would expect, as the higher skill should permit more blows to be blocked.

For the misses scenarios, we note that the lower-level character always has more TrueMisses than the higher-level character. We rationalize that swinging really bad is something that is based on inexperience, thus higher-level characters ought to do it less often.

However, we note that as a percentage of all blow, the lower level frequently deflects and dodges more swings. This seems counter-intuitive. Shouldn't the higher-level character dodge and deflect better? Obviously, the answer is yes. But what we realize is that the lower player swings so ineffectively, that more blows are simply going wide of the mark. The higher-level character simply has fewer blows that NEED to be dodged or deflected swung at them.

(Note: OK, this last remark is somewhat a rationalization. However, I did spend much time actually trying to get higher-levels to dodge/deflect more than lower-levels. The only way to do it is to make dodge/deflect be fixed percentages of all misses. This means that we would have to ignore the effects of skill, etc. I feel that skill should play a part, and I think the rationalization is defensible, so the system is constructed that way.)

Skill Damage

Up to this point, we have largely concerned ourselves with only the melee-portion of combat. That is, swinging a weapon, determining if it hits, how well it hits, and what the impact of the hit is on the victim. While melee is the focal point of combat, it is not the only option available to the player.

Clearly, a character can perform other actions while still swinging the weapon. For example, kicking, bashing, pushing, punching, etc. all come to mind. These extra options are generally lumped under the heading of skills, and they form an important component of a well-developed MUD. As such, it is imperative that the game-design account for skills in the overall design philosophy.

I should also point out, I am using “skill-use” in a generic sense. It should be thought to include not just regular skills (kick, bash, backstab, etc.) but also things like spells, prayers and the other various forms of magic.

Having completed our development for basic melee combat, it now makes sense to turn our attention to skills, and in particular skill-related damage.

A Prelude to Skill Damage

From previous discussions, we established a numerical value for ActDam, indicating the total damage we wanted to be inflicted per combat round in order to maintain what we desired for SurvRnds. From there, we went on to derive DamCap.

Clearly, we don't want to alter what we have said about SurvRnds. However, we need to shoehorn the new concept of skills into what we have developed to date. Fortunately, this is fairly easy to do. We simply need to take a small piece away from DamCap and assign it to “skill damage”. It's probably easiest to understand if we remember what the relationships between the pieces are:

Imaging that we split DamCap up into two pieces, SimpSkillDamage and WeaponDamage such that:

DamCap = SimpSkillDamage + WeaponDamage

That is to say, DamCap is the sum of two pieces; a term based on equipment, and a term based on skill.

We are left with the simple question of how much damage we wish to come from melee (WeaponDamage) and how much from skill-use (SimpSkillDamage). I choose to make SimpSkillDamage = 1/3 WeaponDamage. Since most skills will require 3 rounds to perform, this basically says that each time a skill is performed; it is like getting an extra round of combat.

Rather trivial algebra yields:

DamCap = WeaponDamage + SimpSkillDamage

DamCap = (3 * SimpSkillDamage) + SimpSkillDamage

DamCap = 4 * SimpSkillDamage

  1. SimpSkillDamage

= DamPerRnd due to skill use

= DamCap / 4

= 0.9958 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902 / 4

  1. 0.24895 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

  1. SimpWeaponDamage

= DamPerRnd due to weapon use

= 3 * SimpSkillDamage

= 3 * 0.24895 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

  1. 0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

  1. WeaponDamage and SimpSkillDamage as a Function of Level

As we can see, SimpSkillDamage is incremental everywhere. Players expect that as they rise in level, they will do more damage with their skills, and this bears that out well.

Also, L50 SimpSkillDamage is only 20.0. Since this is the per-round amount, and we presume that most skills will require 3 rounds to perform, this means that a single skill-use from a L50 will do 60.0 damage. This is not quite enough to kill a L1 player outright (HP=100). Nobody lies to die instantly, so it's probably a good thing that this is the case.

Saving Throws

It is important to realize that SimpSkillDamage is based upon DamCap that is partially predicated on the value of HitPercab. The ramification of this is that the damage that we have calculated presumes a hit-rate equivalent to HitPercab. Clearly, skill-usage is also going to require some probability of success and failure.

For skills that involve physical attacks, we can rationalize these failures similar to how HitPercab works. Failures simply mean that the attacker missed widely, or that the victim was able to somehow deflect or disrupt the skill from succeeding.

In the case of magic, we lack an obvious frame of reference of how to rationalize failure. For the most part, we'll avoid coming up with a reason for the failure, and simply state that the game system requires that failure be possible.

Skill failure, whether it be a true skill, or some form of magic, we will lump into the concept of saving throw. That is to say, if the victim “makes a save”, the skill essentially fails.

We must realize that SimpSkillDamage is based on a success rate for skills equivalent to HitPercab. Unfortunately, in the equal-level fight thought to be the norm, HitPercab yields a success of 31.25%. This is acceptable for melee blows, because there are a large number of them reasonably often. But since skills will most likely take 3 rounds to perform, this translates to 1 skill every 7.5-9.0 seconds. I believe players would find it highly objectionable to get one successful skill every 28.8 seconds (9 seconds/use with 31.25% success rate).

Therefore, we will stipulate that SkillPerc, the success rate for skills, will be twice that of HitPercab. That is, for a fair fight, SkillPerc will be on the order of 62.5%, which is much more acceptable.

Since we are doubling the success rate of skills, the only way to maintain the amount of damage we want to inflict on average is to decrease the per-successful-skill-use amount by ␀.

Equations for these concepts will be forthcoming. However, let's explore some obvious ramifications first.

Since SkillPerc is double that of HitPercab, it will have similar performance as HitPercab for fights between greatly dissimilar levels. That is, skills of the higher-level player will success much more often, while the higher-level player will also save much more often against the skills of the lower-level player. This is exactly as we would desire.

Additionally, since HitPercab is designed to yield values between 0% and 100%. By doubling it for SkillPerc, under certain circumstances, we will have > 100% which isn't really practical in the real world. To avoid this conundrum, and achieve the proper average damage desired, we would have to state that if SkillPerc is > 100%, SkillDamage will be appropriately increased. That is, if we had SkillPerc of 140% for a damage of 10, we would reduce SkillPerc to 100%, and multiply damage by 140% for a total of 14 instead. Another way to say this is, for a scenario in which the combatant levels are very far apart, the high-level character will not only have guaranteed success (100%), but will also do greater than normal damage.

There are a few other main concepts when discussing how SkillPerc should perform.

SkillDifficulty and MaxSkillPerc

First, some skills are easier to perform than others are. Clearly, skills that are easier to perform ought to succeed more often than more difficult skills (assuming equal learning in both skills).

To model this, we'll introduce the concept of SkillDifficulty. I have also assigned some arbitrary maximum success rates (MaxSkillPerc) to these classifications as follows:

  1. MaxSkillPerc

= The maximum rate of success for a given skill

= A function of the SkillDifficulty

  1. SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab

Trivial: 100% * 2 * HitPercab

Easy: 90% * 2 * HitPercab

Normal: 80% * 2 * HitPercab

Difficult: 70% * 2 * HitPercab

Dangerous: 60% * 2 * HitPercab

Thus, in a fair-fight where the HitPercab rate is 31.25%, an “easy” skill would succeed 56.25% (31.25% * 2 * 90%) of the time.

The percentages that distinguish the above SkillDifficulties in the above formula will be called the SkillDifficultyFactor. The SkillDifficultyFactor for normal skills is 80%.

We should note that the determination of SkillDifficulty for a given skill is entirely arbitrary. There is nothing (except common sense) that prevents us from saying kick is dangerous, while casting maelstorm is trivial.

SkillLearning

Secondly, skills are learned through practice, so we have an inherent rating for how well learned the skill is. Likewise, as learning is gained in a skill, the success rate is expected to improve.

It is probably simplest to model SkillLearning as a value from 0% to 100% indicating how well learned the skill is. By extension, we'll stipulate that SkillPerc is simply the maximum value from SkillDifficulty multiplied by the SkillLearning percentage:

  1. SkillPerc

= Success rate for a skill

= MaxSkillPerc * SkillLearning

  1. (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab) * SkillLearning

Trivial: 100% * 2 * HitPercab * SkillLearning

Easy: 90% * 2 * HitPercab * SkillLearning

Normal: 80% * 2 * HitPercab * SkillLearning

Difficult: 70% * 2 * HitPercab * SkillLearning

Dangerous: 60% * 2 * HitPercab * SkillLearning

For example, a difficult skill that is quarter-learned (25%) would have a SkillPerc of 35% (70% * 2 * 25%) * HitPercab. In a fair-fight, the effective success rate would be 10.94% (31.25% * 35%).

MinSkillLevel and MaxSkillLevel

Thirdly, skills have an intrinsic “level” to them indicating whether they are learned early in a character's career, or later on. Obviously, we don't want L50 players continuing to use skills they acquired at L1, but instead, want them to trade up to something bigger and cooler.

We will have to postpone a calculation for SkillLevel until after a more thorough look at how learning occurs. Suffice to say, we can use some knowledge about how learning will occur to mimic a “level”, which hopefully agrees fairly well with the player's actual level, and this SkillLevel will be plugged into the relevant equation for damage and SkillPerc.

I mention this now as it is an important and basic concept for skills and this is the most practical place to introduce it. We will come back to this point and talk about it more in depth later though.

Refinement of SimpSkillDamage

It should be pretty obvious that if we want our numbers to come out properly, we will have to achieve:

SkillPerc * SkillDamage = HitPercab * SimpSkillDamage

Or rewriting:

SkillDamage = SimpSkillDamage * HitPercab / SkillPerc

SkillDamage = SimpSkillDamage * HitPercab / ((SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab) * SkillLearning)

SkillDamage = SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor*2*SkillLearning)

As we can see, this term factors in SkillLearning. This would imply that a low degree of SkillLearning would yield higher SkillDamage. This would make absolutely no sense. Obviously we don't want damage-per-success to decrease as a person becomes more learned about the skill.

To avoid such a problem, we'll instead say that:

  1. SkillDamage

= Damage inflicted (per round) by a skill

= SimpSkillDamage * HitPercab / MaxSkillPerc

= SimpSkillDamage * HitPercab / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab)

  1. SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2)

  1. SkillDamage for SkillDifficulty Ratings by Level (fair-fights)

As we can see, the higher the SkillDifficulty, the more damage is done by a skill of a given level. This is obviously desirable, as otherwise there is no reason to use skills that have a chance of failure.

Knowing that the above values are a per-round amount, we also note that a 3-round, L50, dangerous skill does roughly 50 HP of damage. This would not be enough to kill a L1 outright so our desire to avoid instant-death should be roughly intact.

However, there is a potential problem at low level. Obviously, every skill that succeeds needs to do at least 1 damage. Since some of the amounts for L1-L4 are greater than 1.0, we could possibly have a problem. Fortunately, the above values are per-round, and if we make all skills take at least 2 rounds, there will be no problems.

Ramifications of SkillDamage

Realize that what we have said is SkillDamage is based on the skill being fully learned. If a player is in the process of training the skill, their rate of success will be less than MaxSkillPerc, and accordingly, only receive some fraction of the SimpSkillDamage that is intended for them to be inflicting. By not doing the appropriate SimpSkillDamage, they are effectively taking a penalty in their ActDam, which is the same thing as reducing their overall Power. While this is an undeniable truth, a number of factors allow us to justify not worrying about it too much.

First, since we are expecting primarily fair-fights to occur, the impact is probably equal for both combatants. That is, the fact that I am using a skill that is not fully learned is counterbalanced by the fact that my opponent is probably equally handicapped by their skills as well.

Secondly, from experience, players tend to rely on their best skill that is the most learned. Players usually “train” against inferior opponents where the odds are overwhelmingly in their favor. Hence, for the most part, this penalty will only come into play when the fight's outcome is not in doubt.

Thirdly, the damage of the skill is largely based on the SkillLevel, which we presume is the theoretical level when the skill is fully maxed. Presumably, while they are training the skill, their actual level is somewhat lower than this theoretical SkillLevel. Therefore, they are theoretically inflicting the SkillDamage of a somewhat higher-level person, but doing so less often.

For these reasons, I feel that we can justify ignoring the potential decrease in ActDam from using a non-maxed skill.

Converting SkillDamage to Other Hindrances

While many skills are straightforward “do damage to enemy” skills, there are other broad classifications of skills that hinder the enemy, either reducing the amount of attacks the enemy gets, or preventing the enemy from being able to use its own skills. For example, the standard “bash” skill is typically conceived as knocking the player over and disrupting their skills. Meanwhile, “grapple” generally entraps the enemy and prevents them from hitting back. It would be useful to explore how to convert what we know about SkillDamage to model this arrangement.

Knowing SimpWeaponDamage and HitPercab, we can represent the amount of damage a character is expected to inflict from melee damage alone as:

  1. AvgDamMelee

= Average, per-round, damage from melee combat

  1. SimpWeaponDamage * HitPercab

An equivalent equation for skills becomes:

  1. AvgDamSkill

= Average, per-round, damage from skills

  1. SkillDamage * SkillPerc

Our basic question is that if I successfully perform a skill that should do SkillDamage amount of damage, how many rounds of combat is this worth. That is, the number of rounds I ought to lose should be:

  1. MeleeRoundsLostSkill

= Number of Rounds of melee combat lost from skill

= SkillDamage / AvgDamMelee

= (SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2)) / (SimpWeaponDamage * HitPercab)

= (SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2)) / ((3 * SimpSkillDamage) * HitPercab)

= SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 6 * SimpSkillDamage * HitPercab)

= 1 / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 6 * HitPercab)

= 1/3 * 1/MaxSkillPerc

Obviously, the number of rounds of melee lost should not be dependant on the level difference between the combatants, so we will use the fair-fight value for HitPercab (31.25% = 5/16).

= 1 / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 6 * 5/16)

  1. 8/15 * 1/SkillDifficultyFactor

If we wanted to go one step further and say the skill causes both melee and skill to be lost, then:

  1. FullRoundsLostSkill

= Number of Rounds of melee and skill combat lost from skill

= SkillDamage / (ActDam)

= SkillDamage / (AvgDamMelee + AvgDamSkill)

= (SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2)) / ((SimpWeaponDamage * HitPercab) + (SkillDamage * SkillPerc))

= (SimpSkillDamage) / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor) * ((SimpWeaponDamage * HitPercab) + (SkillDamage * SkillPerc)))

= (SimpSkillDamage) / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor) * (((3 * SimpSkillDamage) * HitPercab) + ((SimpSkillDamage / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2)) * ((SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab) * SkillLearning))))

= 1 / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor * HitPercab) * (3 + ((1/(SkillDifficultyFactor*2)) * ((SkillDifficultyFactor * 2) * SkillLearning))))

= 1 / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor * HitPercab) * (3 + SkillLearning))

We'll presume fully maxed, so that SkillLearning=1.00:

= 1 / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor * HitPercab) * (3 + 1.00))

= 1 / ((2 * SkillDifficultyFactor * HitPercab) * 4)

= 1 / (8 * SkillDifficultyFactor * HitPercab)

= 1/4 * 1/MaxSkillPerc

And again using the fair-fight argument as above:

= 1 / (8 * SkillDifficultyFactor * 5/16)

  1. 2/5 * 1/SkillDifficultyFactor)

To determine the number of rounds of skills I should lose:

  1. SkillRoundsLostSkill

= Number of Rounds of skill combat lost from skill

= SkillDamage / AvgDamSkill

= SkillDamage / (SkillDamage * SkillPerc)

= 1 / SkillPerc

= 1 / ((SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * HitPercab) * SkillLearning)

Again we will assume full learning (SkillLearning=1.00) and make the fair-fight argument (HitPercab=5/16):

= 1 / (SkillDifficultyFactor * 2 * 5/16 * 1.00)

  1. 8/5 * 1/SkillDifficultyFactor)

  1. MeleeRoundsLostSkill, SkillRoundsLostSkill and FullRoundsLostSkill According to SkillDifficulty

That is to say, assuming a 3-round, trivial skill, we should remove 1.6 (.5333*3) melee rounds, or 4.8 (1.6*3) rounds of skill-use, or 1.2 (0.4*3) rounds of both skill and melee.

A Final Note on Skill Damage

On a final note for this discussion, I realize that what we have done may seem rather trivial. We have constructed the system so that the effect of “damage to opponent” is equivalent to “opponent loses attacks”, “opponent loses skills” and “opponent loses skills and attacks”. On the surface, it would seem like player's skill use really doesn't matter.

As we will soon learn, not all characters are the same. For example, some players will likely shift more of their ActDam from melee damage into skill damage, and vice-versa. If I know that my opponent is heavily weighted toward melee damage for instance, it probably makes good tactical sense for me to use skills that shut down my opponent's ability to swing. By doing this, we ought to be able to out-damage the other guy, and gain the edge we need to achieve victory. Clearly, doing this is a matter of tactics and play-style, which I won't go into much in depth. Obviously, we want to encourage players to use their smarts, so the system that is being devised will clearly do so.

Refining SimpWeaponDamage

From our earlier discussion of armor, we realized that it was plausible for a player to sacrifice armor in hopes of gaining some other criteria. One obvious situation would be a player that uses substandard armor, but an enhanced weapon. We want to insure that this setup (and the reverse) is not encouraged by our setup.

Following a now familiar pattern, let's first divvy SimpWeaponDamage up into two component pieces. One piece, WeaponDamExp, will be based upon the player's experience and/or skill level, while the second, WeaponDamEq, will be equipment based. We would like WeaponDamEq to mirror ActArmor so that the tradeoffs between the two match.

We thus write the following equation, and attempt to solve for K and n:

WeaponDamEq = K * SimpWeaponDamagen

Since we want to equate this to ActArmor:

K * SimpWeaponDamagen = ActArmor

K * [0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902]n = 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

K*0.74685n * (level1.759815+13)0.635902n = 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

We can solve for n by examining the parenthetical term alone:

n = .163844/.635902

n = .257656

Realize the scalar multiplier (K) is rather meaningless, so I will not bother to solve for its value. However, the exponent can be utilized, and we can now write:

  1. WeaponDamEq

= The contribution to SimpWeaponDamage from equipment

= SimpWeaponDamage0.257656

= (0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902)0.257656

  1. .927552 * ((level)1.759815 + 13).163844

And consequently:

  1. WeaponDamExp

= The contribution to SimpWeaponDamage from character's experience

= SimpWeaponDamage / WeaponDamEq

= SimpWeaponDamage / SimpWeaponDamage0.257656

= SimpWeaponDamage0.742344

= [0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902]0.742344

  1. .805187 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.472058

  1. DamCapExp and DamCapEq versus Level

From this, we see that WeaponDamExp plays a large role in determining SimpWeaponDamage. Even if a L50 were to use a L1 weapon, they would have a damage capacity of 29.862 (1.429*20.893), roughly equivalent to the SimpWeaponDamage of a L26. Or said another way, the L50's SimpWeaponDamage is 29.8 when we expect it to be 60. They are still 50% (30/60) as effective as they should be. Not great, but not horrible either.

Commentary on Percentage Changes in ActArmor and WeaponDamEq

Another interesting fact also emerges from this spreadsheet. As should be obvious, a percentage increase in either WeaponDamEq or ActArmor leads to a corresponding percentage increase in Power. Let us look at the percentage increase of WeaponDamEq vs. ActArmor. (It's difficult to capture this concept in a spreadsheet, so I'm going to just present some findings.)

Because of how we have structured the two functions, they are numerically equal at the same level. Consequently, their slopes (which can be thought of as a percentage increase) are also the same at all levels. Therefore, the Power I gain from increasing my armor by one level is the same as if I had increased my weapon by one level. Thus, when a player decides to upgrade, weapons and armor are equally favored.

However, the situation for trading off is slightly different. Examining WeaponDamEq, we note that if we ignore scalar multipliers and additive constants, the value increases as: ((level)1.759815)0.163844 = (level)0.28834. Since the exponent is less than 1.0, we learn that the increase at low level is greater than that at higher levels. The ramification is that, if I sacrifice armor or weapon in order to gain the other, I will be sacrificing more (level-wise) than I am gaining (level-wise).

This is good, as it encourages players to maintain parity between their weapons and armor. For example, a L30 player might opt to use an L35 weapon and L25 armor, but they would find their resulting power is only 99.26% that of a L30 with L30 armor and weapons. Obviously, it's not a tremendous penalty, but a penalty nonetheless. We, thus, have assurances that players, opting to experiment or simply unable to find proper gear, will neither uncover a loophole that gives them an edge, nor be penalized excessively over characters more properly setup.

More Refinements for Combat Blows

An Introduction to Number of Swings Per Round

The next step in understanding combat is to take a look at how many swings a given player gets per round. Clearly, we remain constrained by the arguments made during the SimpWeaponDamage discussion, so we have to insure that whatever changes we make in the number of swings is counterbalanced by a corresponding change in the damage per blow.

For simplicity, we will conceptualize that the average character two swings per round. This means that the average character has a DamagePerSwing equal to SimpWeaponDamage/2.

  1. NormPCSwingsPerRound

= SwingsPerRound for our “average” PC

  1. 2.0

Clearly, not all characters will have two swings per round. Some racial-types might be “faster” or “slower”. Some body-styles have more limbs to attack with (e.g. octopus).

We capture this idea by stating:

  1. DamagePerSwing

= Damage capacity per combat swing

= SimpWeaponDamage / SwingsPerRound

The more swings I get, the less damage I get per swing. Said another way, if I have a given mob, and choose to give it more SwingsPerRound without changing its DamagePerSwing, I have effectively raised its SimpWeaponDamage, and in turn its Power. As a consequence, the mob would have to be rated at a higher level.

Weapon Proficiency and Specialization for Players

Many fantasy-RPGs have introduced the idea of proficiency and specialization, and our MUD is no different. For the most part, proficiency is thought of as simply improving one's skill level with the weapon in question, while specialization typically improves the SwingsPerRound with that weapon. Specialization may not be performed until fully proficient. Given our previous discussion of damage, we our forced to intertwine these concepts.

Proficiency, a skill, which we will discuss in depth later, can be thought of as advancing with level. That is to say, a L1 is not at all proficient, whereas we expect that as level advances, proficiency increase as well. For that matter, we stipulate that full proficiency is achieved at L20. Thus, we state that proficiency has the effect of raising the SimpOffSkill up to the value shown for L30.

Specialization, since it actually increases the number of swings possessed, behaves a bit differently. Following in the wake of proficiency, we stipulate that specialization starts at L20, and proceeds until maxed at L50. Hence, specialization has the effect of raising the SimpOffSkill from the L20 value up through L50.

That is to say, we will implement SimpOffSkill through the concepts of proficiency and specialization. We presume that by knowing how proficient/specialized a character is, we can derive a “level” from this, and plug this “level” into the SimpOffSkill equation.

Furthermore, we desire specialization to impact the PCs SwingsPerRound. As noted previously, the only way this can be done is to alter DamPerSwing so that SimpWeaponDamage remains constant. For the most part, this entails shifting a bit of the damage away from the weapon, in order to provide for an increase in SwingsPerRound. Therefore, we'll make adjustments in WeaponDamEq (which in turn impacts SimpWeaponDamage), in order to compensate for the change in SwingsPerRound.

Furthermore, we need to realize that:

SimpWeaponDamage = DamPerSwing * SwingsPerRound

Let us start by noting a few values for SimpWeaponDamage. At L20, SimpWeaponDamage is 22.23412. At L50, SimpWeaponDamage is 60.0.

We would like full specialization to grant an extra 0.5 to SwingsPerRound (up to a total of 2.5).

  1. SpecBonusSwings

= Extra SwingsPerRound due to specialization

  1. 0.5

That is to say, at L20, we expect 2.0 SwingsPerRound hence:

SimpWeaponDamage = DamPerSwing * SwingsPerRound

22.23412 = DamPerSwing * 2.0

DamPerSwing = 11.11706

At L50, we expect 2.5 SwingsPerRound:

SimpWeaponDamage = DamPerSwing * SwingsPerRound

60.0 = DamPerSwing * 2.5

DamPerSwing = 24

WepDamEqPerSwing

We previously said that:

SimpWeaponDamage = WeaponDamEq * WeaponDamExp

It will be useful for us to have a per-swing value for WeaponDamEq. We will call this term WepDamEqPerSwing:

WepDamEqPerSwing = WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound

At L20:

WepDamEqPerSwing = WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound

WepDamEqPerSwing = 2.223658 / 2.0

WepDamEqPerSwing = 1.111829

At L50:

WepDamEqPerSwing = WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound

WepDamEqPerSwing = 2.871783 / 2.5

WepDamEqPerSwing = 1.148713

If we let WepDamEqPerSwing increase linearly between L20 and L50, we get:

  1. WepDamEqPerSwing20_50

= WepDamEqPerSwing (Good only in range L20-L50)

= (level-20)/30 * (L50 WepDamEqPerSwing - L20 WepDamEqPerSwing) + L20 WepDamEqPerSwing

= (level-20)/30 * (1.148713 - 1.111829) + 1.111829

= (level-20)/30 * (0.036884) + 1.111829

And by extension:

  1. SwingsPerRound20_50

= SwingsPerRound (Good only in range L20-L50)

= WeaponDamEq / WepDamEqPerSwing20_50

To formulize what we have stipulated for the other levels:

  1. SwingsPerRound00_20

= SwingsPerRound (Good only in range L0-L20)

= NormPCSwingsPerRound

= 2.0

  1. WepDamEqPerSwing00_20

= DamEqPerSwing (Good only in range L00-L20)

= WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound00_20

= WeaponDamEq / 2.0

  1. SwingsPerRound20_50

= SwingsPerRound (Good only in range L20-L50)

  1. 2.5

  1. WepDamEqPerSwing20_50

= DamEqPerSwing (Good only in range L20-L50)

= WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound20_50

= WeaponDamEq / (NormPCSwingsPerRound + SpecBonusSwings)

= WeaponDamEq / 2.5

Obviously, we can combine these functions using copious amounts of min/max functions (frankly, I think it's more intuitive broken apart as above).

  1. SwingsPerRound

= number of attacks a PC possesses

= min(max(WeaponDamEq/((WeaponDamEq@L20)/NormPCSwingsPerRound +

min(max(level-20, 0), 30)/30 *

((WeaponDamEq@L50)/ (NormPCSwingsPerRound + SpecBonusSwings) -

(WeaponDamEq@L20)/ NormPCSwingsPerRound)),

NormPCSwingsPerRound), (NormPCSwingsPerRound + SpecBonusSwings))

= min(max(WeaponDamEq/((WeaponDamEq@L20)/ 2.0 +

min(max(level-20, 0), 30)/30 *

((WeaponDamEq@L50)/ (2.0 + 0.5) -

(WeaponDamEq@L20)/ 2.0)),

2.0), (2.0 + 0.5))

= min(max(WeaponDamEq / ((WeaponDamEq@L20)/2 +

min(max(level-20, 0), 30)/30 *

((WeaponDamEq@L50)/ 2.5 -

(WeaponDamEq@L20)/2)),

2.0), 2.5)

Using the numerical values for the constants:

= min(max(WeaponDamEq / ((1.111829) +

min(max(level-20, 0), 30)/30 *

((2.871783)/ 2.5 -

(2.223658)/2)),

2.0), 2.5)

= min(max(WeaponDamEq/(1.111829 +

min(max(level-20, 0), 30)/30 *

(1.148713 - 1.111829)),

2.0), 2.5)

  1. min(max(WeaponDamEq/(1.111829 + min(max(level-20,0),30)/30 * 0.036884), 2.0), 2.5)

And by extension:

  1. WepDamEqPerSwing

= Damage inflicted per swing that hits

= WeaponDamEq / SwingsPerRound

Thus:

  1. SwingsPerRound and WepDamEqPerSwing by Level

SwingsPerRound, as you will note, not only behaves as designed, hitting the prescribed values at the appropriate times, but also is always increasing. Obviously, we wouldn't want players to lose any swings as they level, so this is good.

Furthermore, WepDamEqPerSwing is also incremental everywhere. Since we will ultimately model this as the damage a weapon is supposed to do, we are effectively saying that weapon damage increases with level always. Again, this is excellent, as it is exactly what we would want to have happen.

Finally, we should also note that specialization is not really optional. We will discuss skills in depth later on, but one of the underlying principles is interchangeability in skill-path choice. Since the amount of damage a weapon will do (modeled after WepDamEqPerSwing) factors in the effects of specialization, a character that chooses not to specialize will have a WeaponDamEq 80% (2.00/2.5) of appropriate. If we were to backtrack this to the Power equation, we find that failure to specialize would result in having only 85% the desired power. (Derivation to follow) We will have to keep this in mind later on when devising the skill system.

(Optional Derivation:

SimpWeaponDamage = WeaponDamEq * WeaponDamExp

= (0.8 * desired WeaponDamEq) * WeaponDamExp

= 0.8 * desired SimpWeaponDamage

SimpWeaponDamage represents 75% of DamCap, which means we would have .75*.8 + .25 = 85% of the desired DamCap. And by extension, that means 85% of the desired ActDam, SimpOffPow and Power.)

WepDamPerSwing

With the information we now have, we are finally able to write the all-important formula for determining how much a weapon does on a per swing basis.

In a trivial sense, we can write:

  1. WepDamPerSwing

= Amount of damage inflicted by weapon per successful swing

= SimpWeaponDamage / SwingsPerRound

However, we must remember that SimpWeaponDamage is composed of two pieces, hence:

= (WeaponDamEq * WeaponDamExp) / SwingsPerRound

= WepDamEqPerSwing * WeaponDamExp

Since WepDamPerSwing is the amount of damage inflicted per successful swing, we learn that this amount is dependent partly on level and experience (WeaponDamExp) and partly on the nature of the weapon (WepDamEqPerSwing). The upshot of everything that we have done is that a character gains more damage as they rise in level, their damage also increases as their weapon improves, and furthermore, they gain more swings as they begin to specialize.

  1. WeapDamPerSwing as a Function of Level

As is evident, the WepDamEqPerSwing value always increases. Hence, a higher-level weapon is always better than a lower level one. Again, this is what we would expect and desire.

Furthermore, we see that a L1 weapon equipped by a L1 character will do an average damage of 2.0 per swing. Obviously, we want every hit to have some noticeable effect, so the fact that it is above 1.0 is good.

A top-of-the-line weapon, L60, damages for 29.36 HP per hit. This means that a single-blow won't be adequate to kill a L1. Since we don't desire instant-death, this is a good setup.

Weapon Proficiency and Specialization for Mobs

As a final note on Proficiency and Specialization, we must make a comment about how all of this applies for mobs. Since builders tend to either specify that their mob has X number of hits, or it is specified by the designer of the racial type, it is a good idea that that mob have X always or bug-reports are likely to arise. The ramification is that if number of hits is specified, we need to ignore specialization's effect on SwingsPerRound.

Furthermore, Proficiency spans L1-L20, and Specialization from L20-L50. This is the full range of player levels, but mobs can extend well into the L50+ range. Since we are using these skills to identify SimpOffSkill, we have a problem. Clearly, we don't want to add a third, mob-only “skill” that aids in calculating SimpOffSkill for the L50+ range as this would be silly, but neither do we want to limit SimpOffSkill to the L50 value.

For practical purposes we are forced to do the following: if specialization is not maxed, we calculate SimpOffSkill from Proficiency and Specialization as per players, otherwise, we use the greater of the mobs actual level or L50 to derive SimpOffSkill.

Combat Use of the Secondary Hand

An Overview of the Tradeoffs Involved

We have previously given values for the number of ParryEligible blows, as well as the expected ActDam inflicted. We do not wish to favor one style of attacks over the others, so let us explore how to make tradeoffs between the terms.

Since our previous argument to derive ActDam presumed that ParryEligible blows effectively missed their mark, we realize that adopting a posture where ParryEligible blows hit means that the character is in fact taking a greater amount of damage per round. That is to say, if I am not blocking those ParryEligible blows, I am effectively suffering greater damage. The only way that this can be reconciled with the BalancedCombat equation is if I am, in turn, also inflicting more damage than normal.

We realize:

BalancedCombat equation:

ActHPa * ActDama = ActHPb * ActDamb

ActHPa * ((multiplier for weapon in 2nd hand) * ActDama)= ActHPb * ((multiplier for extra hits from not blocking ParryEligible blows) * ActDamb)

Clearly, the multipliers need to be identical. For the fair-fight scenario, since ParryEligible represents an extra 50% of all blows, the weapon in the second hand must represent an extra 50% damage.

Mathematically, this looks like:

  1. OffHandMultiplier

= Extra damage (for hitter) (as a multiplier) from using weapon in off-hand

= (ParryEligible blows that land on me) / HitPercab

= (5/22 * RawMiss) / HitPercab

= (5/22 * (1.00 - HitPercab)) / HitPercab

= 5/22 * (1/HitPercab - 1)

As an example, let's imagine a fairly skewed fight in which I am using a 2H weapon and am attacking a much higher-level mob. Because the mob is superior, it hits me 60% of the time (let's say). Plugging into the above equation:

= 5/22 * (1/HitPercab - 1)

= 5/22 * (1/0.6 - 1)

= 5/22 * 2/3

= 5/33

That is to say, for this example, I only receive an extra 5/33 (or 15%) more damage for the use of my off-hand as a weapon. As noted before, the fair-fight scenario yields OffHandMultiplier=0.5 as desired.

This setup, while correct numerically and properly maintaining BalancedCombat, is somewhat hard to defend rationally. Realize however, the damage from the primary weapon does NOT decrease; only the extra damage from the off-hand weapon depends on the level of the combatants. We can presume that the off-hand is less articulate than the primary, and that the off-hand is simply unable to land as well upon a vastly superior foe.

As a final comment on this subject, we should realize that simple ratios do come into play. If I use my weapon to block half the ParryEligible blows, than I should have an OffHandMultiplier that is half as great.

As previously noted during the discussion about parrying, combatants have the ability to actively block blows. For the most part, we expect that a player will be wielding their best weapon in their primary hand and using it to attack with. However, it is how the character chooses to use their secondary (or off) hand that is of interest.

Use of a Shield

One option is to hold a shield in the off-hand. This is obviously the most defensive of options, and should therefore yield the best chance of blocking an incoming blow.

Strictly speaking, the size of the shield ought to play an important part. However, since our combat system does not model “weapon reach” or otherwise factor in dimensions, we will essentially say that a shield is a shield.

Additionally, our system has no capability for using a shield offensively (swinging it like a chair or club, using it as a battering ram, etc.), thus shield-use has no inherent attack capabilities.

Thus, if a shield is in use, all ParryEligible blows should be blocked and no additional blows should be awarded.

Dual-Wielding

Another option would be to equip a secondary weapon in the off-hand. Doing this yields quite a bit of flexibility for the character. This second weapon could be used as a means to also attack the opponent (attack with both hands), or the character might choose to use the off-hand weapon defensively to parry blows made against it (attack with one hand, parry with the other). Obviously, variations are allowed, so that the off-hand parries some blows and attacks as well.

We will give the character the ability to specify whether they want an offensive or defensive posture (discussed further later on), and we will use this to determine how the off-hand is used.

The off-hand should receive extra swings related to OffHandMultiplier and the normal SwingsPerRound. That is to say, if the OffHandMultiplier says to do an extra 50% damage (as is the fair-fight case), the off-hand should receive 50% of the SwingsPerRound value. A non-specialized, dual wielding, fair-fight would see 2.0 SwingsPerRound with the primary, and 1.0 (= 0.5 * 2.0) SwingsPerRound with the secondary.

Since we will assume that even a character flagged-offensive will parry some blows, and a flagged-defensive character might occasionally take potshots that present themselves, we will assume:

Offensive: Parry 10%, attack 90%

Semi-Offensive: Parry 25%, attack 75%

Normal: Parry 50%, attack 50%

Semi-Defensive: Parry 75%, attack 25%

Defensive: Parry 90%, attack 10%

  1. Tradeoffs for Various Uses of Off-Hand

Fencing

The third-option would involve leaving the off-hand empty. A character thus equipped could theoretically use only one “side” of their body, and rather than standing toe-to-toe with my belly-button facing the opponent, a 1-weapon-only character would probably adopt a more traditional fencing posture (one-foot in front, facing semi-sideways). With the off-hand free, the character also has flexibility to use it to grab at their victim or otherwise distract them.

For all intents and purposes, this is a fairly informal style of fighting, more akin to barroom brawling than pitched battles. I have reservations about equating this style of fighting to the others, so I am largely going to simply ignore it.

It's useful to keep it in mind, as certain classes might adopt it (or be encouraged to it) for roleplay purposes. It's certainly plausible that thieves and assassins might jump someone armed with only a single dagger.

Two-Handed (2H) Weapons

Finally, a character might opt to use a single weapon that requires both hands. Such 2H-weapons are larger, more unwieldy, and typically do more damage (swing for swing) than their 1H equivalents.

Realistically, a 2H weapon is typically larger and heavier, but neither is it that much slower to swing. We'll stipulate that a 2H weapon has the same number of swings as the 1H weapon does when in the primary hand.

Unfortunately, this creates a messy situation. Since the person is using a 2H weapon, they need to be getting the normal amount of damage plus the amount we calculated in OffHandMultiplier. Since SwingsPerRound is not allowed to change, this means that the 2H-weapon damage per swing must change depending on the level of the combatants.

Mathematically:

  1. WepDamEqPerSwing2H

= WepDamEqPerSwing for a 2H weapon

= OffHandMultiplier * WepDamEqPerSwing

Unfortunately, this means that 2H-weapon damage depends on the value of HitPercab. I'll always get SwingsPerRound with the 2H weapon, but in a fair-fight, the 2H weapon will do 50% more damage per successful swing than a 1H-weapon would do. But if I fight mobs of greater level, the extra damage the 2H-weapon does becomes less and less.

Outcomes of the Off Hand Weapon System

The upshot of all this is that the greatest offensive setup is to use a 2H weapon. Using dual weapons in offensive mode comes close in terms of total damage, but the off-hand weapon will occasionally parry a blow here and there. Still dual wielding, we can downgrade our attack mode and gradually become more and more defensive. Still, dual wielding in defensive mode allows the occasional offensive swing and a few ParryEligible blows will land. The greatest defensive setup would be to replace the offhand weapon with a shield.

Implementation Notes

Fair-Fights

We should not leave the subject of combat before thinking long and hard about the practical ramifications of our fair-fights. Our game design largely presumes that fair-fights should occur most of the time. However, we have kept the systems for mobs and PCs identical.

Since mobs and PCs are perfectly in synch, a fair-fight is basically a 50/50 tossup with the mob winning half the time, and the PC winning otherwise. Obviously, the human brains will probably best our mob AI, and the PC probably has the initiative of when to attack, etc. While these things give the PC a slight edge, game design should not really factor these things into account.

Clearly, PCs will not like fighting in a 50/50 contest. Victory simply awards them modest XP and booty, while failure means possible death and other large penalties.

For this reason, we should hamstring mobs slightly. Obviously, we don't want to alter the discussions of this document overtly much, but we want to create a game that encourages players to fight like-leveled creatures, and to do this, we need to give players a slight edge.

Giving mobs about 90% of the ActHP that we calculated is probably sufficient to accomplish this. For purposes of this document, I am going to ignore this correction factor, but I am pointing out that it is appropriate to slightly penalize mobs in order to accomplish our larger goals of encouraging fair-fights and making the game fun.

Reducing ActHP for mobs by 10% will have the effect of making the mob last less long in combat. Rather than the 60 rounds of SurvRnds previously calculated, mobs will last 10% fewer rounds. That is to say, on average the PC will last 60 rounds while the mob dies near round 54. All things considered, this gives the PC about 6 rounds worth of padding in the typical fight, which ought to significantly shift the balance into the player's favor.

Synergistic Correction

For the most part, the discussions thus far have centered on one-on-one fights. Clearly, being a multi-user environment, players will certainly want to group, so we should not overlook the impact of multiple characters combining efforts.

Thus far, we have already built in some generous “grouping rewards”. For instance, the fact that MobXP goes up faster than Power was primarily introduced to encourage people to work together and fight the best creatures they were capable of killing. Built into this system was the fact that two equal players, when grouped, would have twice their normal Power; three such would have 3X the Power, etc.

Unfortunately, as things stand, this is not the case. Consider the situation when two equal players group. With both swinging at the enemy, they effectively inflict twice the normal damage. As a result, the mob lasts half as long as normal. So, rather than being able to tank one mob each if separate, EACH of them can tank TWO fair-fight mobs. This yields a total of 4 kills grouped. Granted, the MobXP would be split two ways for the 4 kills, but this is still twice the amount they would have gotten separately. Throw the above “grouping reward” factor in, and grouping REALLY pays off.

Clearly, we did not intend for grouping to have this effect. Power is supposed to be additive, such that when two people tank, they are equivalent to a single character of twice the Power. In order to accomplish this, we must make a SynergisticCorrection.

The SynergisticCorrection is a scaling factor, such that when multiple people group, they become less than 100% efficient each. As more and more people are thrown at a mob, each person gets a smaller and smaller fraction of their damage. However, the sum of everybody's damage increases. The group, as a whole, doesn't suffer from adding new members, but each individual member's damage declines.

Additionally, the same SynergisticCorrection applies to the tank's received damage. As more people are thrown into a group, the tank winds up taking more damage. We'll come back to this in a bit.

The intention of the SynergisticCorrection is to eliminate the geometric growth of Power, and put it back on the additive scale that we desired. That is, we desire that power goes something like:

Power = ActDama * ActHPa + ActDamb * ActHPb + ActDamc * ActHPc + …

However, without the SynergisticCorrection, we see that it goes like:

Power = (ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPa +

(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPb +

(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPc + …

The SynergisticCorrection (K) is simply a multiplier, that when applied to each of the ActDam and ActHP of the group (in the second equation), makes the two equations the same. That is:

(K*ActDama + K*ActDamb + K*ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPa +

(K*ActDama + K*ActDamb + K*ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPb +

(K*ActDama + K*ActDamb + K*ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPc + …

= ActDama * ActHPa + ActDamb * ActHPb + ActDamc * ActHPc + …

Factoring:

K*(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPa +

K*(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPb +

K*(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * K*ActHPc + …

= ActDama * ActHPa + ActDamb * ActHPb + ActDamc * ActHPc + …

And again:

K2 *(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPa +

K2 *(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPb +

K2 *(ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) * ActHPc + …

= ActDama * ActHPa + ActDamb * ActHPb + ActDamc * ActHPc + …

And solving for K:

  1. SynergisticCorrection

= A correction term applied to multi-person groups

= sqrt((ActDama * ActHPa + ActDamb * ActHPb + ActDamc * ActHPc + …) / (ActHPa * (ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) +

ActHPb * (ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …) +

ActHPb * (ActDama + ActDamb + ActDamc + …)))

Technically, we could use separate correction terms, one for ActDam and one for ActHP. The products of the two separate ones would still have to be K2. I chose not to do this though.

The result of this is that SynergisticCorrection has a value of 1.0 for a one-person group. For groups larger than one, SynergisticCorrection has a value less than 1.0.

Effectively, what this means is that in a group, each member gets SynergisticCorrection (as a percent) of their true damage. Obviously, we can't change a person's ActHP, but what we can do is change the rate at which a group takes damage. For simplicity, I opted not to change the HitPercab and instead simply let the damage the tank receives go up accordingly. That is:

Each hitter inflicts:

Corrected Damage Inflicted = ActDam * SynergisticCorrection

Each Tank receives:

Corrected Damage received = ActDam / SynergisticCorrection

Clearly, this is somewhat objectionable, and the only rationalization that can be offered is that it is necessary from a mathematical standpoint to make Power additive, and that it is somewhat reasonable to reduce efficiency for a multi-person group (Coordinating moves and all that).

  1. Analysis of SynergisticCorrection

The above spreadsheet is a bit obtuse. Vertically, I've displayed 8 different test scenarios. Each test scenario shows up to 4 (we can have more, but I didn't bother to plot it) different people in a group. The relative powers for HP and Dam of each of the 4 people are shown. For instance, test case #1 is a 1-person group, with the person evenly balanced between HP and Dam. Test case #4 is a 4-person group, with everyone being evenly balanced.

For each test case, I calculated the SynergisticCorrection, shown in the middle column. The “Additive Power” column is what would result if we summed HP*Dam for each of the group members. This is what we stated would be the desired power. The “Eff HP” and “Eff Dam” columns represent the effective HP and dam for this group. That is, it's the sum of the HP or Dam, scaled by SynergisticCorrection. “Eff Power” is the effective power, which is simply “Eff HP” * “Eff Dam”.

You'll note that Eff Power and Additive Power are identical, this proves that the correction factor we made results in the proper adjustment.

The points of interest are that the more people that are added to a group, the lower the value for SynergisticCorrection (Cases #1-4). Coordination becomes increasingly more difficult with more people involved.

Likewise, if one of the members is unbalanced (e.g. twice the HP, half the damage), SynergisticCorrection becomes less and less (a bigger correction). (C.f. case #2, case #5, case #6)

However, if the group is vastly dissimilar (C.f. case #8, case #9), the SynergisticCorrection approaches 1.0 (no correction). Clearly, the low-level group member doesn't do very much, and the system is telling us that the situation is reasonably identical to the high-level person being alone.

Character Class

We have, up until now, been using a fairly generic definition for characters. We have come quite far using this simplified definition. However, it is now time to begin enhancing our definition and exploring the results. We will start by introducing the concept of class.

An Introduction to Character Class

Simply speaking, character class is equivalent to the person's chosen profession. Being a fantasy-based RPG, we expect to see some characters become warriors. Others will pursue a career in magic, or perhaps religion. Still others might be attracted to the black-careers of thieving and the like.

Furthermore, players often have different perceptions about how a class should be designed. For example, some folks may feel that a given class ought to be successful playing entirely solo without the aid of other group mates. Others may feel that the same class is an obvious “support” character that is meant to enhance the power of other members in its group, but is fairly weak when standing on its own. The former interpretation would lead to a class fairly well balanced between HP, melee damage and skill damage, while the group-centric view probably sacrifices HP in order to enhance damage capacity and ability to lend support to someone else that is fighting.

Experience has demonstrated that there is no good middle ground on this problem. Trying to appease all interpretations just leads to a watered-down class that is no good at anything. We'll avoid this pitfall by splitting the various classes into three parts. One geared toward soloing, one that is group-oriented with an emphasis on offensive capabilities, and a third that is group-oriented but more focused on the defense of the group.

Clearly, each type of character will differ slightly based on how we perceive the class, so we should explore each class in depth.

The Warrior Class

The warrior class is conceived of as a fighter that is evenly balanced and fully capable of going it alone.

The warrior class is probably the simplest to devise since it is essentially identical to the generalized definition of “character” that we have devised to date. In fact, for simplicity, the warrior will have the values determined to date for all equations.

Warrior-classed characters will have fairly even HP, AC, weapon and skill development over their entire career.

The warrior class is designed to be successful when soloing. The HP and damage factors should be structured such that the warrior class is able to play without seeking out other players for assistance.

In a group, the warrior class will be reasonably effective as well. It doesn't have the specializations that define the other classes, but by being well balanced, the warrior class makes an effective backup or substitute for any position that the group finds lacking.

The warrior class will have offensive skills that allow it to damage opponents. Likewise, warriors will also have abilities allowing the warrior to disrupt or distract opponents preventing them from using skills or blocking their melee capacity.

The Bodyguard Class

The bodyguard class is also a fighter-subtype, but it is conceived of as being group-oriented and with an emphasis on defensive actions. In a word, bodyguards are “tanks”.

Compared to the warrior class, bodyguards have a greater number of HP, but inflict less melee damage per round. Bodyguard's skills are geared toward disrupting the opponent and preventing the opponent from successfully executing offensive and skill attacks. Additionally, bodyguard's skills focus upon defending other group mates and making sure that the enemy stays engaged with the bodyguard.

If playing solo, bodyguards mainly rely on being able to outlast their opponents. Their greater HP gives them more staying power, and their basic strategy involves keeping the enemy's ability to inflict damage to a minimum.

In a group, bodyguards typically assume the role of tank. They have the greatest amount of ActHP of any class. Bodyguards are also extremely effective at putting themselves in the line of fire. Hence, enemies find it hard to ignore a bodyguard to attack the other members of a bodyguard's group.

Bodyguard's HP Bonus

Bodyguards will have 20% more ActHP than an equivalent level warrior.

  1. ActHPBodyguard

= 1.2 * ActHP

= 1.2 * 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 22.40558 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Bodyguard's Damage Penalty

To keep Power in balance, bodyguards will have a penalty on their ActDam. In order to maintain parity, this penalty will be equivalent to:

  1. ActDamModifierBodyguard

= Multiplier for ActDam for the bodyguard class

= ActHP / ActHPBodyguard

= 1.00 / 1.2

= 5/6

That is to say:

  1. ActDamBodyguard

= Value for ActDam for bodyguard class

= ActDam * ActDamModifierBodyguard

  1. 5/6 * ActDam

We will stipulate that HitPercab for bodyguards remains the same as for warriors. Thus the derivation for DamCap remains fairly straightforward:

  1. DamCapBodyguard

= Value for DamCap for bodyguard class

= DamCap * ActDamModifierBodyguard

  1. 5/6 * DamCap

As we recall, SimpWeaponDamage represents 75% of DamCap, while SimpSkillDamage represents the other 25%. We do not want bodyguard's skills to be impacted, so this means that the penalty must be entirely born by SimpWeaponDamage:

DamCapBodyguard = WeaponDamageBodyguard + SimpSkillDamage

(5/6 * DamCap) = WeaponDamageBodyguard + (1/4 * DamCap)

By rewriting:

  1. WeaponDamageBodyguard

= Value for SimpWeaponDamage for bodyguard class

= (5/6 * DamCap) - (1/4 * DamCap)

= 7/12 * DamCap

= 7/12 * (4/3 * SimpWeaponDamage)

  1. 7/9 * SimpWeaponDamage

We will want bodyguards to have the same number of swings per round as warriors; hence, SwingsPerRound is the same for bodyguards. Additionally, we won't be placing any restriction on the weapon used by bodyguards, so we stipulate that WeaponDamEq remains constant. As a consequence, there is no change in WepDamEqPerSwing. Therefore, we conclude that the WeaponDamageBodyguard penalty is entirely handled by the Exp term:

WeaponDamageBodyguard = 7/9 * SimpWeaponDamage

WeaponDamageBodyguard = 7/9 * (WeaponDamEq * WeaponDamExp)

Thus, we realize:

  1. WeaponDamExpBodyguard

= Value for WeaponDamExp for bodyguard class

= 7/9 * WeaponDamExp

= 0.7778 * WeaponDamExp

Stated simply, in order to maintain the Power equation, bodyguards will gain 20% more ActHP over warriors, but suffer a 22.22% penalty to WeaponDamExp, which translates into 22.22% less SimpWeaponDamage as well.

  1. Bodyguard Class vs. Warrior Class

Bodyguard Review

Bodyguards are essentially simple warriors that possess more HP and a lesser damage. Beyond that, the changes are cosmetic and are made for the sake of role-playing.

While bodyguard's value in the Power equation remains unchanged compared to warriors, it must be noted that the SurvRnds is slightly altered. Because bodyguard damage is lower, bodyguards take 6/5 the time to kill a warrior. Likewise, bodyguard's higher HP make them less vulnerable, and they take 6/5 the amount of time to die as well. Overall, a bodyguard vs. warrior fair-fight will require 72 rounds (vs. 60 for two warriors).

The Mercenary Class

The mercenary class is also a fighter-subtype, but is conceived of as being group-oriented and with an emphasis on offensive actions. In a word, mercenaries are “hitters”.

Compared to the warrior class, mercenaries have lower HP, but inflict greater melee damage per round. Mercenary's skills are geared toward inflicting as much damage as possible, as well as toward encouraging the enemy to attack someone else other than the mercenary.

Mercenaries fare reasonably well when fighting one-on-one. They are unable to last extraordinarily long, and they must adopt a strategy that lets them inflict as much damage as possible in as quick an amount of time.

In a group, mercenaries are almost always seen hitting behind bodyguards or warriors. Mercenaries have the least amount of ActHP of all the fighter-subclasses, but are rewarded with the ability to do great amounts of damage, and skills that discourage opponents from targeting the mercenary.

Mercenary's HP Penalty

Mercenaries will have 20% less ActHP than an equivalent level warrior.

  1. ActHPMercenary

= 0.8 * ActHP

= 0.8 * 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 14.93705 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Mercenary's Damage Bonus

To keep Power in balance, mercenaries will receive a bonus on their ActDam. In order to maintain parity, this bonus will be equivalent to:

  1. ActDamModifierMercenary

= Multiplier for ActDam for the mercenary class

= ActHP / ActHPMercenary

= 1.00 / 0.8

= 5/4

That is to say:

  1. ActDamMercenary

= Value for ActDam for mercenary class

= ActDam * ActDamModifierMercenary

  1. 5/4 * ActDam

We will stipulate that HitPercab for mercenaries remains the same as for warriors. Thus the derivation for DamCap remains fairly straightforward:

  1. DamCapMercenary

= Value for DamCap for mercenary class

= DamCap * ActDamModifierMercenary

  1. 5/4 * DamCap

As we recall, SimpWeaponDamage represents 75% of DamCap, while SimpSkillDamage represents the other 25%. We do not want mercenary's skills to be impacted, so this means that the bonus must be entirely found in SimpWeaponDamage:

DamCapMercenary = WeaponDamageMercenary + SimpSkillDamage

(5/4 * DamCap) = WeaponDamageMercenary + (1/4 * DamCap)

By rewriting:

  1. WeaponDamageMercenary

= Value for SimpWeaponDamage for mercenary class

= (5/4 * DamCap) - (1/4 * DamCap)

= DamCap

= (4/3 * SimpWeaponDamage)

We will want mercenaries to have the same number of swings per round as warriors; hence, SwingsPerRound is the same for mercenaries. Additionally, we won't be placing any restriction on the weapon used by mercenaries, so we stipulate that WeaponDamEq remains constant. As a consequence, there is no change in WepDamEqPerSwing. Therefore, we conclude that the WeaponDamageMercenary bonus is entirely handled by the Exp term:

WeaponDamageMercenary = 4/3 * SimpWeaponDamage

WeaponDamageMercenary = 4/3 * (WeaponDamEq * WeaponDamExp)

Thus, we realize:

  1. WeaponDamExpMercenary

= Value for WeaponDamExp for mercenary class

= 4/3 * WeaponDamExp

= 1.3333 * WeaponDamExp

Stated simply, in order to maintain the Power equation, mercenaries will have 20% less ActHP than warriors, but be rewarded with a 33.33% increase in their WeaponDamExp, which translates into 33.33% more SimpWeaponDamage as well.

  1. Mercenary Class vs. Warrior Class

Mercenary Review

Mercenaries are essentially simple warriors that possess fewer HP and a greater damage. Beyond that, the changes are cosmetic and are made for the sake of role-playing.

While mercenary's value in the Power equation remains unchanged compared to warriors, it must be noted that the SurvRnds is slightly altered. Because mercenary damage is higher, mercenaries are able to kill warriors in 4/5 the time. Likewise, mercenary's lower HP make them vulnerable, and they die in 4/5 the time as well. Overall, a mercenary vs. warrior fair-fight will only require 48 rounds (vs. 60 for two warriors).

Magic Casters

Being a fantasy-based RPG, it is natural to expect magic to play an important part of the game. The magic casting classes are granted the greatest control over the forces of magic within our game.

Casters, in general, tend to be the physically weakest class, although they make up for this with the power of their magic.

Like fighters, magic casters will be broken into three distinct subtypes based on anticipated play styles. Warlocks/Witches will adopt the solo play style. Mages will adopt a group-based, defensive play style. And Sorcerers will fill out the subtype with a group-based, offensive play style.

The Warlock Class

The warlock class is a caster-subtype conceived of as evenly balanced and capable of fighting one-on-one. Female warlocks will, of course, be known as witches.

Being a caster-subtype, warlocks will have fewer HP than an equivalent warrior, and also be permitted less armor from equipment. The class is primarily focused on magical forms of attacks, and our combat system largely assumes that warlocks will fight from a distance in an “engaged” state if possible.

However, with the presence of all these penalties, the resulting benefit when it comes to skill damage is impressive. That is to say, these penalties allow warlock's magic to be some of the singly most devastating forms of attacks in the game.

Warlock HP Penalty

Because casters are thought of as physically weak, warlocks will have 50% less ActHP than an equivalent level warrior.

  1. ActHPWarlock

= The ActHP value for the warlock class

= 0.5 * ActHP

= 0.5 * 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 9.33566 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

In order to preserve the Power equation, by reducing HP by a factor of 2, we must now increase other aspects of the warlock.

Warlock Armor

Since casters need to be more nimble in order to make all the arcane gestures necessary for spell casting, warlocks will be limited to wearing strictly clothing (as opposed to armor). Since clothing has an ActArmor 50% that of armor, this means:

  1. ActArmorWarlockEq

= Contribution to ActArmor from equipment for the warlock class

  1. 0.5 * ActArmor

= 0.5 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 5000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

However, warlocks will also possess magical abilities by which they can enhance their own armor rating. Overall, we would like for a fully spelled up warlock to have 1.414 (=sqrt(2)) more armor than an equivalent warrior.

  1. ActArmorWarlock

= Value for ActArmor for the warlock class

  1. sqrt(2) * ActArmor

This implies that the value for warlock armor coming from spells is:

  1. ActArmorWarlockSpell

= Contribution to ActArmor from spells for the warlock class

= ActArmorWarlock - ActArmorWarlockEq

= (sqrt(2) * ActArmor) - (0.5 * ActArmor)

= (sqrt(2) - 0.5) * ActArmor

= 0.914214 * ActArmor

= 0.914214 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 9142.14 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

Warlock Success Rates

We opt to leave SimpOffSkill and SimpDefSkill alone for warlocks. However, because of the warlock's overall higher ActArmor, the resulting ActDef is higher:

  1. ActDefWarlock

= ActDef score for the warlock class

= SimpDefSkillWarlock * ActArmorWarlock

= (SimpDefSkill) * (sqrt(2) * ActArmor)

= sqrt(2) * (SimpDefSkill * ActArmor)

= sqrt(2) * ActDef

Returning briefly to the derivation of (Equation 31.) for HitPercab, we essentially stated that the ratio for SurvRnds and the ratio between Power must match. We had HitPercFormab and were seeking to solve for the exponent n that would permit this. Along the way, we stated that ActOffa = ActDefa and ActOffb = ActDefb. For warlocks, this is no longer the case. Hence, we should not assume that the HitPercab achieved earlier applies.

Instead, let's solve more generically. From before, this is still true:

ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa) = (ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa))n / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

Taking the log of both sides:

log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] = n * log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

Solving for n, which we will call the HitPercExponent:

  1. HitPercExponent

= Exponent to be used as the value of “n” in HitPercFormab

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

Presuming a fair-fight between a warlock and a warrior, we can solve this equation.

Warlock (a) hitting Warrior (b):

HitPercExponent

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

Substituting values for warrior and warlock:

= log[ActOff * ActDef / (ActOff * (sqrt(2) * ActDef))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActDef))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))]

Realizing that ActOff = ActDef:

= log[ActOff * ActOff / (ActOff * (sqrt(2) * ActOff))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActOff))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))]

Factoring out ActOff:

= log[1 * 1 / (1 * (sqrt(2) * 1))] / log[(1 / (1 + (sqrt(2) * 1))) / (1 / (1 + 1))]

= log[1/sqrt(2)] / log[(1 / (1 + sqrt(2))) / (1 / 2)]

= log[1/sqrt(2)] / log[2/(1 + sqrt(2))]

= -0.150515 / -0.081746

= 1.841259

By extension then:

HitPercab (warlock hitting warrior)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.841259

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))1.841259

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))1.841259

= 1.25 * (1/2)1.841259

= 34.8848%

For the reverse scenario, warrior (a) hitting warlock (b):

HitPercExponent

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * (sqrt(2) * ActDef) / (ActOff * ActDef)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActDef)))]

= log[ActOff * (sqrt(2) * ActOff) / (ActOff * ActOff)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActOff)))]

= log[1 * (sqrt(2) * 1) / (1 * 1)] / log[(1 / (1 + 1)) / (1 / (1 + (sqrt(2) * 1)))]

= log[sqrt(2)] / log[(1/2) / (1/(1 + sqrt(2)))]

= .150515 / 0.081746

= 1.841259

By extension then:

HitPercab (warrior hitting warlock)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.841259

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActDef)))1.841259

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(2) * ActOff)))1.841259

= 1.25 * (1/(1+sqrt(2)))1.841259

= 24.6673%

The conclusion here is that, because warlock's spells give them a higher than normal amount of armor, they are tougher to hit. A warrior in a fair fight will hit them 24.6673% of the time (compared to 31.25% for 2 warriors fighting).

What is less intuitive is the fact that warlock's increased amount of armor also grants them the ability to hit more often. Warlocks have a fair-fight success rate of 34.8848%. This is a necessary outcome due to the math, although it is not immediately apparent why better armor should make a person hit more often. Fortunately, since “magic” is inherently involved in the warlock case, we are pretty much free to explain it away as simply a side-effect of the magic that the warlock employs.

As a final note on success rate, realize that warlocks will be principally oriented toward doing damage from their skills. Remember that what we did previously was to raise the success rate of skills, and lower the damage. We'll come back to this momentarily, but it's a good thing to remember in this section of warlock development.

Warlock Damage

Thus far, we have decreased a warlock's HP by a factor of 2, and raised warlock armor by a factor of sqrt(2). We must maintain the Power equation's numerical value, therefore, the warlock's damage must be increased by a factor of sqrt(2) as well.

  1. ActDamWarlock

= ActDam value for warlock class

  1. sqrt(2) * ActDam

Following the procedure previously established.

  1. DamCapWarlock

= DamCap value for warlock class

= ActDamWarlock / HitPercab

= (sqrt(2) * ActDam)/ HitPercab

= sqrt(2) * (ActDam/HitPercab)

  1. sqrt(2) * DamCap

= sqrt(2) * 0.9958 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 1.408279 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Warlock Fight Scenarios

Since the changes for warlocks are not perfectly intuitive, I believe we should revisit the combat scenarios spreadsheet [(Spreadsheet 5.)]. I've put the warlock in red.

  1. Warlock Combat Scenarios

There are a couple of interesting things to note about this chart.

First, the Power ratio and SurvRnds ratio remain constant. Obviously, we want this to happen.

Secondly, the HitPercab values for a fair-fight are as we identified them to be above. However, the SurvRnds for a fair-fight are reduced. It takes 38.01 rounds on average (vs. 60 for 2 warriors). Battles with a warlock are fast and furious. The warrior is inflicting the same damage (less often) against a foe with radically less HP.
