The warlock is simply doing the more damage, slightly more often. This reduces the amount of time a fight takes.

It is important to also remember that success rates for skills are doubled (and damage is halved) in relation to HitPercab. Warlocks in a fair fight (using an easy difficulty skill) should expect to succeed 69.76% of the time.

Breakdown of DamCapWarlock

For warrior, we broke DamCap into a melee component and a skill based component. Since we have also stated that warlocks will do most of their fighting using spells, this means that they will not have the opportunity to be doing any melee damage. Consequently, all of DamCapWarlock is regarded as skill damage:

  1. WeaponDamageWarlock

= Value of SimpWeaponDamage for warlock class

= 0

  1. SkillDamageWarlock

= Value of SkillDamage for warlock class

= DamCapWarlock

= sqrt(2) * DamCap

= sqrt(2) * (4 * SkillDamage)

= 4 * sqrt(2) * SkillDamage

  1. Warlock Class vs. Warrior Class; Defensive Properties

You'll note that warlock HP is half that of a warrior.

Also, warlocks possess almost as much armor strictly from their skills as warriors have from actual equipment. Even though warlocks are restricted on equipment choice, the extra bit they get from wearing clothing makes their effective armor much superior to that of a warrior.

  1. Warlock Class vs. Warrior Class; Offensive Properties

I've put the success rates for the two classes near the top of the appropriate columns. As before, SkillDamage was halved and the success rate was doubled.

The interesting things of note are that the warlock is doing nearly ␀ again as much damage per successful round (DamCap) as the warrior. When success rates are factored in, the warlock is doing twice the effective damage (ActDam) of the warrior.

The basic raw-damage comparison is also somewhat interesting. While the warlock is not using any sort of weapon, the warlock's spells are doing roughly the same damage as the warrior is able to achieve with weapons alone. At L50, the warrior does 70 dam/round (assuming all swings and skills hit), whereas a warlock is getting 56.6 dam/round (assuming skill success).

Warlock Skills

In general, a discussion of a class's skills is not an intrinsic part of the overall game design. The skills given to a class do more to help conceptualize it than they do to insure overall harmony and equality. However, I don't want to leave the class topic without throwing out some general ideas that came to mind while developing the numerical system.

Since warlocks are a “solo” caster, their magic would probably be directly offensive in nature. That is, the warlock casts a spell meant to directly harm the intended victim. There are many such examples, so I won't bother to list them. These kinds of spells probably make up the bulk of the warlock's repertoire.

The warlocks also need some defensive magic for themselves. Since warlocks are going to be on the front line, using the traditional “cast-it, and it decays after a little while” type defense would be fairly high maintenance. I would envision a “permanent” spell effect giving them defense. The warlock would have the ability to raise or lower this “shield” at will. With shields up, protection is greatest, but mana (more on this later) regeneration would suffer.

Being that warlocks are solo-oriented, the class should probably lack the “protect others” and “enhance others” magics. If they possess such spells at all, it would be wise to make success-rate or relative effectiveness suffer. These sorts of spells are not the class's primary focus, and should be de-emphasized.

Review of Warlock

The upshot of all these manipulations is the development of a caster class that is extremely comparable to the warrior class.

From the perspective of Power, the two classes are exactly the same. Of course, they should be or one class would be “better”.

As far as penalties and bonuses go, warlocks possess fewer HP, but have the advantage of having greater effective armor and doing greater damage. Additionally, warlocks have shifted all their damage capacity into their skills. We presume that they are not using a weapon, and thereby permit them to possess an incredibly high damage capacity.

The Sorcerer Class

The sorcerer class is a caster-subtype conceived of as group-oriented and with leanings toward offensive magics.

Sorcerers are fairly similar to warlocks over the first few levels. However, as they are group oriented, and a caster, their play-style will tend to involve firing off spells from well behind the lines. As a consequence, HP will be of little value, and the mage class will shrug off the advantage of greater HP in order to raise their “damage” capacity.

Sorcerers differ from warlocks slightly in that their magics are more aligned toward an indirect offense. That is to say, rather than firing spells directly at the opponent, the sorcerer is more inclined to give “power ups” to the other members of the sorcerer's group so that their abilities are enhanced.

In a one-on-one situation, sorcerers are in a disadvantage. They will have a modest number of HP, and some degree of magical armor, but their skills are oriented toward letting someone else do the fighting for them. Sorcerers will doubtless have some direct-offensive magics at their disposal, so they are not complete fodder, but a sorcerer in a one-on-one had better hope for a decent advantage at the outset.

In a group, sorcerers truly shine. Sorcerers are able to both bang away at an enemy from a distance, as well as enhance their groupmate's natural power. Sorcerers are the heavy guns, although to be best used, they must be adequately protected.

Sorcerer HP Penalty

As with all the casting classes, sorcerers will have fewer HP than an equivalent warrior. Additionally, because sorcerers are group-oriented, they have little need for HP. We will arbitrarily decide that sorcerers will have the HP of a warlock over the first 20 levels. Thereafter, HP gain will be half that as for warlock.

  1. ActHPSorcerer

= ActHP value for sorcerers

= ActHPWarlock(up to L20) + max((ActHPWarlock - (ActHPWarlock at L20))/2, 0)

Sorcerer Armor

Sorcerer armor will be identical in all respects to that of the warlock.

Sorcerer Success Rate

Sorcerer success rate will be identical in all respects to that of warlock.

Sorcerer Damage

Being otherwise identical to warlocks, in order to preserve the Power equation, sorcerer damage must make up the difference for the penalty on HP that sorcerers have as compared to warlocks.

  1. ActDamSorcerer

= Value of ActDam for sorcerer class

= ActDamWarlock * (ActHPWarlock / ActHPSorcerer)

= (sqrt(2) * ActDam) * (1/2 * ActHP) / ActHPSorcerer

= sqrt(2)/2 * (ActHP/ActHPSorcerer) * ActDam

Since over the first few levels, sorcerer and warlock HP are identical, so are their values for ActDam. In the later levels, as sorcerers suffer fewer HP, they gain increased damage. As should be self-apparent, this also exists:

  1. DamCapSorcerer

= Value of DamCap for sorcerer class

= DamCapWarlock * (ActHPWarlock / ActHPSorcerer)

= (sqrt(2) * DamCap) * (1/2 * ActHP) / ActHPSorcerer

= sqrt(2)/2 * (ActHP/ActHPSorcerer) * DamCap

Like warlocks, sorcerers will be presumed to be casting full time so that all of their damage will be from their skills.

  1. Sorcerer Class vs. Warrior Class

From this chart, we can see that sorcerers, near the end of their career, have 1/3 the HP as warriors. Recalling that warlocks have 750 HP at L50, we also note that sorcerers are even lower than that.

However, the ActDam values are also interesting. Sorcerers do THREE TIMES the damage per round than an equivalent warrior by the end of their careers. Additionally, all of this damage is in their skills.

The change in ActDam and HP has a corresponding effect on SurvRnds. By L50, a sorcerer vs. warrior fight requires only 26.04 rounds (proof not displayed here).

Sorcerer Skills

In general, a discussion of a class's skills is not an intrinsic part of the overall game design. The skills given to a class do more to help conceptualize it than they do to insure overall harmony and equality. However, I don't want to leave the class topic without throwing out some general ideas that came to mind while developing the numerical system.

Since sorcerers are group oriented, their spells should primarily be geared toward letting the other group mates fight better. Obvious ideas along this line of thinking include spells that let someone do more damage per swing, or that let that person hit more often. That is to say, the sorcerer's “damage” is utilized indirectly. The sorcerer passes his damage capacity to someone else to use for the sorcerer.

Sorcerers also need defensive magics and it is probably appropriate for them to use something similar to what was developed for warlocks in terms of a “shield” for the sorcerer to use.

In terms of protecting the group, defense is not the sorcerer's primary area of focus (mages). If the ability is given, it should be de-emphasized.

Direct attacks are also not the sorcerer's primary area of focus (warlocks). The class can probably not be made successful without some direct attack styles, but again, they should be kept limited.

The Mage Class

The mage class is a caster-subtype conceived of as group-oriented and with leanings toward defensive magics.

As mages are principally oriented toward defense (of the group), their skills should reflect this. They will have a small assortment of offensive spells, and a like-assortment of self-preservation spells. But they will also possess a number of spells capable of benefiting the frontline members of their party. Rather than directly injuring the enemy, mage's energy would be directed toward enhancing the tank's ability to defend itself.

In a one-on-one situation, mages are in a disadvantage. They will have a modest number of HP, and some degree of magical armor, but their skills are oriented toward letting someone else do the fighting for them. Mages will doubtless have some direct-offensive magics at their disposal, so they are not complete fodder, but a mage in a one-on-one had better hope for a decent advantage at the outset.

In a group, mages truly shine. While they don't employ the big and exciting bangs of sorcerers and warlocks, mages are able to keep their group mates alive long enough to take care of the big and nasties. It may not seem as exciting, but there are plenty of fighters that would prefer the extra insurance of not being hit as often or as hard. Mages are an insecure warrior's best friend!

Mages by the Numbers

For the most part, mages are numerically identical to sorcerers in everyway. The primary difference is in how they utilize their “damage”.

All formulas that apply for sorcerers apply equally for mages.

Mage Skills

In general, a discussion of a class's skills is not an intrinsic part of the overall game design. The skills given to a class do more to help conceptualize it than they do to insure overall harmony and equality. However, I don't want to leave the class topic without throwing out some general ideas that came to mind while developing the numerical system.

Since mages are group oriented, their spells should primarily be geared toward letting the other group mates fight better. The obvious ideas along these lines are spells that prevent the front-line attackers from taking damage. That is, spells that lower the person's chance of being hit, or spells that soak up damage incurred. In essence, the mage should be using his “damage” in order to let another attacker survive longer in combat.

Mages also need self-defensive magics and it is probably appropriate for them to use something similar to what was developed for warlocks in terms of a “shield” for the mage to use.

Giving the mage the ability to power up (sorcerer) or directly attack (warlock) should be avoided, except that some crossover is probably necessary to make the class a success.

Clergy Classes

In a similar fashion to the magic casters, the various gods and deities express their benevolence or displeasure through the various practitioners of the theological classes. “Prayers” are the equivalent of “magic”, although we are free to establish different rules for the two and thereby differentiate the two for roleplay purposes.

The clergy (as the three classes will be called when lumped together) are fairly similar to the casting classes in their play style choices. Missionaries will adopt a play style capable of solo-play. Priests will be in the group-oriented, offensive role. Clerics will adopt the traditional group-oriented defensive role.

Clergy is fairly similar to casters numerically as well. They will be somewhat stronger physically than casters, although still less than the fighter-subtypes. Based on their physical penalty, clergy's skill damage will be enhanced.

If looking purely at the numbers, clergy are largely the “lite” variety of casters. They sacrifice some of the raw damage potential that the casters possess, but have greater values in the more tangible aspects like hit points, armor usage, etc. However, we should not quickly dismiss these classes, as the roleplay opportunities they present make these classes highly viable, and by being somewhere midway between pure-caster and pure-fighter, the perceived disadvantages of the two extremes are lessened.

The Missionary Class

The missionary class is a clergy-subtype conceived of as evenly balanced and capable of fighting solo.

As with all of the clergy classes, missionaries will have fewer hit points than an equivalent warrior, and be somewhat restricted in armor choices as well.

The missionaries primary focus is in employing divine acts (prayers) to directly attack the missionary's foes. Like casters, the missionary will be encouraged to fight from an “engaged” state, foregoing melee damage and concentrating on skill damage instead.

Missionary HP Penalty

Missionaries physical weakness leaves them with only 70% of the ActHP that an equivalent level warrior would have.

  1. ActHPMissionary

= The ActHP value for the missionary class

= 0.7 * ActHP

= 0.7 * 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 13.069917 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Missionary Armor

Missionaries need to be somewhat nimble to make the holy gestures necessary to invoke their prayers. As such, they should be constrained on their choice of equipment and rely primarily on clothing. Overall, we would like missionaries to have 71% of the warrior's ActArmor from equipment:

  1. ActArmorMissionaryEq

= Contribution to ActArmor from equipment for the missionary class

  1. 0.71 * ActArmor

= 0.71 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 7100 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

To achieve this 71% value for ActArmorMissionaryEq, we are essentially allowing missionaries to choose armor for the head (9%) and body (33%), but restricting them to clothing for the remaining slots.

We also would like missionary's overall armor to be sqrt(10/7) greater than that of a warrior:

  1. ActArmorMissionary

= Value for ActArmor for the missionary class

  1. sqrt(10/7) * ActArmor

Therefore, the difference represents the armor that the missionary receives from skills:

  1. ActArmorMissionaryPrayer

= Contribution to ActArmor from prayers for the missionary class

= ActArmorMissionary - ActArmorMissionaryEq

= (sqrt(10/7) * ActArmor) - (0.71 * ActArmor)

= (sqrt(10/7) - 0.71) * ActArmor

= 0.485229 * ActArmor

= 0.485229 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 4852.29 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

Missionary Success Rates

The discussion for missionary success rate proceeds fairly closely to what was done previously for warlocks.

We again leave SimpOffSkill and SimpDefSkill alone. The higher ActArmor translates into a higher ActDef again:

  1. ActDefMissionary

= ActDef score for the missionary class

= SimpDefSkillMissionary * ActArmorMissionary

= (SimpDefSkill) * (sqrt(10/7) * ActArmor)

= sqrt(10/7) * (SimpDefSkill * ActArmor)

= sqrt(10/7) * ActDef

Using this value and solving for HitPercExponent:

Missionary hitting Warrior:

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * ActDef / (ActOff * (sqrt(10/7) * ActDef))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActDef))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))]

= log[ActOff * ActOff / (ActOff * (sqrt(10/7) * ActOff))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActOff))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))]

= log[1 * 1 / (1 * (sqrt(10/7) * 1))] / log[(1 / (1 + (sqrt(10/7) * 1))) / (1 / (1 + 1))]

= log[1/sqrt(10/7)] / log[(1 /(1 + sqrt(10/7))) / (1 / 2)]

= log[1/sqrt(10/7)] / log[2 /(1 + sqrt(10/7))]

= -0.07745/-0.04045

= 1.914745

By extension then:

HitPercab (missionary hitting warrior)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.914745

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))1.914745

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))1.914745

= 1.25 * (1/2)1.914745

= 33.1523%

Warrior hitting Missionary:

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * (sqrt(10/7) * ActDef) / (ActOff * ActDef)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActDef)))]

= log[ActOff * (sqrt(10/7) * ActOff) / (ActOff * ActOff)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActOff)))]

= log[1 * (sqrt(10/7) * 1) / (1 * 1)] / log[(1 / (1 + 1)) / (1 / (1 + (sqrt(10/7) * 1)))]

= log[sqrt(10/7)] / log[(1/2) / (1 / (1 + sqrt(10/7)))]

= log[sqrt(10/7)] / log[(1 + sqrt(10/7))/2]

= 0.07745/0.04045

= 1.914745

By extension then:

HitPercab (missionary hitting warrior)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.914745

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActDef)))1.914745

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (sqrt(10/7) * ActOff)))1.914745

= 1.25 * (1/(1+sqrt(10/7)))1.914745

= 27.7372%

Again, we see that the missionary's greater armor decreases the missionary's chance of being hit to 27.7% (compared to 31.25% had it been 2 warriors). Likewise, the missionary also hits a warrior in a fair-fight 33.2% of the time.

Missionary Damage

For the most part, we will make equivalent arguments as we did for warlocks. To satisfy the Power equation, damage will have to be raised. Since HP has a factor of 7/10 on it, and armor has been incremented by sqrt(10/7), this means the remaining factor is also sqrt(10/7):

  1. ActDamMissionary

= ActDam value for missionary class

  1. sqrt(10/7) * ActDam

  1. DamCapMissionary

= DamCap value for missionary class

  1. sqrt(10/7) * DamCap

Given that missionaries are solo-oriented, it makes sense to see them in a front-line role to some degree. We will split their damage evenly between melee and skills:

  1. WeaponDamageMissionary

= Value of SimpWeaponDamage for missionary class

= 50% of missionary damage inflicted

= 0.5 * sqrt(10/7) * DamCap

= 0.5 * sqrt(10/7) * (4/3 * SimpWeaponDamage)

= 2/3 * sqrt(10/7) * SimpWeaponDamage

= 0.796819 * SimpWeaponDamage

  1. SkillDamageMissionary

= Value of SkillDamage for missionary class

= 50% of missionary damage inflicted

= 0.5 * sqrt(10/7) * DamCap

= 0.5 * sqrt(10/7) * (4 * SkillDamage)

= 2 * sqrt(10/7) * SkillDamage

= 2.390457 * SkillDamage

The upshot of this is that we expect missionaries to be praying while they are fighting.

Since WeaponDamageMissionary is 79.7% that of SimpWeaponDamage, we must find a means to bring this about. Recalling that SimpWeaponDamage is comprised of WeaponDamExp and WeaponDamEq, we simply opt to manipulate the component piece appropriately. As WeaponDamEq is more a property of the weapon being used, we decide to roll the change into the other term entirely:

  1. WeaponDamExpMissionary

= Value of WeaponDamExp for the missionary class

= 0.796819 * WeaponDamExp

This effectively means that a missionary, using the same exact weapon as a warrior, will always do roughly 20% less damage with that weapon per swing.

Missionary Fight Scenarios

Since the changes for missionaries are not perfectly intuitive, I believe we should revisit the combat scenarios spreadsheet [(Spreadsheet 5.)]. I've put the missionary in red.

  1. Missionary Combat Scenarios

It is interesting to note that the changes manage to preserve the relationship between Power and SurvRnds. This is, of course, essential.

Secondly, note that a fair-fight occupies a constant 47.32 rounds at all levels. This compares with a fair-fight between warriors of 60 rounds.

Furthermore, the success rates for a fair-fight (against a warrior) becomes 27.74%/33.15%. Since skill success rates are roughly double these numbers, this implies that missionaries will have a 66.3% success rate with easy-skills in a fair fight.

  1. Missionary vs. Warrior Class; Defensive Properties

  1. Missionary vs. Warrior Class; Offensive Properties

As per the design, we notice that missionaries have higher potential damage (DamCap) and higher effective damage (ActDam).

Additionally, we see that missionary's weapon damage is roughly comparable to warriors. At L50, a successful round from a missionary yields 47.8 damage where a warrior would be doing 60.0.

Similarly, missionaries have higher skill damage. A L50 missionary will be doing 2.4 times the damage of a warrior for each successful skill use. Additionally, the missionary has a higher success rate (66.3% vs. 55.5%).

Missionary Skills

In general, a discussion of a class's skills is not an intrinsic part of the overall game design. The skills given to a class do more to help conceptualize it than they do to insure overall harmony and equality. However, I don't want to leave the class topic without throwing out some general ideas that came to mind while developing the numerical system.

Being that the missionary is defined as solo-oriented, it makes sense to grant missionaries a large number of directly offensive prayers. That is, the missionary possesses a great many prayers meant to be invoked upon the enemy to damage the enemy.

As we've also noted, the missionary needs a mechanism to protect him in terms of armor. We'll simply borrow a page from the casters and grant them some sort of automated “shield” (wrapped, of course, in appropriate clergy-based terminology rather than magic).

Likewise, the missionary needs the ability to hit more often and be hit less often, so some sort of prayer(s) will be required to bring this about.

In terms of healing prayers, the missionary probably has a reasonable ability to heal himself. However, given the solo-nature of the class, and the fact that healing-others is a non-primary area of focus, we should seriously de-emphasize the missionary's ability to heal other people. Clearly, healing is part of the preconceived definition of clergy people will have, but we should restrain ourselves as much as possible to give clerics an obvious role to play.

Similarly, the missionary is primarily solo and, as such, should not have strong prayers that enhance other's abilities to fight. Deity-inspired power-ups should remain mostly in a priest's bag of tricks.

Review of Missionary Class

The missionary is, in large part, a mix between caster and fighter. The missionary has some ability to invoke prayers, and is also expected to be a second- or third-rate fighter.

While the missionary has lower weapon damage, we've also stated that the missionary has the ability to hit more often (33.15% vs. 31.25%), and be hit less often (27.74% vs. 31.25%). In terms of just melee alone, the missionary compares relatively favorably.

Missionaries have fewer HPs (compared to warriors), but make up for it with the ability to throw around some meaningful prayers. This gives them great flexibility in combat.

The Priest Class

The priest class is a clergy-subtype conceived of as group-oriented and with a focus on offensive capabilities.

Priests will be (numerically) similar to missionaries over the first few levels, but around L20 and because of their group-orientation they will forego some degree of HP development to enhance their prayer damage capability instead.

Priests, like sorcerers, will employ largely indirect offensive maneuvers. Members of the priest's group will receive enhancements and be better at the things that they do because of the priest's prayers.

Priest's, in a one-on-one situation, will fair reasonably OK. In the early levels, they follow closely in the footsteps of missionaries, a class designed to succeed in the one-on-one. In the later levels their focus shifts toward helping others that fight in the same cause as the priest. This shift somewhat hampers a priest forced into a solo scenario. However, priests will have a reasonable number of HPs, and maintain some emphasis on melee fighting, and as a consequence should do fairly well.

Priests shine in group-situations and are designed exclusively with the intent of making the group as a whole more powerful and successful. Priests are also remarkably well rounded as they have some degree of focus on melee fighting, some minor ability to throw offensive prayers at the enemy, and a modest ability to heal group mates. This allows priests to serve in a backstop role for many other classes; or, to fill in for a group that finds itself completely lacking in terms of melee ability, spell casting or healing potential.

Priest HP Penalty

Similar to what was done for sorcerers, we will state that a priest has the HP of a missionary through L20, and thereafter, gains at half the rate as missionaries.

  1. ActHPPriest

= ActHP value for priests

= ActHPMissionary(up to L20) + 0.5 * max(ActHPMissionary - (ActHPMissionary at L20), 0)

Priest Armor

Priests will have equivalent armor as missionary's. The breakdown and distribution will be identical.

Priest Success Rate

Priest success rate will also be equivalent as missionary's.

Priest Damage

As before with sorcerers, the penalty imposed by the reduction in priest's HP must be reflected in an increase in priest's damage (compared to missionary's). This generalizes as:

  1. ActDamPriest

= Value of ActDam for priest class

= ActDamMissionary * (ActHPMissionary / ActHPPriest)

= ActDamMissionary * (ActHPMissionary / ActHPPriest)

= (sqrt(10/7) * ActDam) * (0.7 * ActHP) / ActHPPriest

= sqrt(10/7) * 0.7 * (ActHP/ActHPSorcerer) * ActDam

Likewise:

  1. DamCapPriest

= Value of DamCap for priest class

= DamCapMissionary * (ActHPMissionary / ActHPPriest)

= (sqrt(10/7) * DamCap) * (0.7 * ActHP) / ActHPPriest

= sqrt(10/7) * 0.7 * (ActHP/ActHPSorcerer) * DamCap

This is naturally the same as the values for missionary for the first 20 levels, but thereafter slowly increases faster and faster (as ActHPPriest is penalized).

  1. Priest Class vs. Warrior Class

Near the end of their careers, priests have ␀ the HP of an equivalent warrior.

The priest has roughly half the HP of the warrior by L50, however, this is counterbalanced by the priest's higher ActDam. On average, the priest is inflicting 2.085 times more damage per round as the warrior (46.3 vs. 22.2).

In terms of melee, it is interesting to note that by L50, the warrior and the priest are roughly comparable (69.8 to 60.0) in terms of raw damage. The priest is also hitting more often too (33.15% to 31.25%).

On the skill front, the priest is doing 3.5 times more damage per successful prayer as the warrior is getting from his skills. And again, the priest is more successful at succeeding at the prayers than is the warrior at his skills.

Priest Skills

The standard caveat about skills and this document applies.

Being group and offensive oriented, the priest's skills should be primarily focused on providing indirect benefits to other members in the party allowing them to do more damage or hit more often. That is to say, the “damage” calculated for the priest should really be converted into either a bonus to be applied to someone else in the group when hitting, or applied as letting someone else hit more successfully.

Having the skill damage be associated with direct attacks on the enemy (missionary) or with healing of the group's primary tank (cleric) might be permissible, but realize it is a secondary focus and detracts from the strengths of other class's abilities.

Priests do need the same armor enhancements as missionaries.

Likewise, as a portion of the priest's damage is melee related, priests will need weapon skills.

Being group-oriented, we can, to some degree, justify more group-protective and group-healing prayers than we could have for missionaries.

Priest Review

Priests are, above all else, extremely versatile. Being a clergy-subtype, they are by nature a combination fighter and caster. They have reasonably good armor, melee damage and skill damage. This makes them very well balanced and able to flesh out a group in many different ways.

However, priests do not excel in any particular field. They have lower HP than warriors, have modest restrictions on the armor they can wear, and don't have the massive damage from prayers that casters receive.

Priests, like the other clergy, are overall, well rounded.

The Cleric Class

The cleric class is a clergy-subtype conceived of as group-oriented and with leanings toward defensive prayers.

As defense is the cleric's primary focus, they typically take up the role of defending and healing their group. They have some offensive capability, but for the most part take little part in battle, preferring to concentrate on defense and restoration.

In a one-on-one scenario, the cleric is in for a battle of attrition. Having little in the way of offensive capabilities, the cleric's primary hope is to restore his own damage, while the enemy is slowly drained from what damage the cleric does manage to inflict.

The cleric is very desirable for a group though. Aiding defensively and restoring the primary hitters and tanks is what a cleric excels at. There are few fighters that do not recognize the advantage of these skills, and this puts the cleric in high-demand.

Clerics by the Numbers

For the most part, clerics are numerically identical to priests in everyway. The primary difference is in how they utilize their “damage”.

All formulas that apply for priests apply equally for clerics.

Cleric Skills

In general, a discussion of a class's skills is not an intrinsic part of the overall game design. The skills given to a class do more to help conceptualize it than they do to insure overall harmony and equality. However, I don't want to leave the class topic without throwing out some general ideas that came to mind while developing the numerical system.

Cleric skills concentrate primarily on the defense and restoration of the group. For the most part, this means they have a number of prayers designed to prevent others from being hit, and to restore the damage that does sneak through.

Clerics have a small assortment of direct-offensive prayers (missionary) and a handful of power-ups (cleric), but these are fairly restricted.

Clerics do require self-defensive prayers for their armor.

Likewise, clerics are moderately involved in the melee portion of a fight so need some weapon skills.

Rogue Classes

The rogue classes consist of those members of society that have difficulty conforming to society's rules. The rogue classes typically are weaker than fighters, and lack any training in magic or prayer. They hold their own primarily by not playing by the normal rules and using every trick and underhanded maneuver at their disposal to gain an edge.

Rogues come in two basic subtypes. Thieves are your basic solo rogue-class. Meanwhile, thugs represent a rogue that has opted to band with others to gain power and wealth.

The Thief Class

The thief class is a rogue-subclass designed to be evenly balanced and capable of playing solo.

Thieves, being a rogue class, will lack any distinction when it comes to combat numbers. They lack the physical stamina of the warriors, and are not strong enough to effectively use all types of armor. Likewise, they possess no intrinsic magic or prayer capability. However, they feel no dishonor about using certain moves that most fighter types shun.

Thief HP Penalty

As compared to warriors, thieves suffer a modest penalty on HP. Thieves will have 85% the ActHP of warriors.

  1. ActHPThief

= The ActHP value for the thief class

= 0.85 * ActHP

= 0.85 * 18.67131 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

= 15.87061 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902

Thief Armor

Thief's skills require a certain degree of nimbleness. As a consequence, thieves lean more toward easily flowing armor as opposed to heavy metal armors. Arbitrarily, we want thieves to have 82% the ActArmor as warriors:

  1. ActArmorThiefEq

= Contribution to ActArmor from equipment for the thief class

  1. 0.82 * ActArmor

= 0.82 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 8200 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

To achieve this 82% value for ActArmorThiefEq, we will essentially allow thieves to choose armor for the head (9%), body (33%), waist (12%) and back (10%).

Thieves, being more nimble, will also possess some natural skills that aid them in dodging more blows successfully. All in all, we would like thieves to have a total effective armor equivalent to 1.1 times that of warriors:

  1. ActArmorThief

= Value for ActArmor for the thief class

  1. 1.1 * ActArmor

Which implies:

  1. ActArmorThiefSkill

= Contribution to ActArmor from skills for the thief class

= ActArmorThief - ActArmorThiefEq

= (1.1 * ActArmor) - (0.82 * ActArmor)

= (1.1 - 0.82) * ActArmor

  1. 0.28 * ActArmor

Of course, the upshot of higher effective armor is a corresponding increase in the ActDef score:

  1. ActDefThief

= ActDef score for the thief class

= SimpDefSkillThief * ActArmorThief

= (SimpDefSkill) * (1.1 * ActArmor)

= 1.1 * (SimpDefSkill * ActArmor)

= 1.1 * ActDef

Thief Success Rate

Because of thief's higher armor, their success rates are slightly altered. Referring to the previous method for establishing HitPercExponent:

Thief hitting warrior:

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * ActDef / (ActOff * (1.1 * ActDef))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActDef))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))]

= log[ActOff * ActOff / (ActOff * (1.1 * ActOff))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActOff))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))]

= log[1 * 1 / (1 * (1.1 * 1))] / log[(1 / (1 + (1.1 * 1))) / (1 / (1 + 1))]

= log[1 / 1.1] / log[(1/2.1) / (1/2)]

= log[1/1.1] / log[2/2.1]

= -0.04139 / -0.02119

= 1.953471

By extension then:

HitPercab (thief hitting warrior)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.953471

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))1.953471

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff))1.953471

= 1.25 * (1/2)1.953471

= 32.2743%

Warrior hitting thief:

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * (1.1 * ActDef) / (ActOff * ActDef)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActDef)))]

= log[ActOff * (1.1 * ActOff) / (ActOff * ActOff)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActOff)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActOff)))]

= log[1 * (1.1 * 1) / (1 * 1)] / log[(1 / (1 + 1)) / (1 / (1 + (1.1 * 1)))]

= log[1.1] / log[(1 / 2) / (1 / (1 + 1.1))]

= log[1.1] / log[2.1 / 2]

= 0.041393 / 0.021189

= 1.953471

By extension then:

HitPercab (warrior hitting thief)

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))n

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))1.953471

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActDef)))1.953471

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (1.1 * ActOff)))1.953471

= 1.25 * (1/2.1) 1.953471

= 29.3403%

The lesson here is that the thief has a marginally superior hit rate (32.27% vs. the warrior's 31.25%), but the higher armor's true benefit is to lessen the chance of the thief of getting hit to 29.34% (vs. 31.25% for a warrior).

Thief Damage

To maintain the Power equation, the thief's damage will have to counterbalance the penalty on thief's HP and bonus on armor. Essentially:

Power = HP * Armor * Damage

Damage = Power / HP / Armor

Damage = 100% / 85% / 110%

Damage = 106.9519%

That is to say, thief damage will be about 7% higher in order to keep thieves at the same level of Power as warriors. Therefore:

  1. ActDamThief

= ActDam value for thief class

  1. 1.069519 * ActDam

  1. DamCapThief

= DamCap value for thief class

  1. 1.069519 * DamCap

Since we do not wish the thief class to be superior in regards to weapons (compared to warriors), we will declare that 70% of thief's damage is weapon related:

  1. WeaponDamageThief

= Value of SimpWeaponDamage for thief class

= 70% of thief damage inflicted

= 7/10 * DamCapThief

= 7/10 * 1.069519 * DamCap

= 7/10 * 1.069519 * (4/3 * SimpWeaponDamage)

= 14/15 * 1.069519 * SimpWeaponDamage

= 0.998217 * SimpWeaponDamage

As in the case of missionaries, a means to reduce thief's weapon damage needs to be determined:

  1. WeaponDamExpThief

= Value of WeaponDamExp for the thief class

= 0.998217 * WeaponDamExp

The upshot of this is that thieves do (within 1%) almost the same exact damage as a warrior when looking at weapons alone. Warriors will have a slight edge, but it is probably not worth speaking about.

Since WeaponDamageThief is established, we can proceed to assign the remaining damage for thieves to their skills:

  1. SkillDamageThief

= Value of SkillDamage for thief class

= 30% of thief damage inflicted

= 3/10 * 1.069519 * DamCap

= 3/10 * 1.069519 * (4 * SkillDamage)

= 6/5 * 1.069519 * SkillDamage

= 1.283422 * SkillDamage

Since thieves need slightly higher overall damage, and none of it is in their weapons, it rolls entirely into the thief's skills. Thief's skills do 28.3% more damage than an equivalent warrior's skills do.

Thief Fight Scenarios

Since the changes for thieves are not perfectly intuitive, I believe we should revisit the combat scenarios spreadsheet [(Spreadsheet 5.)]. I've put the thief in red.

  1. Thief Combat Scenarios

The lessons of this chart are about what we have come to expect. The Power and SurvRnds ratios are preserved. And the hit rates for a fair-fight are as indicated previously. Furthermore, fair-fights only occupy 54.3 rounds (compared to 60 for two warriors). This is due to the thief's higher damage, and the thief's lower HP.

  1. Thief vs. Warrior Class; Defensive Properties

Defensively speaking, thieves compare well to warriors. They have a few less HP overall, and their equipment-based armor is somewhat lacking, but they make up for some of this with skill-based defensive armor.

  1. Thief vs. Warrior Class; Offensive Properties

Offensively speaking, thieves are not that dissimilar to warriors either. They have equivalent weapon damage, and their skill damage is modestly superior.

Thief Skills

The standard disclaimer concerning skills and this document applies.

Numerically speaking for the most part, thieves are reasonably indistinguishable from warriors. Some numbers have been tweaked slightly, but no more so than what we have done for other classes. Thief's chief distinguishing factor will be their skills.

In non-combat aspects, thieves will have the to-be-expected assortment of skills for getting into and out of places without being seen, opening things that they are not supposed to, and otherwise doing thief-like things.

However, preconceptions about how thieves should behave in combat are less intuitive, other than to say that they probably use every (dirty) trick in the book. Naturally, their skills probably include backstabbing, throat cutting, sand-in-the-eyes and leg sweeps.

Additionally, it probably makes sense for thieves to be more acrobatic. Leaping, diving and rolling away from their opponent's blows in order to avoid being skewered seem a natural way for thieves to fight.

Naturally, thieves would not neglect the obvious melee skills such as kick. They might even extend upon them in a more-underhanded manner, e.g. kick-in-the-crotch. Obviously, we wouldn't want a generic kick from a thief to do more than that of a warrior, so unless there is an obvious reason why the thief is able to get more damage out of the blow, we should not simply have thieves using warrior skill do more damage.

Thief Review

As noted, thieves do not differ radically from warriors. They possess no magic or prayers, and are fairly similar in terms of effective armor, HP and damage.

For the most part, thieves will fill an important role-playing nitch for players that would like to explore the realm of roguery without suffering dramatic penalties. Looking strictly at combat, a thief and a warrior compare fairly evenly and players that opt to play thieves should not find themselves coming up short.

However, thief's broader range of non-combat skills probably makes them slightly more versatile than a warrior. Navigating traps, and performing other thief-like operations certainly gives them an edge over warriors. This is of course a subjective evaluation, and I must state that “game design” should probably not attempt to evaluate skills that lend to role-play for a given class.

Thief's combat skills should also be geared toward quick-strike attacks and/or hit-and-fade maneuvers. This is to say, the thief probably would attempt to slip up on an enemy, strike fast, and then disappear into the gloom, possibly repeating these steps over and over as long as possible. This is not to say that thieves shun the more traditional hack-and-slash style of the warriors. Thieves can certainly fight in pitched battles, but the hit-and-fade option is certainly a roleplay-worthy style as well.

The Thug Class

The thug class is a rogue-subclass designed with an orientation toward grouping.

Thugs have an assortment of thief-like non-combat skills, while their combat skills tend to be geared toward incapacitating an enemy to let the group slip by unmolested, or perhaps to weaken an enemy at a critical moment in a fight.

Thugs by the Numbers

As thugs are thought to be second-rate fighters and have no reason to not be fighting, we will NOT penalize their HP (compared to thieves). As a result, numerically speaking, thieves and thugs are identical.

Thug Skills

Thug skills will probably be fairly similar to thieves, especially over the first few levels. However, whereas thieves are going to specialize more on how to get the thief into, and out of, tight spaces by himself without being seen, the thug will be concentrating more on the direct, group-oriented approach.

For example, a thief might simply sneak by an enemy and be on his way, while the thug would need to sneak up on an enemy, knock him cold and thereby let his group slip past.

Likewise, while a thief might adopt the direct approach of simply slitting an enemy's throat and being done with it, the thug will be inclined to pin an enemy's hands (taking the thug out of action while he pins), leaving the enemy open for finishing blows by other members of the thief's group.

The thug, like the thief, also has the hit-and-fade options available as a fighting style (as well as the traditional hack-and-slash).

As a rule, the thug is simply a group-oriented thief.

The Monk Class

The monk class is in some ways a simple fighter subclass, although it deviates more drastically than the other fighter subclasses do, and, because of the roleplay nature of the class, is probably best thought of entirely separately.

From an RPG perspective, the monk class combines many of the martial arts moves favored by eastern cultures. Tradition has them fighting largely barehanded, and without the benefit of armor.

The “Traditional” Monk and Ramifications Thereof

In our previous handling of warriors, we established the above value for SwingsPerRound presuming that the warrior would have a single 1H weapon and be using a shield. Allowances and corrections were made for the use of two 1H weapons or a single 2H weapon.

Clearly, our image of monks does not include the use of shields, and it would be a bad assumption to make that a monk player “wants” to use a shield when they play.

Because of this, it is appropriate to relate the monk to a 2H-weapon using warrior. Likewise, all ParryEligible hits will land upon a 2H-weapon wielding player.

Monk Hit Points

Monks will have the same HP as warriors.

Monk Armor

Monks should be restricted to wearing only clothing. Since clothing has an ActArmor 50% that of armor, this means:

  1. ActArmorMonkEq

= Contribution to ActArmor from equipment for the monk class

  1. 0.5 * ActArmor

= 0.5 * 10000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

= 5000 * (level1.759815 + 13)0.163844

However, since monks are perceived of as nimble and agile, we will assume that monks possess some skills to raise their effective armor. This is somewhat the same argument as was made for thieves, however, we desire monks to be even more skilled at dodging. Recalling that ActArmorThiefSkill = 0.28 * ActArmor, we desire monk's value to be slightly better. Arbitrarily, we settle upon:

  1. ActArmorMonkSkill

= Contribution to ActArmor from skills for the monk class

  1. 0.4 * ActArmor

As a result:

  1. ActArmorMonk

= Value for ActArmor for the monk class

= ActArmorMonkEq + ActArmorMonk

= (0.5 * ActArmor) + (0.4 * ActArmor)

  1. 0.9 * ActArmor

Consequently, monk's total effective armor is 90% that of an equivalent warrior.

Monk Success Rate

As before, the monk's lower armor becomes a lower ActDef score, which in turn leads to different success rates. The process for calculating these follows directly from the previous classes, so I am skipping many intermediate steps:

  1. ActDefMonk

= ActDef score for the monk class

= 0.9 * ActDef

HitPercExponent (monk hitting warrior):

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * ActDef / (ActOff * (0.9 * ActDef))] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + (0.9 * ActDef))) / (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))]

= log[1/0.9] / log[2/1.9]

= 0.045757 / 0.022276

= 2.05408

HitPercab (monk hitting warrior):

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))2.05408

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef))2.05408

= 1.25 * (1/2)2.05408

= 30.1003%

HitPercExponent (warrior hitting monk):

= log[ActOffb * ActDefb / (ActOffa * ActDefa)] / log[(ActOffb / (ActOffb + ActDefa)) / (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))]

= log[ActOff * (0.9 * ActDef) / (ActOff * ActDef)] / log[(ActOff / (ActOff + ActDef)) / (ActOff / (ActOff + (0.9 * ActDef)))]

= log[0.9] / log[1.9/2]

= 0.045757 / 0.022276

= 2.05408

HitPercab (warrior hitting monk):

= 1.25 * (ActOffa / (ActOffa + ActDefb))2.05408

Presuming a fair-fight:

= 1.25 * (ActOff / (ActOff + (0.9 * ActDef)))2.05408

= 1.25 * (1/1.9)2.05408

= 33.4447%

However, these values ignore the shield-based correction we noted above. All ParryEligible blows will land on a monk. That is to say, 5/22 * RawMiss additional blows will land. For the above case:

warrior's RawMiss

= 100% - HitPercab

= 100% - 33.4447%

= 66.5553%

Of which, 5/22 hit:

= 5/22 * 66.5553%

= 15.1262%

This means, in total, the monk is hit 48.5709% of the time in a fair-fight.

Monk Damage

Following reasoning established for other classes, the reduction in monk's armor must be balanced by a corresponding rise in damage.

Additionally, we need to account for the barehand correction. In theory, this barehand correction would simply mirror the damage correction we made for 2H-weapons (i.e. it would be OffHandMultiplier).

Therefore:

  1. ActDamMonk

= ActDam value for monk class

= ActDam * (correction due to HP) * (correction for barehand)

= ActDam * (1/0.9) * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

= ActDam * (1.1111) * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

= 1.1111 * ActDam * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

  1. DamCapMonk

= DamCap value for monk class

= 1.1111 * DamCap * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

This damage will be equally distributed between melee and skills. Hence:

  1. MeleeDamageMonk

= Value of SimpWeaponDamage for monk class

  1. 1.1111 * SimpWeaponDamage * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

  1. SkillDamageMonk

= Value of SkillDamage for monk class

= 1.1111 * SkillDamage * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)

Monk Fight Scenarios

Since the changes for monks are not perfectly intuitive, I believe we should revisit the combat scenarios spreadsheet [(Spreadsheet 5.)]. I've put the monk in red.

Note: For comparison with the other combat scenarios, this presumes the monk is shield-using and therefore DamCap and the HitPercab values are not what we would expect to see with a truly barehand monk]

  1. Monk Combat Scenarios

By now, the conclusions to be derived from this data should be fairly apparent. The most interesting is that fair-fights occupy 38.06 rounds.

One new quirk is introduced by the barehand correction though. We can see how the value for DamCapMonk is changing based on the level of the victim. The fair-fight value is 1.5X more than the equivalent warrior. In the later cases, where the victim is of lower level, DamCapMonk is greater than it was for the same level monk in a fair-fight.

Refining Monk Barehand Damage

Since monks are defined as being masters of barehand fighting, we should delve a bit deeper into this concept. Conceptually, we would like monks to have a flurry of attacks, perhaps twice the number of swings, as a warrior would receive in a single round. The upshot of this decision is that monks have their own values for the number of attacks per round and the damage per attack.

Clearly, the two terms must combine (product) to form MeleeDamageMonk. Additionally, we would like SwingsPerRoundMonk to be 5.0 at L50 (an arbitrary boundary condition).

With these constraints in mind, and with a bit of manipulation:

  1. SwingsPerRoundMonk

= the SwingsPerRound equation for the monk class

= constant * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

The boundary condition is used to solve for the constant:

= [5.0/(sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk) @ L50)] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/(sqrt(1.1111 * SimpWeaponDamage * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier)) @ L50)] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

We will assume the constant is based on a fair-fight, which makes OffHandMultiplier=0.5:

= [5.0/sqrt(1.1111 * SimpWeaponDamage@L50 * (1.0 + 0.5)] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/sqrt(1.6667 * SimpWeaponDamage@L50] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/sqrt(1.6667 * (0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902)@L50] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/sqrt(1.244754 * (501.759815 + 13)0.635902)] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/sqrt(100)] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

= [5.0/10.0] * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

  1. 0.5 * sqrt(MeleeDamageMonk)

If we further assume that the number of swings a monk gets does not depend on the level difference, we can again assume a fair fight, and simplify the sqrt() term further:

= 0.5 * sqrt(1.1111 * SimpWeaponDamage * (1.0 + OffHandMultiplier))

= 0.5 * sqrt(1.1111 * SimpWeaponDamage * 1.5)

= 0.5 * sqrt(1.6667 * SimpWeaponDamage)

= 0.5 * sqrt(1.6667) * sqrt(SimpWeaponDamage)

= 0.5 * sqrt(1.6667) * sqrt(SimpWeaponDamage)

  1. 0.645497 * sqrt(SimpWeaponDamage)

= 0.645497 * sqrt(0.74685 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.635902)

= 0.645497 * sqrt(0.74685) * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.317951

= 0.557843 * ((level)1.759815 + 13)0.317951

Knowing this, then it is easy to invert the function and arrive at:

  1. MeleeDamPerSwingMonk

= The equivalent to WepDamPerSwing for the monk class

= MeleeDamageMonk / SwingsPerRoundMonk

We should avoid simplifying this more mathematically as MeleeDamageMonk depends on the levels of the combatants, whereas SwingsPerRoundMonk does not.

We can therefore show:

  1. SwingsPerRoundMonk and MeleeDamPerSwingMonk versus Level (fair-fights)

As stated previously, the monk always has a higher overall damage capacity.

During the early level, the monk is swinging fairly infrequently, although doing more damage per successful hit than an equivalent warrior. Around L10, this situation reverses itself and the monk begins to swing more often than the warrior, however, the per-hit amount is not as great.

Monk PCs will approach having 5.0 attacks per round, as desired, although the increase with each successive level is less and less. Monk mobs might receive 8+ attacks per round, which is quite a bit, but not overly excessive.

If a Monk were to Use a Shield

Obviously, the barehand correction on damage that we made above complicates monks somewhat. While we did the right thing by equating the monk to the 2H-weapon using warrior for damage, it complicates comparisons somewhat.

If we were to try to compare the monk to our more traditional view of a warrior, we would have to think of the monk using a shield. Obviously, by using a shield, the monk would lose the use of one hand and this would cut SwingsPerRoundMonk by 1/3 (primary hand gets 2/3 of all attacks, secondary gets 1/3). Consequently, damage would also be 2/3 as great as well.

Monk “Specialization”

Monks, because of their specialized melee, lack the “specialization skills” that increase the number of attacks that other classes receive. However, since we are allowing for SwingsPerRoundMonk to be increasing in some fashion, we are simply replacing specialization with some other skill for monks. There is no need for monks to have a separate specialization skill as whatever skill(s) control the increase of SwingsPerRoundMonk already handles this feature.

Monk Comparison

  1. Monk vs. Warrior Class; Defensive Properties

  1. Monk vs. Warrior Class; Offensive Properties

What Monks Are Not

Because monks are typically thought of in terms of eastern cultures and people's perceptions tend to vary, it is probably worthwhile to diverge briefly and talk about what aspects of eastern culture the class is not attempting to capture. In the course of this discussion, certain alternative classes may be mentioned. These classes are, of course, viable in their own right, although this document does not attempt to refine these quasi-classes.

First off, the monk class is not a thief subtype. While “ninjas” are appropriately eastern, they are distinct from monks. Yes, both monks and ninjas wear light armor or clothing and often are well trained in hand-to-hand combat, but acts of stealth and attack that characterize ninjas do not properly belong in a monk class.

Secondly, monks are not weapons masters. While they certainly will use weapons from time to time, we should avoid making them into “samurai”. Clearly, martial-art weapons like bo-sticks, numchucks and the like would be apropos for monks, but the focus of the monk should be to use bare hand attacks as much as possible. Likewise, monks tend to forego heavy armor, which would also be the hallmark of a “samurai”.

Finally, while oriental culture still is imbued with vast amounts of mysticism (acupuncture, chi, yin/yang, etc.), our intention is not to create a “magi”. Monks would certainly have different forms of knowledge at their disposal, some of which might resemble magic, but we should restrain ourselves and keep the class fairly firmly rooted in the natural world.

Monk Skills

The standard disclaimer concerning skills and this document applies.

Monk skills should probably in the footsteps of various forms of martial arts. Moves from kung fu, judo, jujitsu, etc. should all be represented. In fact, any bare hand maneuver conceivable is probably fair game.

Although such arts typically involve numerous, fast attacks, it is probably not feasible to have monks use skills that occupy 1-round apiece due to typing speeds, lag, etc. However, since most of these arts also teach discipline, it may be appropriate to create “combinations” of moves, each step of which takes only a round, but requires multiple-rounds to complete. That is, a kick-kick-punch combination in which they kick in the first 2 rounds, and punch in the third could be conceived of. Ideally, each step (each kick, each punch) would have its own success and damage checks, and the whole process (the 3 round duration move) would be executed with a single command.

Lastly, since monks have a degree of mysticism about them, granting them some innate self-healing abilities is probably appropriate. Obviously, we do not seek to give monks any significant magical/spiritual qualities, yet some healing ability seems to be part of people's preconception for a monk class so should be factored in.

As we previously pointed out, having eliminated “ninja” (eastern thief), “samurai” (eastern `warrior') and “magi” (eastern magician) traits from the monk, and by applying some basic healing powers in the class, this sets the monk up as more of an eastern-clergy than an eastern-warrior. Given that our own definition of missionaries makes them fairly good replacements for warriors, it may be worthwhile to maintain this fact. However, I think if monks are declared as officially a clergy-subclass rather than as a fighter-subclass, there would be numerous complaints, despite the obvious overlaps.

Monk Review

As we have seen, monks do not differ dramatically from warriors in the basic numbers used. HP is an exact match, and armor and damage are roughly 10% different.

However, looking only at the sheer numbers conceals the role-play alterations. Use of bare-hand attacks as opposed to weapon use is a significant change. Likewise, by being restricted to clothing monks will appear to suffer dramatic penalties on armor although skills largely make up for this. Also, by adding martial-arts moves, monks will have radically different skills at their disposal.

The upshot is that monks become an effective alternative to warriors for a player that wishes to roleplay (or experiment with) such a character.

The Ranger Class

Rangers are another roleplay specialized class that is for the most part a fighter-subclass when looking purely at the numbers.

The traditional role of the ranger is that of woodsman fighter. Rangers typically are quite knowledgeable about nature, and are quite capable of creating various creations out of the natural surroundings.

Rangers typically forego the heavy battle-armors of other fighter-subtypes opting for more simple leathers and the like. Traditionally, rangers also shun metallic armor.

Rangers by the Numbers

For all practical purposes, rangers will be numerically equivalent to warriors. Changes for this class will be largely cosmetic and skills-oriented.

Note that I am not imposing a numeric armor restriction on rangers. That is to say, we presume that rangers are wearing a complete set of “armor”, however we will restrict them from using “armor” that is metallic or otherwise anti-ranger.

Ranger Skills

Rangers possess all the basic combat skills that apply for warriors and other fighter-subclasses. Similarly, there is little compelling reason not to allow rangers from training any of the advanced warrior skills. However, we should keep in mind that rangers should be distinct from the basic warrior, thus some sort of tradeoff should occur between advanced ranger-only skills and the more typical advanced-warrior skills.

Typically, rangers have an affinity for bows. It is highly appropriate to give rangers every advantage (marksmanship, range, etc.) over other classes where ranged-combat is concerned.

Rangers, being oriented toward the great outdoors, also tend to possess the basic skills necessary for hunting and gathering. This probably includes certain thief-crossover skills like concealment, hiding, stalking and ambush, as these are all necessary for gathering fresh game. However, these skills should be de-emphasized and kept in the context of hunting for game in the forest rather than assassinating someone.

Since rangers are nature-oriented, they are generally knowledgeable about natural remedies and such. We should avoid giving rangers blatantly magical skills, but some ability to create salves and ointments to deal with an assortment of simple day-to-day problems probably exists for the ranger.

The Crusader Class

[Note: As this document is geared with a global audience in mind, I am opting to present the class as “Crusader” in order to avoid confusion about the name. Grimhaven, for some years, has called this class “Deikhan” and this will not be changing. As people unfamiliar with Grimhaven would not understand the meaning of “Deikhan”, I decided to use the more generic term here for clarity.]

The crusader class is yet another roleplay-oriented, fighter-subclass. The class is primarily a “religious” warrior. That is to say, it is a warrior that has taken up a religious cause and fights (or defends) against enemies of the faith. Typically, the deity whom they follow blesses crusaders and crusaders have an assortment of deity-inspired abilities.

Crusaders have a compelling need to avoid dishonoring themselves or their cause. This imposes some constraints on what actions they should and should not be allowed to perform. Or more properly, certain actions, while technically permitted, should exact a high spiritual cost (and/or deity disfavor) until proper penance is undergone.

Crusaders by the Numbers

Numerically speaking, crusaders will be equivalent to warriors.

Crusader Skills

Crusaders have the normal assortment of basic warrior skills. Like rangers, crusaders should also be permitted the advanced learning of warriors, but at the cost of foregoing certain of their crusader-only talents.

As defenders of the faith, crusaders are naturally drawn to “holy” weapons. Such a holy weapon should probably figure prominently in the crusader's career. Certainly, the acquisition of holy weapons is a major achievement and necessary event for the crusader to partake in, and it seems a natural extension to make the holy weapon a catalyst for some of the deity-actions to occur through.

Deities typically provide modest protections and enhancements for their crusaders to use in the act of fighting against the enemies of the faith. Care should be taken to keep from intruding too far into the realm of the clergy, but a variety of simple (and probably self-only) prayers should be obtainable.

Typically, crusaders are the masters of mounted combat. Every advantage should be afforded to crusaders when fighting from atop a steed. Likewise, crusaders should probably have a variety of skills oriented toward finding and maintaining an appropriate mount for their holy war.

Miscellaneous Commentary on Class-Related Concepts

Class Conversion

We have a number of classes that diverge from another class at a certain point in the career. For example, mages and sorcerers are equivalent to warlocks in the early levels. Priests and clerics deviate from missionaries in the same way.

Since the class is numerically (and probably skill-wise) identical, there is no compelling reason to force the player to decide their career at the outset. In fact, allowing fewer initial class choices simplifies the life of a newbie to some degree. However, this does require that players have the ability to “convert” to the other classes.

I will refrain from expanding on this idea in depth. Suffice to say that if conversion were adopted, a player would play a “clergyman” for the first few levels. At some critical point in the clergyman's career, they would be forced to decide whether to become a true missionary, a priest, or a cleric.

For the warrior/bodyguard/mercenary, missionary/cleric/priest, warlock/mage/sorcerer combos, this offers obvious ideas. Before leaving the subject, I should also point out that crusaders need a “cause” to fight in, and it might be role-play advantageous to have crusaders form by “converting” from a warrior at some critical point in the player's career.

Multi-Class

[Grimhaven has had an on-again, off-again history of supporting multi-class. Since the topic will doubtless come up, I am addressing it.]

During the development of the above classes, I realized that there would be no good way of creating multi-classed characters.

Obviously, certain combinations would conflict just on play-style. For example, a sorcerer (offensive-group caster) and a bodyguard (defensive-group fighter) would have competing visions, as one is oriented toward attack, and other defense.

Likewise, the traditional method of simply averaging numbers would get fairly messy. Sure, we could assign the average HP for the two classes, but for things like AC, how do you impose the average for a warlock/warrior fairly? Half the equipment of a warlock/warrior must be cloth and the other may be armor? The clumsiness of the equipment system is strained enough for single-class characters without imposing additional problems on it.

Furthermore, because some classes emphasize melee over skill, this creates some basic imbalances. Warlocks and warriors fight in distinctively different ways (one goes toe-to-toe, the other engages with spells from a distance). No obvious combination of the two exists for a multi-class, and we'd probably be forced to make the multi choose to go into a pure warrior-combat-mode, or warlock-combat-mode. Such a multi would either have to slug it out with a weapon, or opt for the spells-approach.

Not to mention, the simple “average the two” method for creating a multi-class stats would not yield good values according to the Power equation. For example, imagine that a warrior has 3 qualities (e.g. HP, dam and AC), which we rate at 1.0, 1.0, and 1.0. When we multiply together, the warrior's “power” is 1.0. Another class might have ratings of 2.0, 1.0 and 0.5, which also yielded a “power” of 1.0 when multiplied together. Taking simple averages would give: 1.5, 1.0 and 0.75 for the 3 qualities and the product of these three numbers does not give us our desired power.

Realizing all of the problems that multi-class would present, I am encouraging game designers to give serious thought to such combination classes. In point of fact, the amount of thinking that ought to go into the problem is probably greater than the effort it would take to create a reasonable “hybrid” single-class. That is to say, rather than naively allowing a warlock/warrior to be created and solving the various problems, we would be better off devising an entirely new (single) class, solving the math problems, and adding on appropriate aspects of the two original classes to position this new class midway between the other two classes.

Class for Mobs

Given that a number of our classes are oriented toward a group-play-style, we should keep this in mind when treating the class for mobs. Unless the game is sufficiently advanced that mobs form groups and use synergy just like players, mobs should probably NOT adopt the group-oriented classes (sorcerer, mage, priest, cleric, thug, mercenary, bodyguard). Obviously, we have tried to make the class equivalent to the solo-variety class. However, we must be realistic about things and acknowledge that lower HP and skills oriented toward aiding a (non-existent) group would make such a mob too juicy a target for players not to exploit.

Adjustments to Rounds Lost Equations

We have previously discussed scenarios in which a character opts to use a skill that does not damage an opponent, but instead causes the victim to lose a certain number of rounds of melee blows, skill attempts, or both. The changes made for classes complicate the previous setup somewhat.

Taking another look at BalancedCombat:

ActHPa * ActDama = ActHPb * ActDamb

If A uses a skill as a hindrance, they are effectively reducing their ActDam. For BalancedCombat to work out, the hindrance must amount to the same penalty on the other side.

For instance, let's assume I am a warrior so that I am getting 25% of my damage from my skills. If I hinder my enemy, BalancedCombat states that I trade my skill damage to block 25% of the enemy's ActDam. A 4-round skill will keep an enemy from doing anything (melee and skills) for 1 full round. Let's further state that my enemy is a missionary, so that they are getting 50% of damage from melee and 50% from skills. That 4-round hindrance skill would amount to blocking 2-rounds of melee, or 2-rounds of skills.

We can generalize this by saying that:

  1. NumRndsBlocked

= Number of rounds lost by victim due to use of a hindrance skill

= (percentage of my ActDam that skills represent) / (percentage of victim's ActDam that thing hindered represents)

We also need to account for the difficulty of the skill by adding in a term using MaxSkillPerc, and if we do so, we can see the previously determined terms for MeleeRoundsLostSkill, FullRoundsLostSkill, and SkillRoundsLostSkill. However, this more generalized equation deals with the fact that the emphasis on damage from skill varies from class to class.

Characteristics

Having enhanced our definition of a character by adding class, we now proceed to add characteristics to our character. Characteristics represent the vital statistics of a player and help to individualize a person. For example, not all warriors are the same, some are stronger than others, some are more agile, some use their wits, and so on. Characteristics attempt to capture this concept and provides for some customization and fine-tuning.

Combat Characteristics

As we have a very well established combat system, we are able to speak logically about certain aspects that would play an important part in our overall game design. These would include:

Constitution: impacting a person's ActHP

Might: impacting a person's DamCap via DamagePerSwing (or damage per skill)

Speed: impacting a person's DamCap via SwingsPerRound (or skills per round)

Agility: impacting HitPercab via ActArmor

Finesse: impacting HitPercab via ActFinesse

Obviously, if characteristics give someone 10% more ActHP, than the inverse penalty must also apply. That character would need a lower DamCap, hit less often, or is hit more often in order to preserve BalancedCombat.

Obviously, we have a mathematical need to change the above factors (regardless of class). However, since some classes favor melee over skill (or converse), we need characteristics that generalize the intention. A “mighty” warrior will hit harder with their weapon, while a “mighty” sorcerer will cast more powerful spells. We do not want any class thinking that any of the combat characteristics are unnecessary for their class.

Other Characteristics

For historical reasons, other characteristics have also come into existence. Since these have no impact on the combat system, we can pretty much set them to one side and just make note of their existence.

Strength: Physical brawn indicating how much weight you can carry

Dexterity: Indicates how much volume can be manipulated

Intelligence: Makes it possible to learn more skills

Wisdom: Allows greater learning in known skills

Clearly, we do not want to allow players to trade off their “other” characteristics for “combat” characteristics, as this would impact Power.

Characteristics to Avoid

Some game designs provide additional characteristics. While some of these could be classified as “other characteristics”, I think it is better if they are simply avoided.

Charisma: A person's natural ability to influence people. This is almost impossible to represent in an RPG. A player's ability to influence other PCs is based on the real person, not the game characteristic.

Karma/Luck: Typically, this affects things like saving throws, etc. In our system, failing the HitPercab roll for a skill is a “save” so we should not have a separate characteristic for this event.

Perception: Ability to notice things. This is almost impossible to represent well, as it causes us to “hide” things from some people and not others thereby aggravating some players.

Misconceptions about Characteristics

The complexity of a fantasy RPG greatly complicates characteristics. Not only will we have to deal with standard humans, but we will often have mythical creatures as well.

How do we relate the “strength” of an ogre to that of a giant and also handle humans as well? Obviously, at some point we need to establish absolute hard limits at both ends. Such and such a value is the strength of the ultra-giant, and this value is what the feeble kitten has. Somewhere within those outside limits is what we expect typical humans to possess.

Defining the range between the absolute min and max values is somewhat problematic. Obviously, we need a fairly large range, especially given that players will only occupy a narrow band of the total. However, too large a spread causes fairly bad things to happen when synergy is taken into account. For example, lets say I choose a characteristic setup that gives me twice the HP, and half the damage. If someone else elects half the HP and twice the damage, we could group together and be quite more powerful than two evenly balanced players.

Characteristic System Overview

For historical reasons, characteristics tend to be geared toward a 3-18 system. Unfortunately, such numbers have numerous problems. Firstly, there are only 16 possible values meaning the resolution is very coarse. Secondly, if humans are 3-18, what values apply for non-humans? We would presume that the human values are in the middle of the full range, so we either have a complete range of 0-21 or have negative values sometimes.

Instead, let us devise a 0-200 system. Humans will be in the range 66-134, with a score of 100 being assumed to be average. This leaves adequate space above and below to place the other creatures that inhabit our game.

We will need to insure that the full range (66-134) for humans creates a noticeable change in the appropriate value. Since we will most likely be concealing the actual numbers used for things like armor, damage etc, we need to be sure that players will notice the difference that changing their characteristics make.

Thus, we stipulate that min-human (66) should be 2/3 the value of avg-human (100). Because the change has to be inverted for the other direction, a max-human (134) stat would be 1.5 the value of avg-human. With a little math, we see that a max-human is 2.25X (= 1.5/0.67) better than a min-human stat.

Relationship Between a Characteristic and the Affected Value

If we generalize this logic, we are simply saying that every 33.333-point (= 100/3) change in characteristic results in a 1.5X factor on what it affects. Mathematically, this is a simple geometric growth problem. Each successive point of characteristic is a certain (constant) percentage change increase in the value. The percentage change can be calculated by solving:

StatPercChange33.3333 = 1.5

That is to say, what is the percentage change per point required that causes my value to grow to 1.5X my current value over 100/3 points? The solution is simply:

  1. StatPercChange

= Percentage change in value affected per point of characteristic change

= 1.5(1/33.3333)

= 1.5(3/100)

  1. 1.012238

Therefore, each successive point of stat means the value of what it affects changes by 1.2238%.

If we preserve the inverse relationship, than we are free to trade points in characteristics evenly. That is, being an average person, I might start with a 100 in con and speed. I could choose to reduce con to 66, freeing up 34 (100-66) points, bringing speed up to 134 (100+34). As a result, I get 2/3 (approximately) the ActHP, but possess 1.5 (approximately) the SwingsPerRound. My HP has decreased but my damage has risen and BalancedCombat is maintained.

If instead, I might opt to take only 17 points from con for speed. Using StatPercChange, this means that ActHP suffers by:

(1/StatPercChange)17 = (1/1.012238)17 = 0.813193

And SwingsPerRound increases by:

(StatPercChange)17 = (1.012238)17 = 1.229721

Thus, if we presume that our “typical” value represents a characteristic of value 100, we can calculate the correction by taking StatPercChange to a power where the power is the number of points away from 100 that the actual characteristic is. If my characteristic is n points above 100, the affected value is multiplied by StatPercChangen. If my characteristic is n points below 100, the affected value is multiplied by (1/StatPercChange)n.

Race and Characteristics

As we have previously noted, a fantasy RPG provides a numerous and varied number of inhabitants. Fortunately, our system accounts for this. We are free to create creatures with characteristics anywhere in our range (or even beyond it, but this should probably be avoided).

However, because the combat characteristics impact Power, we need to insure that the benefits are balanced by detriments. If we assume that ogre might is centered on a value of 140, then other ogre combat stats will have to absorb a 40 point penalty (perhaps speed is only 60).

Except for the constraint of a 100 average value for combat characteristics, any race may be created.

Characteristics System in Action

The net effect of this system is that the game designer is free to set the average value for each characteristic on a race-by-race basis. Additionally, the designer can define a range of values around this average. For example, human strength is 100+-33 (range of 67-133), whereas ogre strength is 140+-20 (range of 120-160). Thus, the game designer has vast controls over the macroscopic racial picture in terms of characteristics.

Within the range for each stat, each PC is free to tweak their individual preferences. Perhaps the player wants +20 might and -20 finesse. These adjustments are applied to the average values (set by the designer) to yield the person's actual characteristic. Obviously, since gnome's racial might differs from cyclop's racial might, a cyclops PC with +20 might will not be the same as a gnome PC with +20 might. The player has the final decision about what race to play, and can fine tune based on how they wish to play their character.

Movement, Mana and Piety

As we have established that combat is the mechanism in which people gain experience and advance, it is appropriate for us to take a close look at combat and insure that it will occur in the way that we intend for it. Obviously, ActHP is constructed so that combat is balanced and requires the appropriate number of rounds.

But, to a very large extent, we assume that fair-fights occur and shuffle dissimilar level fights to the back of our minds. In our construction of MobXP, we made these values grow slightly faster than was dictated so as to encourage players to fight the largest creature that they could comfortably do.

However, we also want to discourage the act of “plowing” where a player simply assaults large numbers of inferior foes. Clearly, there is little real risk in such action. The player takes minimal damage from each enemy, and can, most likely, stop at the point that their health gets low. Obviously, attacking inferior foes will result in less XP and wealth due to how those values are calculated, but this doesn't seem to sufficiently dissuade players from the activity.

As game designers, we do not want high-level players sweeping our newbie areas clean of enemies as this limits what is available for low-levels to fight. Thus, we build on the ideas of ActHP in order to place other limits on how combat will occur.

Rationalizing Movement Limitations

Just as players face an ActHP induced, medical limitation on how long they may remain in combat, they should also face an endurance limitation. Obviously, the drawbacks are not as severe. Running out of HP entails death or unconsciousness, where running out of movement leaves you unable to continue fighting.
