Looking again at (Spreadsheet 5.) and the related formulas, we remember that the typical fair-fight lasts around 60 rounds. Interestingly, if I were to fight someone of half my power, my enemy would last for about 40 SurvRnds. Obviously, I could kill two such foes, although it would take me about 80 rounds. More analysis of (Spreadsheet 5.) shows that as the plowing gets worse and worse (higher ratios of SurvRnds), the total number of rounds to kill all the foes necessary to equate to a single fair-fight also lengthens.

The ramification of this is that we can discourage plowing by using movement to limit how long a person can fight for. For example, let's say that attacking a creature at 1/3 my Power yields SurvRnds of 35 rounds. To make up the XP of a single fair-fight, I would have to fight 3 such mobs (total of 105 rounds of combat). Clearly, if my movement ran out around round 80, this strategy would not work. Obviously, I would still be able to plow, but I would still need to regenerate moves after about two fights.

Prelude to ActMove

Our target is to have ActMove run out after 75 or so rounds. However, there are a few things to keep in mind before continuing on.

First, players will expect ActMove to increase with level and age. Since SurvRnds remains constant, the only way that this can happen is if the associated cost per round also rises with level. That is to say, a higher-level expends more (absolute) ActMove per round of combat than a lower-level player, but has a higher total as well.

Secondly, ActMove tends to get used for a variety of miscellaneous uses. Various skills use movement to perform, and of course travel also consumes a small amount per step. For the most part, we don't want these miscellaneous uses to significantly impact the combat use of ActMove; therefore we need to make them fairly inexpensive as compared to the cost of combat.

Thirdly, we need the ActMove limitation to apply regardless of character class. The obvious implementation for ActMove cost is to apply a movement cost per weapon swing, but we need to remember that a casting class must also be limited to a set duration of combat in the same manner. If we decide that the act of casting does not require as much cost in terms of ActMove as melee combat does, than the consequence that must be applied is that casters do not have as great a total ActMove as fighters. Both classes must be equally limited in terms of total duration in combat.

Taken all together, it is probably simplest to devise simple costs for each action, and then to award a player the total ActMove appropriate to properly limit them based on those costs.

Movement Cost Per Step

On the whole, we should assume that a player uses around 3 movement per step and will travel multiple steps between combats.

Since the dynamics of the game usually has low-level mobs found close together, and high-level mobs spread apart, the higher-level players are forced to travel further between fights. There is a natural rise with level of this cost.

All in all, we will assume that newbies travel 2-3 steps between fights and L50s must go 100. Mathematically, this suggests:

  1. AvgMoveCostPerStep

= Typical cost in movement per room traveled

  1. 3

  1. AvgRoomsTraveled

= Typical number of rooms traveled between fights

  1. 2 * level

  1. ActMoveMovement

= Component of ActMove awarded to cover movement related costs

= AvgMoveCostPerStep * AvgRoomsTraveled

= (3) * (2 * level)

  1. 6 * level

Movement Cost Per Weapon Swing

Clearly, swinging a weapon is an exhausting activity, especially as compared to simple movement. Moreover, as noted earlier, as game designers, we really don't care about limiting travel, but limiting combat is another matter. Therefore, we want the cost per swing to be the dominant factor to take into account.

As noted previously, to justify giving out more movement points as a person level, we must make the cost level based.

We must realize that players will not always do as the mathematical model suggests. While we assume that L10 players will use L10 weapons and do L10 damage, in the real world things are another matter. We will almost certainly see players use weapons of varying level.

In such a situation, the player will be doing some different amount of damage than predicted. Since we previously validated the Power equation for a person doing a different amount of damage, we can make a logical deduction. If the movement cost of combat is related to damage in some manner, than a person that swaps weapons (thus changing damage and movement costs) is still OK.

That is to say, players expect that it requires less endurance to swing a lower level sword than a higher one. If we don't correlate damage and movement costs, than we risk a situation in which a player could effectively plow (perhaps a high-level player using low-level weapons). We avoid this possibility by correlating damage and movement cost.

Furthermore, since we are dealing with a per swing amount, rather than a per round amount, it makes sense to use DamagePerSwing rather than DamCap.

  1. ActMovePerSwing

= Typical movement cost per swing of a weapon

= DamagePerSwing / 2

Since we know we want to allow for 75 rounds of combat total, and previously calculated SwingsPerRound, we establish:

  1. ActMoveMelee

= Component of ActMove awarded to cover melee combat

= 75 * SwingsPerRound * ActMovePerSwing

We should not that SwingsPerRound is a fairly ugly, level-based function built around the idea of specializing in a weapon later in the career. Since we are using it here, this means that ActMoveMelee will also grow in weird ways once specializing is assumed to have begun.

Movement Cost for Melee and the Off-Hand

Interestingly, the quirk of combat system as it pertains to use of the second hand factor away nicely. Were a person to dual wield, they would receive extra swings with their offhand related to SwingsPerRound and OffHandMultiplier. Conveniently, while the foe dies faster from the extra damage, this is in exact proportion to the extra SwingsPerRound. That is to say, regardless of how many hands you use to fight with, it still takes the same total number of swing attempts to kill a mob. Dual wielding simply accelerates the combat, but our movement constraint need not change at all.

However, an adjustment is required for the use of 2H-weapons. Because 2H-weapons use the same total number of swings as 1H-weapons, but do more damage, we need to account for this. Fortunately, we simply have to raise the movement cost per swing by the same amount as the damage, so:

  1. ActMovePerSwing2H

= Typical movement cost per swing of a 2H-weapon

= ActMovePerSwing * (1 + OffHandMultiplier)

Unfortunately, this latter equation means that the per-swing-movement-cost of a 2H-weapon depends on the level of the enemy (due to OffHandMultiplier). Like the other quirks due to OffHandMultiplier, this cannot be helped. Simply put, when fighting a superior foe, the extra damage from the off-hand drops, but so does the movement cost per swing.

Movement Cost for Skills

Similar arguments for skill use apply, and we will arbitrarily state that skills should have:

  1. ActMovePerSkillRound

= Typical movement cost for a skill (per round)

= DamCap / 4

As we still want a target of total movement covering 75 rounds, this results in:

  1. ActMoveSkill

= Component of ActMove awarded to cover skill-based combat

= 75 * ActMovePerSkillRound

Movement Cost for Spells

While spells and prayers are technically “skills”, it is likely that people will have a perception that they require less exhertion:

  1. ActMovePerSpellRound

= Typical movement cost for a skill (per round)

= DamCap / 5

As we still want a target of total movement covering 75 rounds, this results in:

  1. ActMoveSpell

= Component of ActMove awarded to cover spell-based combat

= 75 * ActMovePerSpellRound

ActMove

The amount of movement consumed during combat is simply the sum of all the ways that a person will perform combat. For examples, fighters swing and use skills, but should not be given a spell based allowance. Conversely, casters should probably possess spell allowances but no melee or skill allowances. Rounding things out, clergy would have both melee and spell based allowances.

If we add the combat related allowance and the movement related allowance together, we get a total allowance, which is the amount of movement we want our players to have in order to insure the proper combat scenarios:

  1. ActMove

= Amount of movement points a character should possess

= ActMoveMovement + ActMoveMelee + ActMoveSkill + ActMoveSpell

  1. ActMove by Class-Subtype and Level

The upshot of this is shown in (Spreadsheet 41.).

The MoveCombat columns above attempt to show the total allowance being given based on class-subtype. This value is essentially just 75 rounds multiplied by the sum of the appropriate per-round amounts. That is, MoveCombat for fighters is 75 * (Melee/Rnd + Skill/Rnd).

All in all, the movement allowance is MUCH less than the combat allowance at all levels. We used some fairly general statements about how far players would have to travel between fights, which will be almost impossible to validate. Even if a person travels 2-3 times as far as we think they will, they are not significantly impacting their combat chances.

We also note that low-level players have a few hundred movement-points total, and that high-levels have a few thousand. These numbers do not seem overtly disconcerting.

Racial Modifiers

To further complicate matters as an optional enhancement, players will certainly expect that certain races use more or less movement per action (and/or have move total ActMove). As previously noted, movement is used as a limitation, so we should not create races that use less move per action AND have more total as this would invalidate the use of movement as a limitation.

For the most part, we appease the player's perception that movement costs should be race based by throwing in arbitrary racial multipliers onto each factor (movement, swings, etc.) However, they also carry through to the calculation of a player's total ActMove. If it takes that character less to perform a certain action, they are getting less of an allowance for that action.

Because of this, I am going to ignore “race” for the purpose of this movement discussion. Obviously, we are free to scale costs and allowances by any constant we wish, but to avoid confusion I won't do so.

Extensions for Non-Fighters

Following similar reasoning, we ought to be able to construct systems for caster's mana and clergy's piety that will have similar effects as warrior's movement. That is to say, we can construct ActMana and ActPiety such that they restrict casters/clergy to 75 rounds in combat.

In fact, if we again look at (Spreadsheet 41.), we can see the big discrepancy that casters movement has when compared to fighters. Players will almost certainly complain about this. We have no compelling reason to force casters to budget both movement AND mana. Each has the same goal. If we presume that a caster will not enter physical combat and that the mana system is properly constructed to limit casters to 75 rounds of combat, than we can safely relax the movement restriction on casters. That is to say, casters have more than enough movement for the fight, but their mana will run out if they attempt to plow.

Mana

Using equivalent reasoning as before, we base mana costs on the value of DamCap. In this fashion a low-level spell will cost less than a high level one:

  1. ManaPerRound

= Mana cost per round of spell casting

= DamCap / 2

By extension given the 75 round limit we desire:

  1. ActMana

= Player's total allowance of mana

= 75 * ManaPerRound

  1. Mana by Level

From this we learn that casters have from 133-2000 total points of mana. These numbers do not seem disconcertingly high or low. There is a gradual upward trend in ActMana so that each level gained awards more mana to the caster as well.

Under the hood, we also note the per-round mana casting costs. Higher level spells cost more to cast. Or said another way, high-level casters could cast a LOT of low level spells before running out of mana. Of course since those low-level spells do very little damage, everything works out OK.

Piety

Clergy use piety in the same way as casters use mana. In order to differentiate the two systems as more than just s semantic change, it was decided to make piety use a 0-100 scale for the maximum piety at all times. So instead of spells having a constant cost, but players having variable (increasing with level) total mana, prayers have a variable (decreasing with level) cost, but constant total piety.

Basically, if we read the above (Spreadsheet 42.) and convert to percentages, we represent our piety system properly. For example, a person always has 100.0 total piety points:

  1. ActPiety

= Player's total allowance of piety

= 100.0

The piety cost is then simply the ManaPerRound for the level of the prayer being invoked divided by the character's ActMana, expressed as a percentage to put it in terms of `piety':

  1. PietyPerRound

= Piety cost per round of praying

= ManaPerRound / ActMana * ActPiety

Logically then, the PietyPerRound for a prayer of my level is always 1/75 of my total piety. Therefore, the cost is 1.3333 piety per round for a prayer of my level. As another example, the a L25 prayer can be invoked by a L50 for a piety cost of 0.626 per round (= 12.52/2000 * 100).

Magic Equipment

One of the hallmarks of DIKU MUDs is the presence of stat-altering equipment. Players will almost certainly expect equipment that awards additional mana, piety or movement, so we should spend a moment and state the ramifications.

Realize that the fundamental purpose of mana, movement and piety is to restrict how long a player is able to remain in combat. These values are not as critical as say ActHP, but they do serve the purpose of discouraging players from plowing. If I have to regenerate after 10 spell casts to fix my mana, I may as well be casting against the toughest mob I can safely kill when I do it.

However, unlike ActHP, having extra movement, mana or piety does not impact my Power. It's presumed that characters are performing skills of their level, and the allowances are sufficient to allow them to. Having extra movement, mana or piety might let me perform skills over my level, but since it's also presumed that a person only knows certain skills at a certain point, this is somewhat moot.

At worst, a player might design their character to gain skills at a fast rate, and play to acquire +stat gear. They would be able consistently perform skills above expectations, thereby having greater SkillDamage than anticipated. Depending on the class, and how easy it is to accomplish this, there is a possible loophole created.

However, on the whole, +stat gear relaxes a restriction on players that merely discourages plowing. Sure, a player could acquire +stat gear and then go plowing, but so what? We devised the system to discourage the activity, not prevent it.

For the most part, +stat gear of this type is safe to introduce into the game in moderation. Provided that there is not a movement that acquires +stat gear in order to plow, or that advocates the fast-skills and +stat option of play, there is no real problem that a game designer needs to worry about. If either trend does crop up, this probably indicates that there is too much +stat gear, and something needs to be done.

Economy

More often than not, game development proceeds in complete ignorance of the economy. As we will most certainly want to provide items that impact Power for sale, we cannot hope to setup a cohesive game design and not address the economy in some fashion.

Obviously, since our system assumes that players will be using certain weapons, certain armor and certain gear, we clearly need to integrate our game design with the economy.

Mob Wealth

An appropriate starting point is simply to determine how much MobWealth each kill ought to be worth. It is reasonably intuitive to state that MobWealth ought to be a function of Power.

A creature that is twice as difficult to kill ought to be worth twice the booty. If it's not, then players will simply go whack some low-level mobs in order to raise funds.

However, going too far in the other extreme is also bad. If mobs of twice the Power are worth significantly more than twice the gold, then there is a real incentive to kill higher-level mobs. The only way to do this would be to group. Obviously, we don't want to require grouping, and a large (wealth) benefit for high Power mobs should be avoided.

Likewise, if double the Power leads to greatly more wealth, than it is more than likely that high Power characters will be awash in wealth. A high-level player could give away a “trivial” amount of their wealth to make a low-level player fantastically “rich”. Such a system encourages newbies to leech off of high-level players and generally creates a situation that is not desirable.

While it might seem that we want to model MobWealth in a similar fashion to MobXP (grows 2.2X for every doubling in Power), this in fact causes the economy to swing dramatically. Due to this larger doubling, the MobXP@L50 is 16000 times larger than MobXP@L1. If we were to use this for wealth, then we would be awarding 16K talens to a L50 for every talen that a L1 makes. As we will see, higher incomes translate into higher expenses. Accordingly, at high levels, things have gone through the roof and we get costs that are unpalatable. Similarly, since gold, unlike XP, can be traded freely from player to player, we should strive to keep the economy constrained as much as possible.

Therefore, we devise that MobWealth is simply a scalar multiple of Power. As mobs become tougher to kill, they become accordingly richer. However, there is no gold-incentive for killing weaker/stronger mobs.

[Note: There are many solutions to how to construct a balanced economy. Like the combat system, much iteration was tried, and I am merely presenting an end-case that seems to be a good balance of the various concerns that lie ahead. Feel free to deviate if you choose.]

The only significant boundary condition we need is to insure that low-level mobs have a handful of talens (on the order of 5-10). Because we know that Power@L1 is 196, I choose a scalar of 20:

  1. MobWealth

= Amount of wealth a mob should carry

= Power / 20

= ((level)1.759815 + 13)2 / 20

= 0.05 * (level1.759815 + 13)2

  1. Level, Power and MobWealth

As we can see, newbie mobs carry around 10 talens, while at L50 that amount has grown to 49K. Like Power, the L50 amount is 5000 times greater than the L1 amount.

The highest-level mobs have a million gold! Given the other numbers for this economy, this is a tremendous amount certain to appease the lucky group (probably 10+ PC's) able to kill such a mob.

Economic Feedback Loops

Like in the real world, the macro-economy is amazingly diverse and difficult to control. As game designers, we should avoid looking at specific individuals when evaluating the economy. Obviously, no individual should be able to impact the ideal free-market. However, too often implementers make drastic sweeping changes based on how well a handful of players are doing.

We are fortunate to be computer-modeling our economy, as it allows us to easily gather vast amounts of data about the economy. Without too much trouble, we can easily make it so that every action that gives or drains money from a player is classified, and we can keep running balance sheets either globally or level-by-level or even class-by-class.

Adding only minimal complexity, multipliers can be introduced to increase or decrease the amount of money flowing into/out of the economy from each action. The game designer simply needs to identify the desired state of the economy in terms of “repair costs should be 10% of my total costs”, and then provide a way for the multipliers to adjust based on the balance sheets.

Simply put, it is better to have an economy that automatically adjusts based on well specified target goals for gold availability and costs than to simply “wing it” and make drastic manual corrections when problems are noticed.

Balance Sheet Values

I will preface by saying that what follows is simply what I have found to work fairly well empirically. This is NOT an absolute discussion, and individual implementers should feel free to make adjustments in the desires that they choose. I am offering it primarily to give people some ideas of a starting place.

Each gold transaction is classified as one of:

Internal transfer: moving money from my person to my bank account.

Income: Money picked up off the ground or from a corpse.

Gamble: Money made at the casino.

Junk: Money awarded for junking items at a junkyard.

Rent: Money spent renting goods.

Repair: Money spent repairing goods.

Shop: Money spent in shops on miscellaneous.

Shop-components: Money spent in shops on components.

Shop-armor: Money spent in shops on armor or weapons.

Shop-pets: Money spent in shops buying pets.

Hospital: Money spent healing.

Data is collected globally and not broken down by class or level. I presently do not feel it is appropriate to make class or level distinctions as this would most likely result in some arbitrary skewing. Why should it cost a L5 ranger 100 talens to repair a helm, and a L10 cleric repairing the exact same helm be charged 200?

For the most part, we can ignore mobs entirely. Obviously, money very rarely moves between mobs to begin with, but realize that the economy we want to keep close tabs on begins and ends where a pc is not one-side of the transaction.

Also, we should collect two figures for each transaction, a net amount and a gross amount. Every transaction (income or drain) adds to the net amount, but only those transactions that increase the player's wealth contribute to the gross. The total amount ever made can be viewed from the gross, the net amount is viewed in the net, and we can derive the total amount ever drained by subtracting one from the other.

Total Income

Overall, players should make a small profit. We want them to build a small fortune over time, as this is a worthwhile goal for an RPG. We stipulate that we want the total net amount for all transactions divided by the total gross amount for all transactions to be roughly 1-2%. That is, for every 100 talens gained by PCs, they are keeping 1-2 of them.

Since the source of most of the money in the game is off of kills, we can fairly easily tweak MobWealth to achieve our values. If players are making too much, we can scale it up by a constant amount, and if too little, it can be scaled down.

Shops

Standard DIKU code allows for profit ratios to be specified so that shopkeepers always sell an item for more than they will buy it for. Unfortunately, this does not go quite far enough. Too often players will discover certain items that they will acquire in the field and bring back to sell. In a badly skewed economy, players will sell items to the shops more often than they buy things and the shop becomes a source of revenue.

In a realistic sense, shopkeepers set up shops to make money. If things kept being sold without ever being bought, supply and demand should kick in and the price ought to plummet. Devising a sophisticated market where each individual item has fluctuating prices is rather difficult, especially in light of relatively small player bases, etc. However, if we evaluate “shops” in their entirety, things get a bit simpler.

We simply stipulate that we want shops to have a 5% overall profit rate (for the shop). Therefore, for every 100 talens of items the shop sells to players, it will buy 95 talens worth of the player's goods. There is no requirement that the same items that are sold are bought. Nor do we care (overly much) that one shop makes money while another loses money. We are simply looking at the total amount of money spent and acquired in shops and saying that, on the whole, shops slightly drain money from players.

Experimentation showed that it was not necessary to adjust the price that shops sell items to players for. Simply adjusting the price that the shop would pay for an item that a player wanted to sell was sufficient.

Additionally, this had the effect of keeping the selling price (to stores) fairly low. Pleasantly, this encouraged a secondary auction market. I might buy a sword (new) from a store for 100 talens. After leveling, I might wish to upgrade. If the store only buys it back for 15 talens, then I might seek other players looking for a second-hand bargain via private auction.

Equipment Availability

Aside from finding gold directly on a mob, the other chief way players make money is from finding equipment and selling it. The importance of finding booty (equipment) as opposed to loot (money) is an appropriate area of concern. Too much booty feeds the equipment market and allows players to acquire gear, either replacement or upgrade, easily. Knowing, and adjusting the availability of gear is important to a well-balanced economy.

We established that selling armor and equipment to stores should amount to no more than 25% of a player's total gross income. A global modifier was established to control the success of loading equipment or other booty on mobs. The availability of equipment is scaled up and down to keep booty income in line with what is desired.

Keep in mind the other modifiers. If we had an economy in equilibrium, but too much money was booty oriented, the equipment modifier would drop and less equipment would be available. Since less equipment is available, less is being sold to the shops and the shop modifier would adjust (upwards) meaning that each item sold gives out slightly more gold. Also, the total income modifier will correct to insure that players still make a profit. Players won't be profiting as much from booty, but the loot modifier will increase.

Rent and Repair Feedback

Two large drains in the economy are the areas of rent and repair.

The first thing that should be established is what percentage of all drains the two should represent. For instance, maybe rent and repair should represent 70% of all money I spend. The remainder is spread to things like purchasing food, or upgrading items at the shops.

Concurrently, establishing the individual percentages for each area should be done. For instance, perhaps repair should be 50% of my costs, while daily rent should only be 20%.

We can sum up all areas of the economy and determine the total drain in a player's life, these can be compared to the individual drains for rent and repair, and the costs can be scaled up and down to insure the appropriate percentages are achieved.

I will come back to this discussion after we talk about rent and repair systems more in depth.

Advancing Our Economic Understanding

Let us proceed by combining what we already know and seeing where it leads us.

Gold Acquired

Realize that MobWealth is the total amount of wealth the mob possesses. However, wealth can either be in the form of coins (MobLoot), or held in the form of equipment (MobBooty) that can be hauled back to civilization and sold. During the shops feedback discussion we stated that booty would amount to about 25% of a player's total income.

  1. MobBooty

= Amount of wealth held by a mob in the form of booty

  1. 1/4 * MobWealth

Therefore, the remainder of MobWealth must be in the forms of gold:

  1. MobLoot

= Amount of wealth held by a mob in the form of coins

= MobWealth - MobBooty

= MobWealth - (1/4 * MobWealth)

  1. 3/4 * MobWealth

Since we also know KillsPerLevel, and if we assume that all booty is sold, we can combine to yield:

  1. GoldAcquiredPerLevel

= Total amount of wealth acquired per level

  1. MobWealth * KillsPerLevel

  1. GoldAcquiredPerLevel by Level

What we see from this is the amount of gold that a player of a given level will acquire during that level. That is, during the time that a player is a L10, we expect that they will make about 4813 talens.

Obviously, a L1's short (only 5.5 kills) career and low wealth per mob translates into virtually no gold acquired. Meanwhile, the reverse case for a L50 yields nearly 4 million coins for L50 alone.

A Preliminary Look at Expenses

For the economy to work well, we need to insure that the economy drains money at about the same rate (slightly less) than it adds it. We know that the feedback loops will fine tune the economy to yield the 2% income profit ratio desired, so we are fairly safe in simply devising drains to equal our faucets and letting the feedback loops tweak as needed.

Expenses will come in two flavors, upgrades and fees.

Obviously, as a player advances they will want to acquire better and better items and build their net assets. Such items we will call upgrades. Obviously, the game design assumes that the player is improving his lot. E.g. getting better weapons doing more damage, wearing better armor protecting better, etc. Nevertheless, paying for the upgrades is a significant expense.

The second kind of expense, fees, represents those unrecoverable expenses that are the cost of going adventuring. Buying food to keep you alive, repairing gear that gets damaged, paying informants, hiring helpers, etc. all qualify as fees.

Fees should be broken into two parts, combat and non-combat. Obviously, non-combat fees, like buying bags or food, do not really vary from class to class. However, the way combat fees are spent does vary because each class fights in a different manner. For instance, a fighter will need to pay to repair his equipment and perhaps some hospital costs. A caster, on the other hand, will consume precious components in the course of casting (and may also need repair or the hospital). Since we do not want the economy to unduly penalize any one class, we should strive to keep the combat fees identical for all classes.

Therefore, the sum of a person's combat-fees, non-combat-fees, and upgrades should equal their GoldAcquiredPerLevel. While the actual line items in each category may change depending on class, each class should be expected to pay about the same amount for each type of expense.

A Prelude to Equipment Repair

Upgrades and Planned Obsolescence

Clearly, upgrade expenses are simply the differential. That is to say, if I own a sword worth 100, and want a mace worth 120, I need only chip in 20 gold to make the purchase.

The problem with this is that if items retain their value, than the cost of goods must grow geometrically. That is, if we say that upgrades amount to 10% of a person's income (as an example), then the price of level X gear is 10% of GoldAcquiredPerLevel at level (X-1) + 10% of GoldAcquiredPerLevel at level (X-2) + … + GoldAcquiredPerLevel at level 1. Since the price compounds in this manner, it would be extraordinarily huge at high levels.

In itself, having high cost armor isn't inherently bad. It would force people to upgrade along obvious paths simply because trading up more than a few levels worth of gear at once would be prohibitively expensive.

However, since most gear will enter the shop-market by being acquired by adventurers and sold to the shop, a massive flaw is revealed. If equipment value becomes extraordinarily high, then finding equipment becomes more lucrative.

We would have two problems. First, players would be hunting equipment because it pays so much better. Why kill a L50 mob for a few thousand gold apiece when I can go whack a few L40's with equipment worth a few million?

Second, finding and selling equipment would basically destroy our economy by heaping massive money on a person. Even if we solve the first problem by somehow tweaking the shop profit ratios appropriately, the auction market will nullify this. For instance, if I sell L50 gear for 50K to the shop, and the shop turns around and asks 1 million for it, it won't be long before auctions take place. Sellers make much more than the shop pays, and buyers pay much less than they would from the shop.

The only obvious solution to this dilemma is to escape the geometric-growth assumption. That is to say, at the point I am ready to upgrade, the value of my present gear is essentially worthless. With essentially no trade-in value, then the cost of equipment closely mimics how the gold curves behave.

The obvious ramification of this plan is that gear must degrade, gradually becoming worthless. The period over which this degradation occurs must match the period over which an upgrade happens. In general, we want folks trading up their equipment once per level; therefore we are also saying that a given piece of equipment becomes worthless in the time it takes to gain a level.

Repairs Per Level

The obvious mechanism to have items degrade to worthlessness is to have them become damaged in the course of adventuring. Obviously, players will want to repair this damage, so some capability for repairing items must be present as well.

[Note: I will again reiterate that the economy has numerous “solutions”, all of which are valid. What I present is simply what I think is a good blend of the various numbers.]

To begin with, let us arbitrarily state that we want there to be 2.5 repairs per level:

  1. RepairsPerLevel

= Total number of complete repairs per level

  1. 2.5

That is to say, over the course of a given level, I am forced to repair my entire set of equipment 2.5 times. My helm needs 2.5 repairs, my suit needs 2.5 repairs, etc.

This number is entirely arbitrary, although we want to have it reasonably large so that players think that armor is in fact `repairable'. However, making it too large upsets the FightsPerRepair value.

Realize that when the equipment is new, it essentially has an “extra repair” in it. That is, my helm starts new, decays, is repaired fully (1.0), decays, repaired fully (1.0), decays, repaired partially (0.5), decays and is dead. The item is able to decay (RepairsPerLevel+1) time. As this is the case, it is probably more useful to speak of:

  1. DecaysPerLevel

= Total number of complete decays per level

  1. RepairsPerLevel+1

= 2.5 + 1

  1. 3.5

KillsPerRepair

Since we know how many KillsPerLevel, it is a simple matter to determine the number of fights a person has between repairs:

  1. KillsPerDecay

= Number of fights between successive repairs

= KillsPerLevel / DecaysPerLevel

= (1.53548 * (level) + 4) / (3.5)

  1. KillsPerDecay as a Function of Level

Clearly, we always want KillsPerDecay to be greater than 1.0, otherwise, a suit of equipment would completely decay in a single fight (leading to massive complaints). As we can see, the lowest value it reaches is at L1, where we can go just over one fight without repairing our gear. Obviously, this isn't great, but it's somewhat justifiable as it teaches newbies (early) about repairing their gear.

Since having to rush back to civilization to find a repair shop is somewhat of a hassle, as players rise in level and venture further abroad, it would be good if they can remain in the field longer without needing to repair. Thankfully, KillsPerDecay rises with level. A L50 can go more than 23 fights without needing to stop and repair their equipment.

Furthermore, since each of the above “kills” is thought to be a fair-fight, thought to last 60 rounds each, thought to be about 2-3 seconds per round, we establish that each fight is 2.5 minutes long. Newbies will have to repair about every 5 minutes, however, they are also leveling phenomenally fast, so this situation doesn't persist for too long. This newbie situation is a worst-case scenario using theoretical values for time. For practical purposes, the value is probably closer to every 15 or so minutes (not great, but not horrendous), while high-levels can play for many hours (roughly) without needing to repair.

Repair Cost Fraction

Pushing onward, we can next define the fraction of the full price that a single repair should cost. That is to say, if an item costs 100 gold new, what should it cost to fully repair it?

Interestingly, if this fraction is exactly the inverse of RepairsPerLevel (and since an item decays to nothing over a single level), then the total lifetime cost to repair the item equals the item's price. Although I can make no logical argument that this should be so, I like the elegance of it, so:

  1. RepairCostFraction

= Cost to fully repair an item in terms of the item's value

= 1 / 2.5

= 0.4

In theory, this number can be whatever the game designer wants. However, large values for RepairCostFraction seems to heavily weigh expenses toward repair (to the detriment of upgrades). Obviously, having repair costs exceed the GoldAcquiredPerLevel means a deficit situation for players and speaks badly of the game design. Not to mention, if repairs are a significant fraction of the item's total cost, the perception that it is “better” to just go replace the item rather than repair it grows.

Conversely, too low a value for RepairCostFraction raises the price of a suit of equipment. If we charge nothing for repair, then all of GoldAcquiredPerLevel must be used in upgrading. Obviously, having really expensive equipment suits also seems silly.

Level 1 Suit Cost

As there are multiple pieces of equipment in a suit of equipment, we want to insure that each piece is valuable. That is, each piece should be worth at least 1 piece of gold.

I choose to make the L1 suit cost 20 talens.

Level 1 Expenses

Since Level 1s will be given a suit of equipment to start with, they have no expenses related to upgrading.

However, during their L1 career, they will have to repair their L1 suit RepairsPerLevel times. Each repair will cost them RepairCostFraction times the price of the L1 suit.

Since we opted for elegance, RepairCostFraction and RepairsPerLevel cancel each other out, and the L1 has repair expenses equal to the price of their suit. This will be true regardless of our level, so I will just state that repair costs at any level equal the cost of the suit.

Level 1 Profit

First, we know GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L1 will be acquired during L1. Secondly, their L1 gear is adequately durable to let the player reach L2. Therefore, the player's total repair costs is simply the cost of the L1 suit, 20 talens.

Therefore, the difference is the amount the L1 makes obtaining L2. We would like this amount to be the cost of the next suit. So:

L1Profit = GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L1 - L1SuitCost

L2SuitCost = L1Profit

L2SuitCost = GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L1 - L1SuitCost

Extending the System

We can simply iterate this process and yield the SuitCost for any level we choose. Since this is basically an iterative equation, it quickly becomes messy, so I will forego any attempt to write it down in terms of level alone.

That is to say:

L3SuitCost = GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L2 - L2SuitCost

L4SuitCost = GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L3 - L3SuitCost

L5SuitCost = GoldAcquiredPerLevel@L4 - L4SuitCost

And so on…

  1. SuitCost

= The price of a full suit of equipment for a given level

= (GoldAcquiredPerLevel - SuitCost) [for previous level]

Obviously, this is non-intuitive. Hopefully, this spreadsheet will educate:

  1. Suit Costs

As you can see, SuitCost starts out fairly low at only 20 talens. For the first few levels, the price (almost) doubles each level.

By level 50, this trend has attenuated somewhat. The L50 SuitCost is only about 10% more expensive than the L49, although that 10% represents 160K talens. The L50 SuitCost is quite expensive, coming in at close to 2 million coins.

The net effect is to make it fairly difficult for a person to leapfrog upgrades. Suits more than a few levels above a person cost more than a person makes during that entire level.

A Cost Breakdown

It is somewhat interesting to further break down the costs, by fight, repair and level.

  1. Costs Break Down

Obviously, some of these columns we've seen before.

The Profit/Level column, which is simply the Income/Level - Repair_cost/Level is also the SuitCost for the next level.

One curious thing to keep an eye on is the Co-Ed Naked MUD Fighting scenario. Recall from the discussions of our simple combat setup, a L50 warrior fighting in L1 gear (or alternatively, naked) would be roughly equal to a L25 fighter. Killing a L25 yields 4545 talens per fight. Since they would be naked, there would be no repair costs accrued, for a total profit of 4545/fight. Contrast this value with the 25584/fight profit the L50 would make if in an appropriate L50 fair-fight using equipment. Therefore, it's more profitable to fight in proper equipment (and deal with the repair).

[Actually, this last remark may boil down to the constraint that we never want SuitCost to double from one level to the next. I never actually proved that this was the case, but it's probably a reasonable statement.]

Shifting the Rewards between XP and Wealth

[This needs work, this is just working notes so I remember.]

Lower (or 0) gold, becomes higher XP. This balances rewards so that a good XP mob is a bad gold mob and vice versa. Is this attainable?

However, …

Lower XP means more kills needed to level. Since we still want the same net profit, it works out that lower XP should make gold go down too…

Math:

Mob has n more XP than normal.

We must kill 1/n the normal number of mobs.

With 1/nth the kills, our repair costs are 1/nth as well.

With 1/nth the kills, we might have extra value/cost in suit (buy an extra, or sell with worth still in it). Suit profit is SuitCost(1-1/n)

To maintain profit, we must multiply gold on the mob by K, such that:

KI/n + S(1-1/n) - R/n - S_ = I - S_ - R

S = SuitCost at my level, S_ SuitCost at next level, R is repair costs, I is income/level.

I(K/n - 1) = R(1/n-1) + S(1/n-1)

K = [(R(1/n-1) + S(1/n-1))/I + 1]*n

For values of n ~= 1, the R and S terms disappear, and K is linear with n. Give more XP, must give more gold as well. Logical, but Weird!

Equipment Load and Replacement Rates

Since we know how much MobBooty must be found on each kill, and we know the SuitCost value, we can calculate a load rate.

  1. EQLoadRate

= Percentage of a full suit that must load each kill

= MobBooty / SuitCost

That is to say, knowing that MobWealth@L4 is roughly 30 gold, MobBooty@L4 is about 7.5 talens. Since SuitCost at L4 is 110 talens, we can see that we should find about 6.8% (= 7.5/110) of a suit on each mob we kill.

Obviously, this doesn't mean that 6.8% of the mobs have a complete suit. Simply, every mob of that level has a 6.8% chance of loading each item in that suit. In all likelihood, each mob will have a handful of pieces.

Along similar lines, if we know that a suit of equipment is only good for a single level, and we know how many KillsPerLevel there are, then we can derive the necessary replacement rate for equipment. The replacement rate is simply the critical value, under which, items are not loading fast enough to cover the obsolescence factor, and over which implies that more items are being loaded than are necessary for our adventurers.

  1. EQReplaceRate

= Load rate necessary for players to find EQ to replace damage items

= 1/KillsPerLevel

  1. EQLoadRate and EQReplaceRate as Functions of Level

From this we can see that as we rise in level, the chance of finding gear (EQLoadRate) decreases. On the other hand, each piece that is found is worth a considerable sum of money so there is some parity.

Intuitively, the more KillsPerLevel there are, the less equipment we need to find on any one given mob. Hence, we see that EQReplaceRate drops as we go up in level.

Of great significance is the comparison between EQLoadRate and EQReplaceRate. Since the EQLoadRate is less than the EQReplaceRate, this means that killing a level's worth of mobs does NOT provide sufficient gear to completely replace the adventurer's equipment. A person will only find about ␀ the amount of gear that they will need to in order to make up for their gear becoming junk.

On the surface, this would seem like a bad situation. Of course, if not corrected for, bad things will most certainly occur (As we will come to see, corrective action can be made). However, it has the pleasant effect of keeping equipment rare and precious. Players will be required to keep their gear in decent working order because there is no guarantee that they will be able to easily find a suitable replacement.

A Break Down of SuitCost

While it is nice to speak abstractly about the cost of a suit of equipment, in reality, a suit is composed of numerous pieces of equipment and so we must subdivide the price based on this.

As we learned earlier, a suit of armor has 17 pieces of equipment, plus a shield, plus a weapon. C.f. Percent of ActArmor Found on Any Given Equipment Slot

For the equipment alone, it seems natural to base the price of each piece on the amount of protection it provides. The more protection we get from that piece, the more that piece costs.

Likewise, as the decision to use a second weapon or a shield is reasonably balanced, we should insure that price does not factor into the equation overly much. That is to say, a weapon and a shield should be priced identically.

It remains to be decided the relationship between equipment and the held-items. Arbitrarily, I opt to make the held-items 20% of the total suit-cost (10% for each hand). Therefore:

  1. Cost Breakdown by Equipment Slot

Since we know the SuitCost for all levels, we can further refine this.

Anticipated Game Design Problems

Nothing ever works out perfectly in a system as complex as a MUD. I think it is important to be mindful of the tradeoffs that we have made along the way, and highlight some of the potential weaknesses and problem areas.

Uselessness of Armor

If we examine (Spreadsheet 11.), we note that the relative scores between L1 ActArmor and L50 ActArmor have a ratio of about 2:1. Effectively, this means that the protection afforded by a newbie suit is only ␀ that of the best armor in the game.

Since the cost of equipment will be somewhat an issue for players, it is quite possible that some players will realize that sacrificing some AC to save a buck is cost-effective. It is quite plausible to see players experimenting by sacrificing armor in order to get a better weapon.

[Needs more data from systems not yet developed]

Clumsiness of the Worn Equipment System

The development of clothing and armor and the relationships between them are pretty much contrived. It was necessary to restrict the armor from equipment on certain classes, and by using two types of equipment we manufactured the results that we desired. Furthermore, we have placed entirely arbitrary restrictions on various classes over which slots may have armor and which must be clothing in order to enforce these desired limitations.

In an ideal world, we might conceive a system of encumbrance whereby anyone could wear any worn equipment that would fit. The makeup of the equipment would impose limitations, either by not being flexible enough to accommodate certain actions, or by it possessing some physical liability that disrupts skills, magics or communing with one's deity.

Such a system would require a highly developed framework. For example, items would each have to each be rated for their individual composition (75% steel, 25% glass). Each material type would have to have characteristic properties defined for it (weight, flexibility, effects on magic, etc.). And every action would have to have in depth understanding of what limbs are required to perform the action in question. Platemail leggings and leather sleeves might allow me to punch well, but not to kick.

Needless to say, such a system would be unimaginably complex. The “fantasy” environment further complicates matters since there are no firm guidelines. Is plasma armor quiet or noisy? Can centaurs kick if they are wearing plate leggings on their hindquarters? Do metallic boots interfere significantly with a mage's ability to cast?

If such a system could be created, it would be far superior to the simplistic system mentioned here for worn equipment. However, the amount of time it would require for debugging and testing makes deployment somewhat problematic. The simplistic system is adequate for our purposes, and there is no reason to suppose that transitioning (at a later date) to a more complex encumbrance system is precluded.

Synergy and the Ultimate Group

When power was originally conceived, we assumed that we would ultimately see small- to medium-sized groups of high-level players. If we take another look at (Spreadsheet 1.), we can see that the relative power between L50 and L120 is around 20:1.

While we do make a SynergisticCorrection adjustment, in reality, it probably does not require 20 L50's to topple a single L120. Despite our best efforts, the system is complex enough to allow for one player's strengths to offset another's weaknesses and synergy to creep in.

We should not worry too greatly about this. If players interact to beat the system, it is certainly not a problem. In fact, doing so enhances the community and the overall enjoyability of the game.

While it would seem like the 20:1 ratio is obscenely high, we must recognize that using synergy, the big bad L120s can probably be toppled by a group of only 10-15 using a solid play strategy.

Likewise, we should recognize the impact synergy would have on playtime per level. If we reexamine (Spreadsheet 7.), we can see that it should take around 35 days of play to achieve L50. Since the effective power of a synergistic group exceeds that of an additive one, we expect that players could conceivably gain XP at a faster rate than what we anticipated.

The bottom line is that we should refrain from judging the “worth” of our system solely on how fast a given character is able to obtain L50, or how few L50s it took to kill Mighty Herclopuloid. The goal is simply to provide entertainment and a challenge, and provided that the gaming system does both, it can be regarded as a success.
